HEADLINE: A TV Reporter Finds a Home With a TV Past

BYLINE: By JOANNE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
A COAST GUARD cutter streams by, leaving a spray of water in its wake. Just a few waves behind: a tugboat. This is the sort of traffic Vera Gibbons routinely sees from the long stretch of windows in her 19th floor apartment at United Nations Plaza, along with sailboats and the odd kayak or two. 
 ''I grew up on the water,'' said Ms. Gibbons, 38, who moved to Manhattan 10 years ago from Mattapoisett, Mass., and who appears on television for Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine. 
 The expanses -- east, north and west, and almost floor to ceiling -- are both distracting and inspiring, and are still a fabulous novelty; it has been barely six months since Ms. Gibbons moved from an East 52nd Street co-op whose windows offered nothing but an up close and personal view of the neighbors. But she savors her new apartment's history and vibes as much as its views. 
 The previous owner was Walter Cronkite, who for five years used the 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment as an office. ''It was good karma,'' she said.
 When Ms. Gibbons, then a writer for Smart Money magazine, bought the 52nd Street one-bedroom in 1998, a few years after moving to the city, the lack of a view was really not a problem. ''I didn't think I needed one,'' she said. ''The apartment had a beautiful layout; it was safe and secure.''
 Ms. Gibbons rethought matters when, just after 9/11, she went from writing consumer pieces and articles about charitable giving to representing Smart Money in television segments about the latest economic forecasts. (Is the employment picture getting rosier? What are the growing segments of the job market? What's the best way to choose an accountant?) 
 The good news about Ms. Gibbons's new slate of responsibilities: she was no longer expected to show up at the office every day. The bad news: she was no longer expected to show up at the office every day. ''I was spending most of my time by myself in my gloomy apartment analyzing data,'' said Ms. Gibbons, who moved to Kiplinger's in 2003. She appears Saturday mornings on MSNBC; Mondays and Thursdays on CNN Headline News; and monthly on CBS's ''Early Show'' and the weekend edition of ''Today.'' 
 ''I began fiddling around on the Internet looking for a new place and became increasingly more serious this year,'' she said. ''This was such a rough winter.'' It was dark, and she was down. 
 Then Ms. Gibbons happened on the Fox Residential Realty Web site, which featured an enticing description of a one-bedroom apartment with lofty vistas. The broker, Joanna Simon, showed her around and noticed her noticing the photos of Mr. Cronkite, the newscaster long described as the most trusted man in America. ''She said, 'I don't know if you know it, but this is Walter Cronkite's apartment,''' Ms. Gibbons recalled.
 There was, Ms. Gibbons remembered, a conference table in the middle of the living room, a work station nestled between two sets of built-in bookcases, a big leather easy chair in one corner and a handsome desk in another. There were ornate brass knobs on the doors (not Ms. Gibbons's taste), ornate moldings painted brown with gold speckles (totally not Ms. Gibbons's taste) and brown tiles paving the kitchen walls (oh dear).
 ''It looked like an office, but I saw how I could turn it around,'' she said. ''I just thought, 'Wouldn't it be fun to have Walter Cronkite's apartment?''' She would not say precisely what she paid, but said it was less than $1 million for what she calls multimillion-dollar views. 
 Few are immune to their charms. ''When the cable guy came,'' Ms. Gibbons recalled, ''he said, 'So where can I put my lounge chair?'''
 In February, soon after Ms. Gibbons put down her deposit, she got a call from the broker. The ever-cordial Mr. Cronkite would be happy to meet her. When was she free? That was easy. ''I'm free,'' Ms. Gibbons remembered answering, ''when he's free.'' 
 A few days later, broker, buyer and seller sat companionably around the conference table in the apartment. ''He was such a nice guy, everything you'd expect him to be,'' Ms. Gibbons recalled. He asked about her job, and he asked her to his nearby apartment to have a drink with his family.
 He also asked Ms. Gibbons to drop by his place in Martha's Vineyard (she did, during a trip home this past August) and wanted to know if she would be interested in any of the pieces in the office. Only the desk, a family heirloom, tempted her, but it was already promised to Mr. Cronkite's son.
 Furniture acquisition is moving at a stately pace, as is the whole process of home improvement. So far, two decorative columns in the entry have been clipped, leaving the bases behind. The ornate moldings were painted white after Ms. Gibbons decided it was too big a production to remove them, and some of the brass door handles have been replaced by sleek chrome. 
 But her yellow and white striped wallpaper has not been put up in the entryway. The flat-screen television that is planned for the spot that held Mr. Cronkite's computer has been ordered but has yet to appear. Ditto the contingent from California Closets. 
 The sofa pillows, the teal draperies, the blue and white floral-covered headboard for the bed and the cream-colored cushions for the window seat are currently represented by fabric swatches. Eventually, the appliances in the galley kitchen -- only morning coffee is prepared there -- will be upgraded, with the Formica replaced by granite.
 But Ms. Gibbons, who has animated the living room with family photos, seems to feel no particular urgency about getting things spruced up. ''It just means more checks to write,'' she said.
 Still, the pressure may soon start to mount. ''My friends in the media want to know when the housewarming party is going to be, and they want to know if Walter is going to come,'' Ms. Gibbons said. ''He's already told me he'll be there.''

HEADLINE: Embracing the Neighborhood Ambience 

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
CONSTANCE K. NEWSOM takes pride in her prewar row house in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn -- pre-Civil War, that is -- but she is also looking forward to some new neighbors across the street, a row of 14 starkly modern single-family town houses taking shape in cinderblock outlines.
 The town houses on State Street, priced at about $2.6 million, are the leading edge of a series of projects that are to fill in lots that were cleared decades ago in the name of urban renewal, only to become a battleground of urban dreams.
For years, Ms. Newsom and her neighbors on State Street fought off proposals to turn the block into high-rise low-income housing, or a huge court complex. Now they are mostly thrilled with the plans but anxious about how things will finally look. The town houses are part of a larger project: It will eventually include condominium developments, lofts, commercial space, a theater and subsidized housing, much of it for people working in the entertainment industry. 
 The houses, under construction by two developers, Abby Hamlin and Francis Greenburger, were designed to embrace the lightly ornamented Greek Revival brick buildings across the street built in the late 1840's, and the more elaborate Italianate 1870's brownstone down the block, while at the same time remaining decidedly different.
 Averaging just under 18 feet wide, the houses are to include front stoops, iron railings, cast limestone details, and facade lines to echo those of their older neighbors, along with patches of old-fashioned red brick. 
 But the new buildings dropped the ornamentation of their neighbors and added some modern strokes -- swatches or entire facades of more contemporary white and black bricks, and dramatic window layouts, some set off by wide copper panels, that change from house to house. Every facade is different. ''We were looking for a way to respond to the neighborhood, but in a way that was original,'' Ms. Hamlin said. 
 Ms. Hamlin managed the portfolios for several families with large real estate holdings in New York as president of Swig, Weiler & Arnow, before setting up her own development company, Hamlin Ventures. The project is a joint venture of her firm and the much larger Time Equities, a real estate development and management firm headed by Mr. Greenburger.
 The design by Rogers Marvel Architects was one of nine winners of housing design awards to be presented later this month by the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter. (Richard Meier was also a winner this year for his recent glass tower at 165 Charles Street, as was Davis Brody Bond, for Strivers Gardens, a condo project on West 135th Street.)
 Ms. Newsom, who was chairwoman of a subcommittee that reviewed proposals for the site, said that although some neighbors ''wanted Corinthian columns,'' people are ''essentially happy,'' based on the renderings they have seen and the plans reviewed by their architect.
 ''Modern design is the only thing you can do credibly,'' she said. ''But it will be like Avery Fisher Hall, until the bands start to play, we won't know what it sounds like.'' 
 The new town houses are priced somewhat above the prevailing prices for older town houses in the neighborhood, where, brokers say, recent sales have ranged up to about $1.9 million. But unlike older houses, which often require restoration or redesign, the new houses will be completely finished, Ms. Hamlin said, with materials like honed slate, marble and teak, which are offered in the latest Manhattan condo developments, but with far more space, along with a private backyard and a working fireplace.
 And unlike older town houses, which often let in little light through their narrow windows and northern exposures, these will include a 21-foot wall of windows facing the backyards, which are 37 feet deep. 
 Some of the town houses will have a fifth-floor penthouse and gardens, other smaller ones will have front balconies on the fourth floor, framed by a roof cornice line, like a giant picture window. Unlike condos, each house will also have a 900-square-foot cellar.
 Ms. Hamlin said most of the potential buyers -- one house is now in contract -- have been from Manhattan, families with two or three children, seeking more space. The town houses are around the corner from the A line subway and about 20 minutes to Times Square. 
 Jonathan J. Marvel, a principal in Rogers Marvel, said that the opportunity to design a unified block of individual row houses was extraordinary, almost unknown because many of the last blocks of speculative row houses were built in Harlem at the turn of the 20th century.
 ''It is something of our time, and not out of place in the neighborhood,'' he said. ''It is also something playful, that creates a sense of individuality, yet all within the composition as a whole.''
 If the houses sell, the developers plan to build 10 more around the corner of State and Hoyt Street, and other developers might be prompted to follow their lead, especially where the zoning already bars more dense development. 
 Town house developments have been rare for the last century because developers usually want to put up the most housing in the smallest possible space. There have been only a few rows of luxury town houses built, and they have had their troubles.
 In the 1980's, Sheldon Solow built a row of 11 18-foot-wide granite-clad town houses on East 67th Street near Second Avenue in Manhattan, adjacent to a 45-story building he built that used up most of the zoning rights for the site.
 The houses were offered for sale in the mid-1980's for several million dollars each, but amid the real estate recession that followed, they were never sold, and are now offered for rent, with some now divided into two and three apartments. Many row houses built outside Manhattan in recent years have been two- or three-family houses constructed under city programs for buyers with moderate income. 
 But Richard Bearak, the deputy director for planning and development in the Brooklyn borough president's office, said new contextual zoning rules in neighborhoods like Park Slope that limit building sizes could encourage the construction of row houses, because they are smaller. 
 Four and a half years ago, the developers bought the State Street site from New York State for $4.6 million, after being selected in response to a request for proposals. The market value of vacant land in downtown Brooklyn has since soared. Though the developers paid less than $10 a square foot for 500,000 square feet of development rights, after excluding the subsidized project, land in the area has recently been offered for sale for as much as $150 per square foot of development, Ms. Hamlin said. 
 A few years back, Karen Sebiri, a broker for Prudential Douglas Elliman (the new town house project is being marketed by Corcoran), considered buying a row house on this section of State Street, but was scared off by the uncertainty of what might be built next door. Now she said she believes the new project will be ''a big boost for the entire neighborhood.''
 ''When you put something like this in, you are only going to bring up prices in the neighborhood,'' she said. ''Had I known there would be luxury town houses across the street, I would have bought.''

HEADLINE: Medicaid's Code Red

BYLINE: By Louis S. Richman. 
Louis S. Richman is a research associate at the American Institute for Economic Research.

 BODY:
NEW YORK lawmakers are understandably concerned about the runaway cost of Medicaid. With nearly four million people receiving benefits, New York's program is the largest and most costly in the country.
 And the program is rife with fraud and abuse. According to James Mehmet, former investigator for the Health Department's fraud and abuse office in New York City, some 40 percent of all claims in the state are considered questionable, costing taxpayers as much as $18 billion a year. 
Unfortunately, the reform agenda being pushed in Albany focuses mostly on various symptoms of the problem, rather than the problem itself, which is structural. Medicaid is not one program, but 56 different ones operating in the 50 states, Washington and five United States territories. Unlike Medicare, which is entirely a federal program, Medicaid is paid for by both the federal and state governments. 
 Like many other federal initiatives, the program had modest beginnings, with a first-year budget in 1965 of $770 million. This year, it will cost about $330 billion. New York's share of this will be around $45 billion, nearly 14 percent of the total.
 Since states are authorized to supplement federally mandated services and extend eligibility beyond what Washington requires, programs vary greatly, giving states considerable flexibility as they consider ways to fix their ailing programs. New York offers one of the most comprehensive and inclusive programs in the country, spending nearly $10,800 per year per beneficiary. California, by contrast, spends less than half that per beneficiary.
 Through a complicated cost-sharing formula based on a state's average per capita income, federal matching funds cover from about half to more than three-fourths of the states' Medicaid costs. On average, Washington picks up 57 percent of the tab.
 One of Albany's complaints, voiced by Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader, and others, is that Washington is shortchanging New York, reimbursing only half of the cost. According to Mr. Bruno, the 50 percent federal share New York receives is lower than that of 37 other states and more than 10 percent below the national average. ''If our United States senators could even get New York up to the 60 percent national average,'' he said, ''we would receive almost $5 billion more.'' 
 Medicaid began as a welfare program, providing basic medical services and hospital care to welfare recipients. Eligibility was restricted to families and households with limited assets and incomes at or below the federal poverty line. Over time, the mission was expanded to cover people with disabilities, elderly nursing-home residents who have exhausted their savings and assets, former welfare recipients and pregnant women, infants and children from households with incomes up to twice the poverty level. No state has been more generous in extending eligibility than New York.
 To fix Medicaid, the program needs to be fundamentally rethought. The only alternatives to such a rethinking involve ending eligibility for thousands of beneficiaries, cutting back on treatments available under the program and demanding more money from Washington at a time when the federal government seeks to provide less. All these options are political nonstarters and would do little to alter the program's structural flaws. 
 Fortunately, states like Colorado, Florida and South Carolina recognize the need to change and have developed a new model that other states could use. Perhaps New York can learn from their experience. 
 Under the new patient-centered approach these states are pursuing, they would no longer pay Medicaid bills directly. Instead, they would give eligible recipients cash grants to purchase health insurance from a range of providers approved by the state through a competitive bidding process not unlike the process used to qualify insurers under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. Any part of the cash grant not spent on insurance would be invested in a medical-savings account to cover deductibles and co-payments.
 Such a system would have several advantages. Program participants would be indistinguishable from other insured patients, and therefore doctors, hospitals and clinics would no longer have an incentive to spurn them and would be far less likely to get away with overbilling and other fraudulent charges. Besides, for $20,000 a year -- less than half of what the program now costs the state -- a family of four could purchase a good insurance plan. 
 Because Medicaid beneficiaries would have an incentive to seek the best insurance value for their money, and to work their way into better jobs requiring less assistance, Medicaid's costs could be brought under control. It would be a win-win situation all around.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Where There's Smoke, There's Still Ire

BYLINE: By DONNA KUTT NAHAS

 BODY:
IN 2003 when state lawmakers debated a bill to eliminate smoking from nearly all workplaces, Jim Haefner predicted that it would ruin his bar business in Lynbrook. 
 Mr. Haefner, who has been serving cocktails and beer at B.K. Sweeney's American Grill for nearly 20 years, said he has never been bothered by a smoke-filled barroom. But now, two years since the ban took effect in July 2003, he says he ''kind of likes'' the smoking ban and relishes going home not smelling like smoke.
But some bar owners are not so happy, saying their profits have decreased under the ban. A group of Suffolk County tavern owners have filed two lawsuits to overturn the measure. 
 Under the law, bar owners who can prove that the ban has caused undue financial hardship can apply to local health departments for a waiver. Yet no one has applied for a waiver in either Nassau or Suffolk County, said Cynthia Brown, spokeswoman for the Nassau Health Department, and Lori Benincasa, director of health education for the Suffolk Department of Health Services. 
 Despite the ban and hundreds of citations for violating the law, smoking continues in some Long Island bars. Many bars in Nassau and Suffolk would go out of business, owners say, if they complied with the law, which is enforced by inspectors from the county health departments who are dispatched if a complaint is received or visit during regular food inspections.
 ''After 10 p.m., if you go almost anywhere on Long Island, most people smoke in bars,'' said Jack McCarthy, the president of the Suffolk County Restaurant and Tavern Association. ''They figure the health inspectors are gone, so they smoke.''
 The initial no-smoking bill, introduced by State Senator Charles J. Fuschillo, Republican of Merrick, and Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, Democrat of Manhattan, was intended primarily to protect workers from secondhand smoke.
 A recent study financed by the State Department of Health and reported in the international journal Tobacco Control in August said that the rates of respiratory and related illnesses among bar workers dropped to 38 percent in 2004 from 88 percent in 2002. The department said that 93 percent of the state's 78,000 restaurants, bars and bowling alleys were complying with the law.
 But some restaurants and taverns say that there are economic ramifications and that their profits are eroding because of the smoking ban.
 ''Initially it was quite a blow,'' said Claudia Bruno, the executive director of the Long Island chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association. ''Restaurants were off 10 to 15 percent for the first year. Some have seen their businesses come back, and some are at the same level. But it's the bars that are feeling it.''
 Mr. McCarthy contends that 70 percent of his 250 members say their business is off 20 to 50 percent.
 ''Money is made on cocktails, desserts, cordials and bottles of wine,'' said Mr. McCarthy, who owns McCarthy's Pub in Centereach.
 Yet the State Department of Taxation and Finance said that sales at bars and taverns from September 2003 to August 2004, the most recent period reported, were up nearly 3.5 percent compared with the same period a year earlier. 
 The law says that complying with the ban means that bar and restaurant owners must post no-smoking signs, remove ashtrays and make a reasonable effort to prevent customers from smoking. 
 In the last year in Nassau County, 312 violations were recorded, and in Suffolk, 157 violations were issued from July 2003 through Sept. 21. Violators can be fined up to $1,000 by the local health department for a first offense. 
 Late one night in September at the Posh Ultra Lounge at the Garden City Hotel, two women in their 20's held cocktails in one hand and cigarettes in the other. When asked if they were aware that smoking was prohibited in public places, they shouted above the din, ''You can smoke here.'' At the other side of the bar, a circle of well-dressed women puffed on cigarettes, chatted and giggled as bouncers stood nearby.
 Brian Rosenberg, the hotel's vice president who oversees the lounge, said: ''We are trying to follow the law as best we can. We have over 5,000 square feet. We say, 'Put it out,' and they walk to another area of the nightclub and light up again.''
 From August 2004 to August 2005, 248 complaints about illegal smoking were reported to the Nassau Health Department, Ms. Brown said. In Suffolk, 602 complaints were logged over a two-year period beginning in July 2003, Ms. Benincasa said.
 Many bar and restaurant owners who do comply with the ban complain that the law's instructions on enforcement are vague. 
 ''You cannot make a bar or restaurant owner a police officer,'' said John R. Ryerson, who owns McGuire's Restaurant and Comedy Club in Bohemia. ''Am I a police officer? If I am, then deputize me and give me a badge.''
 Opponents contend that the ban also harms the industry that markets electronic games and jukeboxes to bars. Danny Frank, the executive director of the Amusement and Music Owners of New York, a trade group, says that because customers cannot smoke in bars, they spend less time drinking and less time shooting pool or playing electronic shuffleboard.
 ''Look at what they've done to our industry, and the hardships they have imposed,'' he said. ''They are not getting to the heart of the problem. They don't hit the target but shoot an arrow in the woods and hurt someone else who really shouldn't be a victim.''
 Some taverns in Suffolk are fighting the legislation in court. Last October three bar owners filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court challenging the Suffolk health department's ruling that they had violated the ban when they continued to serve alcoholic drinks to customers who refused to stop smoking. The judge, Paul J. Baisley Jr., agreed with the bar owners and said the department's ruling was ''arbitrary and capricious.'' 
 In April, Suffolk County appealed the decision to the Appellate Division in Brooklyn. The court is expected to rule in three to six months, after it hears oral arguments. 
 The same Suffolk taverns filed a second lawsuit against the health department in June in an effort to strike down the law. William C. Goggins, the lawyer for the bar owners, said the ban was written in ''such a manner as to permit or encourage arbitrary enforcement.'' 
 Opponents say that even if the ban is not overturned, they will fight to amend the law and shift the burden of guilt from the bar owner to the smoker. 
 Senator John J. Flanagan, Republican of East Northport, said he agreed with opponents that the law was not being enforced evenly, and he said a bill he introduced in June would cite ''both violators'' of the law: the bar owner and the smoker. 
 The bill did not come to a vote in the Senate, but Mr. Flanagan said he would refer it to the Health Committee again in January. 
 Brian X. Foley, a member of the Suffolk County Legislature who wrote the county's version of the law, said the push for an amendment was an attempt to undercut the measure. 
 ''The Suffolk Bar and Tavern Association is opposed to any kind of legislation that will protect lives,'' said Mr. Foley, a Patchogue Democrat who is running for Brookhaven town supervisor. ''Every worker in a restaurant, corporate tower in Manhattan or corner tavern has a right to a safe, healthy workplace.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Rich Wolff and Kristin Zurlo step out for a smoke at B.K. Sweeney's American Grill in Lynbrook. (Photo by Kirk Condyles for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Medicaid's Code Red

Louis S. Richman is a research associate at the American Institute for Economic Research.

HEADLINE: Putting Charity Through the 'What's in It for Me?' Test

BYLINE: By EDUARDO PORTER

 BODY:
WE must be really good people. By the end of last week, American charities had raised more than $1.4 billion to help survivors of Hurricane Katrina, according to The Chronicle of Philanthropy. The Red Cross said that it alone had received more than $1 billion in pledges and donations. 
 But are we really as selfless as all that? Is our willingness to deprive ourselves to give money to an anonymous refugee simply driven by a disinterested desire to do good? Biologists, psychologists and economists who have studied such acts of goodness say there is more to altruistic behavior than meets the eye. 
For one, altruism isn't an exclusively human trait. Vampire bats are pretty altruistic, too, regurgitating blood for members of the group that haven't eaten. Sterile worker bees, which are incapable of conscious thought, let alone moral behavior, are about as altruistic as a living creature can be: they give their lives so their queen may reproduce.
 And the altruistic impulse in humans is frequently absent in the face of need, which seems inconsistent with selfless goodness. Why does the generosity sparked by events like Katrina fail to appear when it comes to helping the 700,000 African children who die from diarrhea every year for lack of clean water? 
 Kathleen D. McCarthy, director of the Center on Philanthropy and Civil Society at the City University of New York, argued that Americans' response to Katrina had much to do with what she calls the ''but for the grace of God factor.'' The devastation hit so close to home that they could imagine their own living rooms under water. It's harder for them to put themselves in the place of a dying African child.
 The impulse toward goodness, in fact, varies according to circumstance. In an experiment by economists at the University of Chicago, the University of Maryland, the University of Nevada at Reno and East Carolina University, residents of Pitt County, N. C., were asked to contribute to a center to study natural-hazard mitigation, as a response to the devastation caused by Hurricanes Dennis and Floyd in eastern North Carolina.
 Economists found, unsurprisingly, that people were much more likely to contribute when their donations entered them into a lottery in which they could win several hundred dollars. But they also found that contributions of white men rose by a similar rate when beautiful white women were asking for money. 
 In most altruistic acts, there is something in it for the giver. ''At one level, altruism has a selfish component to it,'' said the economist Gary Becker, a pioneer in the analysis of altruistic giving. 
 People get several things from acting altruistically. There's the enlightened self-interest: the needy may feel they are more likely to receive help when they themselves are in trouble. Then there's the inner glow that comes from acting according to one's ideals: be it giving to needy children or to church on Sunday. Having a good deed made known also has its glory, as well as avoiding the stigma of not contributing when everyone else in the congregation, alumni association or social club has. 
 These factors help explain why typically fewer than 1 percent of contributors to a given cause are anonymous, researchers say, or why people love to lug their stuff around in tote bags with the logo of their public radio station. Corporations virtually never give without trumpeting the act in a news release. 
 The selfishness may just be part of our wiring. Biologists were long stumped by altruism in animals because it didn't seem to make evolutionary sense. Creatures like the altruistic vampire bat, it was theorized, would eventually be wiped out of the gene pool because forgoing consumption to aid a fellow in need would reduce their own chance of survival and reproduction. This would leave only selfish bats. 
 But biologists have found that this only appears to be a paradox. They observed that altruistic animals tend to be more helpful with their own family or clan, which have a higher chance of sharing these altruistic genes. Researchers also found that altruistic animals engage in tit-for-tat strategies: generous to those who are generous back, but withholding from the selfish. 
 And, of course, the altruists are usually accompanied by those who prey on them. For example, as Americans reached for their pocketbooks to help hurricane victims, scam artists started phony Web sites to take their money. The thieves were behaving like the cuckoo, which leaves its eggs in the nests of other birds. When the cuckoo chick hatches, it throws the other eggs and chicks out of the nest, and the host parent -- hard-wired to care for chicks -- unknowingly raises the intruder.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 9, 2005

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about motivations of people who donate money included a garbled sentence. It should have read: ''There's the enlightened self-interest: donors give in the belief that if they run into trouble, they will be more likely to receive help.''

HEADLINE: My Brother's Keeper

BYLINE: By Bobbie Ann Mason. 
Bobbie Ann Mason is writer in residence at the University of Kentucky and the author, most recently, of ''An Atomic Romance: A Novel.''

DATELINE: Mayfield, Ky. 

 BODY:

Personal Accounts
 Numbers don't lie, but they can tell different stories. America's 4.9 percent unemployment rate in August was near historic lows, for example, but last year wages for the average American worker (adjusted for inflation) fell for the first time in a decade. Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter -- the 15th quarterly increase in a row -- but median household income remains below what it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter, but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period last year, when household debt reached a record high. And so on. 
 But how, in this era of killer hurricanes and housing bubbles, are Americans actually doing? To get a more human answer to that question, the Op-Ed page asked writers in different parts of the country to provide snapshots of their local economies over the next year. Here are their initial dispatches.
 ON the Monday after Hurricane Katrina, cars lined up on Broadway, a busy street here in my hometown. Rumors of $4-a-gallon gas sent people straight to my brother's store, Don Mason's Gas-N-Go. 
 ''I sold 5,000 gallons at $2.46, twice as much in six hours as I did on the best day I'd ever had,'' Don told me. ''But the next day was the worst -- I had no gas.''
 Don sells generic gas, and he has had trouble getting it. ''Being unbranded hurts,'' he says. Unbranded usually sells for a bit less than the big names like Shell and BP, but the gas comes from the same place. ''The only difference is their additives,'' he says. 
 When the refineries shut down for Hurricane Rita, allocations to the big brands got priority, Don says. He pays up to 30 cents a gallon more than his competitors do. This week he was selling gas for $2.79 -- it cost him $2.71 -- and the name-brand stations in town were selling for 10 cents less. 
 ''I can't compete if this keeps up,'' he told me. 
 All his life Don wanted to own his own business. After working for Coca-Cola for many years, he finally managed, in 2002, at age 45, to buy a small gas station, a quaint little building that he stocked with snacks from Sam's Club. Business took off, enabling him to build a larger store and quit Coca-Cola. He and his wife, who teaches third grade, had built a new home. Their two sons are grown -- one newly wed and living nearby, the other a student at the local Baptist Bible college. Don's dream of being his own boss was complete. 
 You pump your gas outside, but you have to pay inside so that you can buy stuff and make small talk. The profits aren't in the gas. They're in the junk snacks, light bulbs, cake mix, motor oil, sausage biscuits, Spicy Tater Babies. Don arrives before 6 a.m. to create breakfast for people on the go. On the wall above his milk cooler is a mural of a Holstein cow and a sign from our father's old dairy -- Mason's Dairy Grade A Buttermilk.
 Don's not afraid to risk losing business. When the town considered legalizing alcohol, he slapped a ''Vote No'' sign on his window. And he won't sell lottery tickets. ''They're a tax on poor people,'' he explains. 
 Now the hurricanes have churned and spun many people's dreams. Don is disturbed by the difference between the prices he and his competitors pay.
 ''Last week I ordered a load and got a good price, $2.31 -- good till 6 p.m., but they didn't deliver until 11 p.m., and the price had shot up to $2.65. I'd been selling for $2.59 all day. They jacked up the price because Hurricane Rita was coming, but Rita was still on the other side of the Florida Keys,'' he told me.
 He called the distributor in Paducah, Ky., and the headquarters in Denver but got the runaround. Nobody would discuss the price. ''They can't justify it,'' Don said. 
 In his struggle, he got lucky for a couple of days. He got one load of gas out of Louisville for 21 cents cheaper than he could get it from nearby Paducah, and he got a load of branded gas by mistake -- 40 cents cheaper than unbranded. 
 ''It'll straighten out in a couple of weeks and go back to normal,'' he said. ''Before Rita, prices were going down and I was doing pretty good.'' But the local economy is in a whirl, with a big employer moving out.
 Don said, ''Bush keeps hollering about how good we're doing, but we're not doing any good. I'm not setting the woods on fire, but I'm making it. If people think you're doing good they'll stop by. If you get a new truck, park it out front, and people will think you're doing good. Image is everything.''
 He laughed. ''People want to see you do good. I've lived here all my life. People know me.''

HEADLINE: City of the Big Gaps

BYLINE: By Luis Alberto Urrea. 
Luis Alberto Urrea, the author of ''The Devil's Highway,'' is a professor of English at the University of Illinois-Chicago.

DATELINE: Naperville, Ill. 

 BODY:

Personal Accounts
Numbers don't lie, but they can tell different stories. America's 4.9 percent unemployment rate in August was near historic lows, for example, but last year wages for the average American worker (adjusted for inflation) fell for the first time in a decade. Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter -- the 15th quarterly increase in a row -- but median household income remains below what it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter, but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period last year, when household debt reached a record high. And so on.
 But how, in this era of killer hurricanes and housing bubbles, are Americans actually doing? To get a more human answer to that question, the Op-Ed page asked writers in different parts of the country to provide snapshots of their local economies over the next year. Here are their initial dispatches.
 HURRICANE KATRINA blew a young African-American football star to the Chicago suburb where I live.
 It's not just a White Christmas here in Naperville -- it's white all year round. The parking lot of Naperville North High School is liberally larded with BMW's and pop-top sports cars. But A. J. Liddell's race has not affected the city's welcome to him and his family -- the suburbs, too, want to help. That A. J. is a formidable football player has, perhaps, jacked up the enthusiasm. One fundraiser brought in more than $14,000 for his family.
 But few of the hundreds, if not thousands, of poor evacuees now staring at Chicago's formidable towers are likely to enjoy the good fortunes of A. J. Liddell. And that's the larger story of the local economy: that in this era of outsourcing, housing bubbles and budget deficit pay-downs, the traditional Chicago gap between haves and have-nots has eroded into a chasm. 
 We are the city, you will recall, where just over a decade ago more than 700 people died in a heat wave. Read: poor people. Read: poor old people of color. This year, when a potentially deadly repeat was forecast, the news media started to run panicky stories about how to cool yourself down if you didn't have air-conditioning. Think residents of the Cabrini-Green public housing complex sitting in tubs of cold water for eight hours.
 And now, with the cost of gas and heating oil on the rise, there is real worry that a classic Chicago cold snap could cause another tragedy among this same group. Gas prices in the Chicago area have risen this summer by double the usual percentage rate.
 But it's the malaise in the schools that reflects the sharpening of the class struggle during the Bush era.
 The majority of the evacuee children being absorbed here are not going to Naperville North, but to places like the 21 Chicago public schools that have failed to meet state testing standards for six years, putting them in danger of being shut down under the Bush administration's No Child Left Behind law. That's 12 elementary and nine high schools in some of the neediest sections of this city. While the city frantically tries to restructure seven of these schools, it is also paying a consultant $1.5 million to figure out what to do with the other 14. If one of the elements of disaster is financial crisis, imagine the effect of over a million more dollars bleeding out -- before the needs of the new students are met.
 Even in the affluent western suburbs, certain school districts have eliminated mandatory physical education in high school because there is no money for it. Perhaps there should have been another law called ''no child left on his/her behind.''
 This summer, the gap in pupil spending between the haves and the have-nots in Illinois widened substantially, with the top-spending district spending a whopping $19,361 more per student than the lowest-spending districts in the state. That's $4,000 higher than last year and the biggest reported gap in 10 years. You begin to see how education is the canary in this fiscal coal mine. If you can't afford gym, if you can't afford special ed, if you can't afford lunches or books, how will you afford such innovative items as bilingual teachers, or texts, or English as a Second Language classes, or language labs? Housing, counseling, heating oil?
 The City That Works, as we like to call ourselves, does work. The American Dream, I can assure you, works. I come from a dirt street in Tijuana, after all. The eternal problem we must address, not just as a city, but as a nation, is equitable access. How do we make the dream available to as many Americans as possible?

HEADLINE: Revenge of the Cornhuskers

BYLINE: By Richard Dooling. 
Richard Dooling is a screenwriter and the author, most recently, of ''Bet Your Life.''

DATELINE: Omaha 

 BODY:

Personal Accounts
 Numbers don't lie, but they can tell different stories. America's 4.9 percent unemployment rate in August was near historic lows, for example, but last year wages for the average American worker (adjusted for inflation) fell for the first time in a decade. Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter -- the 15th quarterly increase in a row -- but median household income remains below what it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter, but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period last year, when household debt reached a record high. And so on. 
 But how, in this era of killer hurricanes and housing bubbles, are Americans actually doing? To get a more human answer to that question, the Op-Ed page asked writers in different parts of the country to provide snapshots of their local economies over the next year. Here are their initial dispatches.
 IF new construction is the cardinal symptom of municipal economic health, Omaha has to be in the pink of vigor: $2 billion in new construction in the last five years in a city of fewer than half a million souls. This includes an arena and convention center, a revitalized riverfront with a campus built by the Gallup Corporation, skyscrapers from the First National Bank and Union Pacific, and a $90 million performing arts center opening this month.
 My friend and neighbor, Curtis Christensen (also the city's public finance lawyer), tells me that Omaha pays its bills on time and that's one reason why Moody's and Standard & Poor's give our municipal bonds their top ratings. Even during the Great Depression, pay as you go was the law of the land in Nebraska: in 1932, construction of the Capitol in Lincoln came in under budget (at $9.8 million) and was paid for before it was completed. If we were a country, Go-Big-Red-State Nebraskans would invade Iraq, but only if we had the money to pay for it.
 Our bond rating, says Mr. Christensen, is but one puzzle piece; others are the public and political will to build, and, yes, generous contributions from private wealth. In these parts, private means not just nonpublic, but quiet and invisible. Just as most of the water in Nebraska runs underground in the nation's largest aquifer (the Ogallala Aquifer), most of the money in town is hidden in the accounts of investors, who follow the example of the town's alpha money man, Warren Buffett, and don't flaunt it. Mr. Buffett, who weighs in at $44 billion according to the latest list from Forbes, lives in a modest house in midtown. I don't know where the other two billionaires in town live -- Joe Ricketts of Ameritrade and Walter Scott Jr. of the construction company Peter Kiewit Sons' -- probably in very nice houses that mere dot-com millionaires would deem totally inadequate.
 Omaha also has hundreds of ''original investors.'' They or their parents ''gave a young fella named Warren Buffett a few thousand dollars back in the 70's.'' Now the few thousand dollars are worth 40 kajillion, and the ''original investors'' live down the street, in fiscal anonymity. If they feel the need to throw money around, they do it out of town, and wash their hands afterwards.
 Even our lemons often become lemonade. In 1986, Ken Lay purchased the Omaha-based Northern Natural Gas and, as part of the deal, promised to headquarter his new company here. Months later he merrily broke his promise and took what was to become Enron to Houston, and the rest is infamy. Bruce Rohde, former chief executive of Omaha's ConAgra, was in the news this summer saying what most in town believe: namely, that the Enron debacle could never have happened here, because of the city's business ethics and what can only be called its moral rectitude in fiscal matters.
 The vibrant economy has so far failed to draw crowds. You can still drive anywhere you want in 20 minutes. Many citizens privately resent the perennial attempts of the Convention and Visitors Bureau to attract more tourists with catchy slogans and marketing campaigns; if we wanted to stand in line or sit in traffic, we could spend a weekend in New York, Chicago or Los Angeles.
 Yes, the several dozen insurance companies headquartered here will have to foot their share of this year's hurricane losses. Mr. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway estimates that it may pay 3 percent to 5 percent of Hurricane Katrina's total insurance bill, or up to $3 billion. Sounds like a lot, but with $40 billion in cash reserves, the original investors appear calm in the storm's wake.

HEADLINE: Rocky Mountain Dry

BYLINE: By Pam Houston. 
Pam Houston is the author, most recently, of ''Sight Hound.''

DATELINE: Creede, Colo. 

 BODY:

Personal Accounts
 Numbers don't lie, but they can tell different stories. America's 4.9 percent unemployment rate in August was near historic lows, for example, but last year wages for the average American worker (adjusted for inflation) fell for the first time in a decade. Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter -- the 15th quarterly increase in a row -- but median household income remains below what it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter, but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period last year, when household debt reached a record high. And so on. 
 But how, in this era of killer hurricanes and housing bubbles, are Americans actually doing? To get a more human answer to that question, the Op-Ed page asked writers in different parts of the country to provide snapshots of their local economies over the next year. Here are their initial dispatches.
 HEW HALLOCK, the editor of The Valley Courier in Alamosa, Colo., comes from a long line of cattlemen who have grazed their stock near Springfield, out on the state's eastern plains. After two years of drought that forced some ranchers to send their cattle to Oklahoma and others to simply sell out, 2005 has been a good year: plenty of rain and high beef prices have allowed for at least temporary sighs of relief.
 But increased gas prices are already affecting where Hew's family can afford to run their cattle and how they market them. ''We can't sustain the current rate of growth in the San Luis Valley and still provide the water people need, and it is agriculture that will pay the price for overuse,'' he told me. ''A hundred and fifty years ago our ancestors came out to Colorado and found a new way to live, and I suppose that is what we'll have to do.''
 Seven thousand feet above sea level, Colorado's San Luis Valley is one of the largest high-desert valleys in the world. Enclosed by the Sangre de Cristo mountains to the east and the San Juans to the west, the valley is home to a community of ranchers and farmers working to preserve a lifestyle threatened by diminishing water tables and rising land and fuel costs.
 A little farther down valley, Colin and Karen Henderson own and operate El Sagrado Farm outside La Jara. On their 300 acres they grow grains, oats, barley, wheat, alfalfa and 20 kinds of certified organic vegetables. ''We are an old-fashioned diversified farm,'' Colin said. ''We are focused on sustainability, on taking care of the land.'' El Sagrado is off the grid, relying on solar, wind, bio-diesel (made from used cooking oil) and horsepower (in the form of two giant Belgians). For 17 weeks each summer the Hendersons feed 43 families as part of a community-supported agriculture farm-share program. 
 ''Farmers have always had to use their ingenuity to survive, maybe now it is just a little bit worse,'' he told me. ''We don't want to be separate in our self-sufficiency, we want to be integral; that is the true definition of community.'' 
 About 200 miles northwest of La Jara, near Montrose, Bob Hasse is raising yaks. ''It is impossible for a ranching family to survive without debt from generation to generation in commodity farming, without borrowing from the future on their land,'' Bob told me. He believes that if ranching is to survive in Colorado it will be with high-end exotics: elk, bison, American Kobe beef and (in his opinion) the far superior yak. He sells yak hides for clothing and furniture, yak skulls to local artists, and yak meat (as low in fat as elk and bison, but higher in omega-3's) to the health-conscious crowd. 
 Bob secured his own financial future by working for years in the business world, but he is concerned for his children and grandchildren: ''To get started in life without help is harder and harder. Even though we are making some money now, I can't afford to hire my kids at a rate of pay they would be interested in; hopefully in the next few years that will be possible.''
 I met Banjo Joe at a fruit stand on the side of the road in Palisade. He said it was a beautiful year for peaches; mostly, he thought, because of prayer. Joe's boss, Peter Forte of Forte Farms, had a dream that there were bees crawling all over him, and after that, Joe said, they knew it would be a bumper crop. 
 Banjo Joe, whose real name is Dan, has been picking peaches in the Grand Valley (nestled between the Book Cliffs and the Grand Mesa, the largest flat-top mountain in the world) since 1972. He identifies himself as the if-it's-broke-then-fix-it guy. Joe doesn't spend too much time thinking about his future or financial security. 
 ''Customers are blessings,'' he said, ''and I try not to let finances blind my eyes. I love peaches. I even wrote a song about them. If we freeze out early in the year I have to prune people's yards all winter just to live. Being a farmer is like going to Vegas. You either win or you have a lot of time to play the banjo.''

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
DIBNER, DAVID

 BODY:
 DIBNER--David. On Wednesday, September 28, 2005, David Dibner, accomplished businessman, philanthropist and civic leader, died unexpectedly at his home in Wilton, CT. Mr. Dibner, who was Chairman of the Dibner Fund, a family foundation, and former Chairman of the Burndy Corporation, was 78 years old. Mr. Dibner had a long and distinguished career. After serving in the navy in WWII, he trained as an engineer at Columbia University and continued with post-graduate studies at the London School of Economics. In 1968 he attended the Advanced Management Program at Harvard University. In his more than 30-year career at the Burndy Corporation, a leading multinational manufacturer of electrical and electronic connectors and tools, he rose from engineer to chairman of the board. Mr. Dibner was also an exceptional and committed civic leader. In Wilton, the community where he and his wife, Frances Kessler Dibner, resided for 53 years, he spearheaded and chaired the building of the Wilton High School, as well being chair and an active board member of the Norwalk Hospital. His involvement extended to business, academic and philanthropic sectors: he was a founding member of the American Business Conference and an active trustee of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn. He also served on the boards of Columbia University School of Engineering, the American Technion Society and was a member of the Committee for the Humanities at MIT. In addition, he was a fellow of the Aspen Institute and a member of the Council on Foundations. 
In 1989, following the death of his father, Bern Dibner, Mr. Dibner assumed responsibility for the Dibner Fund, a family philanthropy, and the Burndy Library, one of the world's outstanding collections of rare books, manuscripts, incunabula and objects in the field of the history of science and technology. Together with his wife Frances and with support of the Dibner Fund, Mr. Dibner established the Dibner Institute for the History of Science and Technology, a center for advanced study located along with the Burndy Library on the campus of MIT. In addition to the Fund's deep commitment to scholarship in the field of history of science and technology, Mr. Dibner oversaw the Fund's national and international grantmaking in science education, humanitarian aid, the environment, peaceful coexistence, Jewish heritage and culture, and local community organizations. Mr. Dibner was an avid gardener and landscaper. His hobbies included woodworking, sculpting, sailing, hiking, and travel. He deeply loved the American west for its history, art, indigenous culture and landscape. Above all else he was a loving and devoted husband to his wife of 55 years. He was a proud and loving father to his sons and daughters-in law: Brent and Relly (Wolfson) Dibner, Daniel and Victoria (Clark) Dibner, and Mark and Rachel(Zax) Dibner. He was an adored and loved by his grandchildren, Gil, Tal, Carmel, Aurora, Avalon, Bern, Sage and Skye. A memorial service will be held in the near future. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. Dibner's memory to the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, the Wilton Volunteer Ambulance Corps or a charity of personal choice.

HEADLINE: Katrina Rachets Up Local Sugar Production

BYLINE: By JEFF GROSSMAN

 BODY:
ANTHONY SINAPI didn't pay particular attention to a recent bill for sugar until asked to compare it with past ones. The price had jumped $7 per 100-pound bag, and his bakery in Hartsdale, Sinapi's, can go through two tons of it a month.
 ''Thank God you brought that to my attention,'' he said when asked about the invoice. ''I manufacture Italian ices, too. Thank God the season's over, or else I would have been hitting skyrocket prices here.'' 
Mr. Sinapi is feeling the pinch of a nationwide sugar shortage. Supplies were already scant over the summer because the federal government, which controls production levels across the country, underestimated demand for the year. Then prices took another hit when American Sugar Refining Inc., the Yonkers-based manufacturer of Domino Sugar, lost one of its largest processing plants in Hurricane Katrina. 
 ''We're not going to be able to replace all that productive capacity,'' said Donald Brainard, the company's vice president for human resources. The damaged refinery, in Chalmette, La., can turn out 900,000 tons a year. It will be brought back to that level in phases, but it remains unclear how long the repairs will take. 
 To make up for the shortfall in the meantime, production has been stepped up in Yonkers, in Baltimore, and at a plant in Crockett, Calif., that American Sugar Refining bought in August. The refining company is owned in turn by Florida Crystals Corporation, which has headquarters in West Palm Beach, and by a cooperative of Florida sugar-cane growers. ''We will be able to replace, by increasing operations at our other locations, a percentage of the Chalmette output,'' Mr. Brainard said. ''It's anybody's guess -- 20 percent, 25 percent, 30 percent -- it's certainly not going to be anywhere near the full productive output of Chalmette.'' 
 Locally, work schedules have been increased, even though the plant was already in use around the clock. Mr. Brainard estimates that the Yonkers plant can bolster production levels by 10 to 15 percent.
 Paul Rusignulo, 44, a packaging specialist who until recently lived in Louisiana, is one of a few key employees who have been temporarily relocated to Westchester. ''I'm sure I'll be doing a lot of the same work, plus whatever else I can get my hands on,'' he said. ''I like to live and learn.'' 
 All Chalmette employees, relocated or not, are being paid salary and benefits, and the company is providing emergency housing in a barge tied up alongside the refinery in Chalmette. When Mr. Rusignulo returns to Louisiana, he says, he plans to live in a trailer at the Chalmette refinery until his house in St. Bernard Parish can be demolished and rebuilt.
 Despite the pressures created by the extra workload, said Fred Gaffney, who has worked at the Domino plant since 1982, the change has been a boon for Yonkers union workers, who represent about 60 to 70 percent of the work force at the plant. 
 Mr. Gaffney, who represents the local sugar division of the International Longshoremen's Association, explained that the 205 unionized workers at the refinery went on strike from December till June. About 65 of them were laid off after the strike, he said, and their unemployment benefits expired in the last week of August. But since the hurricane, almost all of those who had not found jobs elsewhere have been rehired temporarily.
 ''I just hope the company comes around and thinks that we need to keep them here, and open up some more jobs,'' he said.
 But though Katrina has helped workers at the refinery, retailers like Bea Ebinger, owner of Bea's Cakes in Armonk, are fearing even higher prices. Ms. Ebinger says she bought enough sugar in August to carry her through several weeks, because September is traditionally a busy month. 
 ''It's like gasoline,'' she said, ''but gasoline you can only hold so much. Sugar you can. Now that it's a nice, dry, cool time of year, you can hold it in a cool dry place.'' 
 Her strategy for future purchases: ''If the price is reasonable, I'll just buy a lot more to get me through a couple of months instead of just one month.'' But she acknowledged that even a slight change in the price could have a big impact on her business. ''Whether it's butter or eggs or sugar or flour, things that you're using in large volume, it can really change your bottom line quite significantly by a few pennies on a pound, because you're using so many pounds of it,'' she said.
 The United States Department of Agriculture establishes in advance the amount of sugar each processor can sell in a year, said Ron Sterk, an assistant editor for Milling and Baking News, a Kansas City-based trade magazine. The production year runs from October through the end of September. The department's low forecast of demand this year, he said, led to national shortages despite several increases to the quota. The hurricane, which also damaged a refinery owned by the Imperial Sugar Company, only added insult to injury. 
 As for passing on the increases to the customer, Ms. Ebinger said she would wait to see where prices leveled off before she thought about that. ''There are people who are already getting burned at the gas pump,'' she said. ''Here in town, our local businesses are really trying to help the customers shop locally and save gas. I'm keeping my prices the same. I'll absorb that bit to maintain my customers.'' 
 Mr. Sinapi feels differently.
 ''Especially with the gas going up, and I do a lot of wholesale, it makes sense to raise a little bit of everything,'' he said. ''Everybody's got to take a hit. I can't take it on my own.''

HEADLINE: Bloomberg's City

BYLINE: By James Traub. 
James Traub writes often for the magazine about New York City politics.

 BODY:
On a brilliant Sunday afternoon last month, Mayor Michael Bloomberg came to Lenox Avenue in Harlem to march in the annual African-American Day Parade. As he and his supporters prepared to step out into the street, a phalanx of marchers led by Fernando Ferrer, Bloomberg's Democratic challenger in the coming mayoral election, appeared behind him. Ferrer was flanked by leading black figures, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, gadfly and provocateur. Suddenly the rivets began to pop on the mayor's smoothly machined schedule. The parade organizer bizarrely, but very insistently, demanded that Bloomberg march alongside his own challenger. The mayor, flushed, said, ''I'm here to march with my friends.'' Harlem is not friendly territory for a white Republican officeholder. Was there a racial subtext? It wasn't clear. The crowd grew denser and more turbulent, squeezing Bloomberg and his entourage to the edge of the street. ''Run, Freddy, run!'' came the cry from behind. The mayor, throttled, sidelined, stood with his arms crossed for five, six, seven minutes and said. . .nothing. He said absolutely nothing, and the incident, the nonincident, melted away. 
New Yorkers tend to recall their recent political history as a series of epic confrontations, most of them with a strong racial component. In 1986, whites in the Howard Beach neighborhood in Queens chased and beat three black men, one of whom fled into the path of an oncoming car, was struck and died; in 1991, the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn spun out of control after a black child was killed by a car driven by a Hasidic man; in 1999, police officers shot and killed Amadou Diallo, an immigrant from Guinea who made the mistake of reaching into his pocket. It would not be correct to say that there have been no such incidents since Michael Bloomberg became mayor four years ago, but it is true that none have been raised to iconic status. This mayor has achieved something that few of his predecessors would even have strived for: he is the master of the nonevent.
 Perhaps it's not surprising that a politics of anticlimax emerged from the smoking ruins of 9/11, which took place the morning of the primary elections in 2001. The zero-sum squabbling that constituted the bass line of city politics suddenly seemed inane and self-serving. Fernando Ferrer, then pursuing the Democratic nomination, toned down the racially loaded rhetoric of ''the other New York.'' And Bloomberg, a billionaire entrepreneur who until that moment had conducted an inept campaign for the Republican line, suddenly seemed appealing precisely because he stood so far outside the city's political culture. Bloomberg offered himself as a technocrat, a management consultant for an eight-million-employee corporation with terrible short-term prospects. At the time, he said to me, ''I'm not arguing that my background makes me suitable to win; I'm arguing that my background makes me suitable to govern.''
 And yet 9/11 also seemed to have transformed the meaning of ''govern'' in a way particularly unsuitable to Bloomberg. In the two months between the terrorist attacks and the election, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the incumbent, ruled over the city the way Churchill had over England in the early days of World War II. Giuliani's emotional bond with New Yorkers, his air of indomitable command, offered brittle citizens a saving sense of reassurance. Neither in Bloomberg, a cool rationalist who seemed to live inside a cushioned corporate bubble, nor in his opponent, Mark Green, who defeated Ferrer in a runoff amid ugly, business-as-usual accusations of racial foul play, did that inner flame of authority seem to burn bright. In an article headlined ''No-Fun City,'' I approvingly quoted an urban scholar to the effect that New York needed a ''Colin Powell figure.''
 Obviously, it did not get one. The new mayor had the aversion to large public gestures of a man who had previously been accountable only to bankers, lawyers and accountants. He was rhetorically disabled. Bloomberg wasn't even a New Yorker; his Boston accent rendered ''last'' as ''lahst'' and ''half'' as ''hoff.'' He had neither the ethnic authenticity of a Giuliani or an Ed Koch nor the aristocratic grace of a John Lindsay. He was a businessman in a city whose elites held the species in very low regard. And he seemed to have only the haziest idea of how to translate business principles into the act of governing. During a campaign news conference, I heard him make the odd argument that New York was losing teachers in record numbers because ''when you walk down the street and someone says, 'Who do you work for?' and you say, 'the New York Police Department' or 'the Board of Education,' people, unfortunately, don't say, 'Hey, you're doing a fantastic job.' '' That, he said, is the mayor's job.
 But it turned out that New York's case of post-traumatic stress syndrome was very short-lived. Citizens didn't want a daddy, and they didn't want Churchill; they wanted someone to fix the schools and keep the streets safe and the subways running, just the way they always did. Bloomberg was elected because he seemed more likely than his opponent to continue Giuliani's policies, as he promised he would. At the same time, his nonpartisan, managerial approach to governing offered a kind of antidote to his predecessor. Even many people who welcomed the Giuliani blunderbuss had come to find his tenure exhausting. Determined to yank big-government liberalism up by its roots, Giuliani had staged nonstop confrontations with school officials, city watchdogs, policy advocates, reporters and, of course, minority leaders. The confrontations may have been indispensable to his achievements, but they had also rubbed the city raw long before 9/11.
 As mayor, Bloomberg has confronted when he had to, describing the Board of Education, which he wished to abolish, as ''a rinky-dink candy store,'' but has otherwise practiced the arts of enlistment and inspiration. Mark Green now says of the mayor, ''I've always thought his greatest asset is that he's a non-Giuliani.'' This is a bit too dismissive; you don't build a multibillion-dollar enterprise just by handing out lollipops. But the contrast with Giuliani is unmistakable. When Bloomberg calls on reporters, he addresses them as ''Sir'' or ''Madam,'' which, while a bit starchy, is quite a change from his often belittling predecessor. And City Hall no longer feels like a moated fortress, as it once did. When I called Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, to ask about Bloomberg's record, the first thing she said was, ''We talk to his commissioners all the time.'' Giuliani so despised the organization that he once tried to strong-arm businessmen into avoiding its annual dinner.
 These are good times in New York. The real estate boom has left renovated factory buildings and brasseries in its wake and kept the city's coffers at least temporarily filled. Tourists, delighted by the safe streets, are coming in record numbers. New immigrants are finding jobs, albeit low-paid ones, and revitalizing marginal neighborhoods. Downtown Brooklyn is becoming a major nexus of business and culture. New York University and Columbia are flourishing. Unemployment has dropped to 5.1 percent from 6.8 percent over the last year. 
 But the good fortune doesn't feel as solidly founded as it did in the late 90's. Nothing does, of course; the terrorists put an end to skylarking optimism. But even New Yorkers who don't worry about the apocalypse know that you can't build an economy on real estate prices. The city's economic base is getting narrower as factories close and jobs in finance move elsewhere. What happens when the bubble bursts?
 It is, of course, a positive sign in itself that New Yorkers worry about the future rather than the present. The volatile compound of race, crime and public order, which has given a thermonuclear dimension to city politics for much of the last 40 years, is largely absent today. This is arguably Bloomberg's greatest achievement. Besides doing his best to co-opt potential troublemakers like the Rev. Al Sharpton, Bloomberg also had the good sense to appoint a very talented police commissioner, Ray Kelly, and then to leave him alone. By embracing, and improving on, the crime-fighting strategies he inherited from the Giuliani years, Kelly has reduced New York's crime rate, already far below that of other major cities, another 20 percent. And he has done so without the paramilitary style that alienated so many of the minority citizens who were themselves the chief beneficiaries of the improvements in public safety.
 Bloomberg also succeeded where his predecessor failed by persuading state legislators to grant him full control over the city's vast and refractory school system. Bloomberg has said again and again that he wants to be held ''accountable'' for the schools. And now that fourth-grade test scores have risen, he can lay claim not only to political courage but also to wise policy. Eighth-grade scores, however, remain abysmal. Moreover, Joel Klein, the mayor's education chief, imposed on the schools a progressive ''child centered'' reading curriculum, which according to a group of highly regarded reading specialists, ''puts beginning readers at risk of failure.'' (A more traditional program was later added in a small number of schools.)
 One peculiarity of Bloomberg's time in office is that he has suffered much more trenchant criticism from the right than from the left (though this is a problem any New York Republican would be happy to live with). In ''The Prince of the City,'' an admiring biography of Giuliani, the historian Fred Siegel describes Bloomberg as a ''liberal paternalist'' who has surrendered, inch by inch, the hard-won gains of the Giuliani era. The argument seems hyperbolic, for Bloomberg has faithfully pursued his predecessor's policies on such core issues as crime and welfare. Nevertheless, Bloomberg was a Democrat, and a member in good standing of the city's liberal elite, until he switched parties in order to win the 2001 nomination. And many of his instincts did not change with his party affiliation. Giuliani faced a towering deficit when he took office, and he chopped it down to size by shrinking the size of government, enraging traditional liberals and public-employee unions. Confronted with the same problem, Bloomberg borrowed funds and pushed through an 18.5 percent increase in the property tax. His supporters describe this as an act of courage, since the mayor was sticking it to middle-class homeowners who have been lightly taxed as a matter of political prudence; conservatives argue that Bloomberg was piling more dead weight on the city's already crushing tax burden. Bloomberg has described New York as a ''luxury good'' for which businesses and citizens are willing to pay a premium, a view that the city's fiscal watchdogs consider dangerously nonchalant. The city's finances may deteriorate soon: a $4.5 billion deficit is projected for the 2006 fiscal year. Bloomberg has yet to explain how he will whittle down that sum without resorting to new taxes.
 Neither, however, has his Democratic opponent. Fernando Ferrer has argued that the deficit can be substantially reduced by targeting waste, fraud and abuse -- a claim that gives financial experts pause. Though Ferrer has not quite revived the rhetoric of ''the other New York,'' he describes Bloomberg as a complacent mogul who pursued the West Side football stadium megaproject to benefit a ''wealthy developer friend'' while ordinary New Yorkers endure unemployment, poor schools and inadequate health care. Ferrer has proposed levying a special $1 billion annual tax on stock transfers for four years to raise money for the schools, a new effort to secure health insurance for half a million uninsured New Yorkers and an $8.5 billion multiyear program to build and renovate 167,000 units of housing, 30 percent of it for low- and moderate-income families. These proposals have obvious appeal in a city where so many citizens are poor and dependent on the state; at the same time, they form the kind of staggeringly ambitious agenda that gives credence to Siegel's argument that Giuliani's small-government gospel has left little trace on the city's political culture.
 And what of Bloombergism? Is there a political future in managerial competence -- or at least in a default-liberal type of managerial competence? In 2003, Bloomberg had to abandon a quixotic and solitary effort to make city elections into nonpartisan contests; New York's palate, habituated to the sugar rush of sniping and billingsgate, may be too jaded for the nutritious but flavorless brand of technocratic politics he represents. Save it for Phoenix, Gothamites might say. Or perhaps not: in a country where ideological division perpetually teeters on the brink of theological warfare, New Yorkers may come to cherish the paradoxical idea that they, of all people, have learned to practice the politics of the nonevent.

HEADLINE: Emergency Spending As a Way of Life

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IF brevity is eloquence, President Bush and Congress set a new standard of brilliance after Hurricane Katrina.
 In approving Mr. Bush's request for $51.8 billion in emergency assistance, Congress passed a three-page law with fewer than 700 words.
 Here are the details: $1.4 billion would go to the military, $400 million would go to the Army Corps of Engineers and $50 billion would go for anything else tied to what was described only as ''disaster relief.'' 
 Even in the United States, $50 billion is a lot of money to allocate with just two words. But many lawmakers now assume that the final federal bill for Katrina will shoot well past $100 billion, and that would come on top of comparable emergency spending for the continuing war in Iraq.
 The problem facing Mr. Bush and the Republican-controlled Congress is not the cost of Katrina itself. The problem is that, even before Katrina, Congress and the White House had lost their grip on the budget.
 In the last few years, huge chunks of the federal budget have been channeled through emergency supplemental bills. Part of that money was for natural disasters, but a much bigger part of it was for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and counterterrorism efforts from Uzbekistan to Africa. The budget is also packed with fiscal time bombs -- Medicare prescription benefits, tax cuts and health care costs for veterans -- that are set to explode in the next few years. 
 The good news is that the budget deficit declined in the 2005 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, to about $330 billion from $412 billion in the previous year. Tax revenue rose 15 percent, partly because of a big increase in corporate profits and partly because a major tax break for business expired last year.
 The bad news is that overall outlays keep climbing briskly, propelled by Medicare, Medicaid, farm subsidies, normal military spending and spending on the war.
 In theory, emergency spending bills are for one-time, unforeseeable calamities. In practice, Mr. Bush has financed the entire war in Iraq, as well as the war in Afghanistan, with emergency supplemental requests that totaled $248 billion over the last three years. With no sign yet of a troop reduction in Iraq, the costs are likely to exceed $80 billion in 2006.
 Emergency spending on natural disasters has shot up as well. Though no one would have budgeted for a calamity like Katrina, many budget experts have long called for a ''rainy day fund'' to cover at least some of the calamities that will occur.
 ''We don't know exactly what's going to happen, but we know something is going to happen,'' said Representative Jeb Hensarling, a Texas Republican. ''These are natural disasters, but they shouldn't be unanticipated.''
 Mr. Hensarling is one of a small group of House Republicans who have pushed their own party leaders, mostly without success, to adopt tougher controls on the budget. 
 Mr. Hensarling and other fiscal conservatives recently proposed offsetting the costs of Katrina with spending cuts. To save $30 billion, they called for a one-year postponement of the Medicare prescription drug program, which is to take full effect next year. They also called for rescinding $25 billion in lawmakers' pet projects contained in a $286 billion transportation bill passed this summer.
 But Republican leaders rejected those ideas. Mr. Bush, who declared that rebuilding the Gulf Coast would ''cost whatever it costs,'' has recycled proposals to kill about 150 programs. But those measures would save only about $9 billion.
 ''There just is no vision for limited government,'' said Representative Jeff Flake, an Arizona Republican. ''We are on track to set a very dangerous precedent that it's the federal government's role to make everyone whole after a natural disaster.''
 Mr. Flake was among the very few lawmakers who voted against the transportation bill, complaining that it was loaded with 6,500 projects that were specifically demanded by individual members of Congress.
 ''We've had very little support from the leadership on budget rules,'' Mr. Flake continued. ''We've even given away the rhetoric. We've replaced the 'Freedom to Farm' bill with the 'Farm Security Act.''' The first one cut price supports. The second one increased them.
 Mr. Bush has done little to slow the spending. He has yet to veto a single bill, including the transportation bill, which will cost $30 billion more than he initially demanded. 
 The Bluedog Coalition, a group of conservative House Democrats, called last week for a bipartisan meeting to discuss a post-Katrina budget.
 ''The response to the disaster has just been to open up the wallet and dump it out,'' said Representative Dennis Cardoza, Democrat of California and leader of the Bluedogs. 
 But Democrats insist that sacrifice has to come from tax increases as well as spending cuts. They have called for a return to ''Paygo'' rules, which existed in the 1990's and required Congress to pay for new programs and tax cuts with savings in other areas.
 Most Republicans, including the self-styled fiscal conservatives, object to any such restrictions on tax cuts. Republicans hope to extend tax cuts worth $70 billion over the next five years, even as they cut programs like Medicaid, farm subsidies and welfare payments by $35 billion.
 Permanently extending all of Mr. Bush's tax cuts from 2001 and 2003, a top Republican goal, would cost about $1.4 trillion over the next 10 years, plus interest.
 On top of that is the cost of fixing the alternative minimum tax, which was intended to prevent rich people from taking too much advantage of tax deductions. Because the alternative tax is not adjusted for inflation, it ensnares millions of additional families every year. 
 Mr. Bush had said he would deal with the problem this year through a sweeping overhaul of the tax code. But tax reform has been delayed until at least next year, and many Republican lawmakers simply want to abolish the alternative minimum tax without making up for lost revenue.
 That would cost about $30 billion just for next year and as much as $1 trillion over the next 10 years, according to estimates by the nonpartisan Joint Committee on Taxation.
 Even in the United States, that's a lot of money.
