HEADLINE: If It Looks and Feels Like a Drought, Is It?

BYLINE: By APRIL RABKIN

 BODY:
FEDERAL meteorologists have sent mixed signals as to whether the state had a drought this summer. Some areas had plenty of rain, others almost none. But Ledyard Lewis, a farmer in North Stonington, doesn't need an official ruling. He knows a drought when he feels one.
 ''You pick it up in your hand and it's just like sawdust,'' Mr. Lewis said about his corn crop. ''If this isn't a drought, I don't know what is. We went July 8 to September with no rain.''
His corn has been hit hard. The stalks have grown to a height of only 8 feet, down from a high of 12 feet, and, worse, the ears are puny. 
 Storms in the middle of last month came too late for farms in the central and eastern parts of the state. Conditions there are so bad, with rainfall just a fraction of normal, that agriculture officials in the state are planning an emergency meeting later this month to discuss the dry conditions and gather damage estimates. 
 It would then be up to Gov. M. Jodi Rell to ask the head of the United States Department of Agriculture to declare a drought disaster in the state. Such a designation would qualify farmers for federal aid, much of it in low-interest loans. Governor Rell said last month that the state would look into the dry conditions.
 ''It may seem odd to be announcing this on the first rainy day we have had in weeks, but drought conditions are a real possibility,'' Mrs. Rell said in a statement. ''The extended lack of rainfall over the past few weeks and the long-term forecast for below average rainfall has me concerned.''
 While the State Department of Agriculture said it could not estimate how much money the dry conditions have cost farmers, the farmers themselves have a good idea. Mr. Lewis wouldn't give a dollar figure, but said his income would be down 25 percent. Peter Charter, a farmer in Ellington, estimated his damages at $4,000 to $5,000. Clark Woodmansee, a farmer in Preston, estimated his crop loss at $15,000. And Ned Ellis of Hebron said he had lost between $10,000 to $20,000.
 The drought particularly hurt dairy farmers by coinciding with the thirstiest months for corn, from tasseling through ear development. Tasseling is when the strings for pollination grow at the top of the stalk. The development of the ears follows and continues until the harvest.
 Farmers use the corn to feed their cows. They chop the stalks and ears into what is called silage. Much of this year's silage will be stored and used as feed later this year and into next summer. Many farmers will buy grain from out of state and use surpluses from previous years to get through the shortage. 
 Mr. Ellis said his farm produced 17 to 18 tons of corn silage per acre this year, down from the usual 22 tons. He said the stalks grew to a decent height because rainfall was normal until July. Then the rain stopped, the stalks withered and the ears did not fill out. They have smaller diameters and many are half the normal length.
 Mr. Woodmansee said he just harvested his worst crop ever.
 ''We didn't get much second or third crop of hay,'' he said. ''Everything's just dried up.''
 The drought has also made it more difficult to get water to livestock, especially dairy cows, while they are in pasture because many wells and ponds have run dry. Mr. Lewis was hauling water in his pickup truck to 100 beef cows -- 300 gallons a trip, three trips a day. Mr. Ellis's dairy cows have been searching for water at their usual watering holes, some of which have become muddy because of the lack of rain. Several cows became stuck in the mud in August and one died. 
 ''I've never seen it this bad,'' Mr. Ellis said. ''The fertilizer fellow wasn't even recommending people put it on. For a fertilizer dealer not to recommend it, that tells you how dry it is.''
 Mansfield, in Windham County, for example, saw only 0.34 inches, compared to the average of 3.9 inches in August, said Joyce Meader, a dairy and livestock teacher with the Cooperative Extension System of the University of Connecticut. In July, it received 1.18 inches, versus the average 3.8 inches.
 In contrast, one of the wetter counties was Litchfield. It received 2.81 inches in July, compared to the average 4.9 inches, but 4.38 inches in August (average 4.74 inches), according to Janet Fisher at the Northeast Regional Climate Center at Cornell University. All of Connecticut, she said, received 4.21 inches in July and 1.92 inches in August, compared to averages of 4.19 and 4.39 inches. 
 Despite the experiences of farmers, meteorologists in most cases have not called the dry conditions a drought. Online maps of the United States Drought Monitor, which tracks drought conditions, showed that there was a drought in Connecticut for just one week in mid-September; the rest of the summer was just ''abnormally dry.''
 But Nicole Belk, a hydrologist at the National Weather Service in Taunton, Mass., said that Connecticut is indeed suffering from a drought.
 ''A large part of Connecticut is in meteorological and agricultural drought,'' she said.
 She added that in the next few months, closer-to-normal precipitation is likely to relieve the drought.
 William Simpson, a weather forecaster at the service in Taunton, said rainfall deficits may get lost in the averages. 
 ''Numbers can lie,'' Mr. Simpson said. ''We could get five inches in one day and it could all flow off, whereas a few inches spread out over weeks will percolate more.''
 John Breakell, state executive director of the Farm Service Agency of the federal agriculture department, has another explanation for the confusion about whether it is a drought.
 ''They weren't big wide storms,'' Mr. Breakell said. ''They were little cells.
 ''A tremendous downpour might dump an inch one place and not at all up the road. That's one reason why they had such a different effect across the state.''
 In New London, Marsha Jette, the county executive director with the Farm Service Agency, said lots of farmers reported cows dying in the heat.
 ''Milk production was way down,'' she said, and ''vegetables were cooking on the vine.''
 Nancy Welsh, the executive director with the Farm Service Agency for Middlesex and New Haven counties, said crop damage was exacerbated by heavy rainstorms in June that brought in diseases. ''It caused the crop to just die, no matter what they sprayed,'' she said. ''Then we went into dry conditions, so stuff they replanted just shriveled up and died.''
 For most dairy farmers, Ms. Meader said, ''It's not going to be easy.'' To make matters worse, economists predicted that the price of milk will fall, she said.
 The state has less than 200 dairy farms, with an average herd size of 113 cows. Dairy is the largest agricultural business here in terms of land use. Nursery and garden supply, the largest business in terms of income, felt the drought's impact less, Ms. Meader said.
 Many farmers also count on selling their surpluses for income. 
 Mr. Charter in Ellington said his hay yield is 30 to 40 percent less than normal. 
 ''We usually sell the surplus hay, and this year there's no surplus to sell,'' he said. 
 He said he hoped the federal government would declare his county a disaster area and send aid. But farm aid takes many months, he said.
 Two weeks ago, the fields got an inch and a half of rain, he said.
 ''But the season's over,'' he said. ''It is what it is.''

HEADLINE: Abortion Might Outgrow Its Need for Roe v. Wade

BYLINE: By JOHN LELAND

 BODY:
WITH the confirmation last week of John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice of the United States, eyes turned to President Bush's next judicial nominee, who, on a closely divided court, may determine the fate of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that recognized a woman's right to an abortion. But such speculation overlooks a paradox in the abortion wars: while combatants focus on the law, technology is already changing the future of abortion, with or without the Supreme Court. 
 Even if the court restricts or eliminates the right to an abortion, the often-raised specter of a return to back-alley abortions is not likely to be realized, said Dr. Beverly Winikoff, president of Gynuity Health Services, a nonprofit group that supports access to abortion. ''The conditions that existed before 1973 were much different than what they are in 2005,'' she said. ''We have better antibiotics now and better surgical treatments.'' 
But no change is bigger than the advent of an inexpensive drug called misoprostol, which the federal Food and Drug Administration approved for treatment of ulcers in 1988, but which has been used in millions of self-administered abortions worldwide. If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, freeing states to ban abortion, this common prescription drug, often known by the brand name Cytotec, could emerge as a cheap, relatively safe alternative to the practices that proliferated before Roe. 
 ''We won't go back to the days of coat hangers and knitting needles,'' said Dr. Jerry Edwards, an abortion provider in Little Rock, Ark. ''Rich women will fly to California; poor women will use Cytotec.'' 
 Because it was never intended for use in abortions, it has not been widely tested for safety and effectiveness.
 In 2000, researchers at three obstetrics and gynecology clinics in New York noted that low-income immigrant women were already using misoprostol as an alternative to going to an abortion clinic, because it was easier and less expensive. They got the pills from doctors, pharmacies, relatives and from contacts in other countries. 
 The drug causes the uterus to contract and, if the contractions are strong enough, to expel the embryo or fetus. In the United States, misoprostol is typically used off label with the abortion drug RU-486 in non-surgical abortions and in some surgical abortions. A spokeswoman for Pfizer, which sells misoprostol under the name Cytotec, said the company does not comment on off-label use. Last year, Americans filled 365,000 prescriptions of misoprostol for ulcers, according to IMS Health, a pharmaceutical consulting firm. 
 A dose sufficient to cause an abortion costs less than $2, said Dr. John K. Jain, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Southern California, who has performed limited clinical trials of abortions using misoprostol alone. He said he found that it was effective 80 to 90 percent of the time, if administered by a doctor. This is slightly lower than its effectiveness in combination with RU-486. 
 Misoprostol is usually used in the first trimester, but under clinical conditions, Dr. Jain and other researchers say it has been used safely and effectively in the second trimester. Women taking it on their own risk greater rates of failure and higher side effects, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and fever and chills. 
 Carrie Gordon Earll, a senior analyst of bioethics at Focus on the Family, which supports a reversal of Roe v. Wade, said the existence of new technologies like misoprostol should have no bearing on the law. 
 ''The law operates as a teacher in a moral sense,'' regardless of people's opportunity to break it, she said. ''Even if you have some people who get a drug off the black market and sell it to women, that doesn't mean we don't have a policy to discourage abortion.''
 In Brazil, where abortion is banned except in rare circumstances, misoprostol is the method of choice for up to 90 percent of all abortions, said Alessandra Chacham, a professor of sociology at the University of the State of Minas Gerais, who studies reproductive health in Brazil. In the late 1980's and early 1990's, she said, pregnant women started to spread the word, because the drug's label warned that it could cause miscarriages. Compared with illegal abortions using other methods, the rate of infection with misoprostol was 12 times lower, researchers have found. But researchers at the University of Rio de Janeiro reported that they also found that among babies born with certain birth defects, a high percentage of the mothers used misoprostol. When the government in response restricted access to misoprostol, drug smugglers created an illegal black market, Ms. Chacham said. 
 But American women may not be as receptive, said Norma McCorvey, who in 1973 was known as Jane Roe, the woman who brought the case that legalized abortion, but who has since argued for the reversal of the court's decision. 
 ''When women start using these self-induced drugs, and start seeing body parts in their potty, they're going to go bananas,'' Miss McCorvey said. ''And it's going to be horrible.''
 Dr. Jain said researchers still need to learn more about what happens when the drug doesn't work. Currently, if women fail to terminate a pregnancy using RU-486 and misoprostol, they still have a surgical abortion. But if abortion were illegal, many of these women might carry to term. ''Data suggest it causes birth defects, including facial paralysis and limb defects,'' Dr. Jain said. ''It's hard to quantify, but yes, there probably is a risk.''
 And widespread use of misoprostol could have another unintended consequence, said Mitchell Creinin, director of family planning at the University of Pittsburgh, who has run clinical trials on the drug. In Brazil, if women have problems with the drug, they go to the hospital to be treated for miscarriage. If women in the United States start using misoprostol for abortions, Dr. Creinin said, ''someone going through a miscarriage is going to be looked at suspiciously, like, 'Did you do something?''' 
 Dr. Creinin added that ''compared to when abortion was illegal before Roe, misoprostol is still safer.'' But as with any illegal drug, there is a period of elevated risk before users discover the proper dosages and protocols. If abortion became illegal, he said, ''If I were a woman, I'd rather go to Brazil than Mississippi, because at least there they've learned how to do it.''

HEADLINE: Just a Really Bad Stretch? 

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN 1927, Secretary of Commerce Herbert Hoover engineered such a spectacular government response to the Great Mississippi River Flood that he propelled himself to the presidency a year later on a platform of compassionate competence. His failure to face the disaster of the Great Depression with comparable finesse led to 20 years in the presidential wilderness for his Republican Party.
 Democrats can only dream that Republicans might suffer a similar epochal setback, based on President Bush's bad few months, sagging leadership scores and fitful first response to Hurricane Katrina. The latest polls actually show his approval rating bouncing back. But Mr. Bush, who was first elected as a compassionate conservative, whose presidency found purpose in his response to the Sept. 11 attacks and who won re-election on his strength as a wartime leader, has suffered all the same, on terms he himself set.
Successful Republicans from Fiorello H. LaGuardia to Rudolph W. Giuliani, from Dwight D. Eisenhower to Mr. Bush and his father, have long sold themselves on a combination of incorruptibility and good management. Mr. Bush likes to note that he is the first president with an M.B.A. degree, and he pledged to run a C.E.O.-style administration. So his early stumbles on Katrina have redounded with particular force. And they are being magnified by a flurry of unrelated allegations against Republican leaders in Congress. 
 ''The problem is once you set yourself up as competent, it's a very fragile reed,'' said Richard Norton Smith, executive director of the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum in Illinois and a biographer of Hoover and another Republican, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York. ''Obviously, Hoover's was disproved and Dewey never got the chance. And Jimmy Carter, too, the ferociously competent engineer that he was, came to grief. The law of unintended consequences, far more than the Constitution, is what governs the modern presidency.''
 Tectonic shifts in American politics take time -- often a long time. It took two decades of New Deal, Fair Deal, World War II and the dawn of the cold war for the Democrats to be vulnerable to Republican cries of ''Twenty years of treason!'' It took another 50 years for the party of the working man to be caricatured as the party of the windsurfer, with Roosevelt Democrats becoming Reagan ones along the way. It took more than a century for the Republicans to morph from the party of Lincoln into the party of the ''Southern strategy'' and states' rights. 
 The punditry and poll readings of any bad week, month or even year are an unreliable guide to the long-term fortunes of politicians and movements with the residual strengths -- personal, financial and institutional -- that Mr. Bush and the Republicans possess. In 1983, some prominent party voices were predicting doom for Ronald Reagan in the face of recession and high unemployment, only to see him re-elected in a landslide the following year.
 But even the invincible Mr. Reagan, never a stickler for details, was nearly undone by the Iran-contra scandal in his second term, rebounding after a thorough housecleaning and his history-making embrace of Mikhail Gorbachev. 
 Today, Mr. Bush is ensnared in a daunting war in Iraq, and by high gas prices and economic unease at home. And he is being challenged by some in his own party on the reconstruction costs of Katrina.
 Mr. Bush's troubles are amplified by those of his counterparts on Capitol Hill. The Republicans took control of Congress 11 years ago in part on the argument that Democrats had become sloppy and self-dealing after 40 years of majority rule, but they are now facing the same accusations. Indeed, last year, allies of Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader -- anticipating the campaign-finance indictment that forced him to step aside last week -- changed the rules requiring leaders to relinquish their posts while fighting criminal charges, before a public outcry made them reverse field.
 Forget Lord Acton's dictum about absolute power corrupting absolutely, said Steven F. Hayward, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. The current situation, he said, ''reminds you of that old Who lyric: 'Meet the new boss, same as the old boss.''' 
 But Mr. Hayward added that the philosophical divide between the two major parties remains real, and he speculated that the Republicans' troubles could mean a revival of the phenomenon that found its voice in 1992 with Ross Perot -- though perhaps this time from inside the party with a maverick like Senator John McCain. 
 ''There's a strain of opinion that's conservative but not ideological or partisan, that finds deficit spending and the sort of out-of-control growth of government to be a deeply troubling issue,'' he said. ''With divided government, both parties had their fingers on that, but now the Republicans control everything.'' 
 Still, the mere assertion of the House Democratic leader, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, that the Republicans were ''crumbling'' seemed unlikely to make it true. On the contrary, they and the White House are girding for a fight, and redistricting has further reduced the number of competitive House seats, cementing the Republicans' electoral advantage in the way their financial edge has held since Nixon. 
 Meantime, Congressional Democrats lack the galvanizing ideas that have driven Republicans for a decade, and they remain divided, as shown by Senate Democrats' dead-even split last week over the nomination of John G. Roberts Jr. to be chief justice.
 Former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican and onetime chairman of the ethics committee, said he believed his party's troubles were transitory. He expressed confidence that an inquiry into the sale of stock from a family-founded company by the blind trust of the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist of Tennessee, would come to naught.
 ''We don't know how any of these things will turn out,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''I don't think the party has suffered any permanent damage, but that's not to say it couldn't.''
 The National Review Online editorialized after Katrina that the administration could only redeem its missteps with a performance ''more in keeping with the G.O.P.'s image as the 'daddy party,' the party of competence that can be trusted in times of crisis.'' Mr. Bush may have begun doing that with his swift response to Hurricane Rita.
 Paul C. Light, an expert on the federal bureaucracy at New York University, said that Republicans have enjoyed a historical edge in public opinion polls on questions of which party was best able to manage the government. Although the Democrats closed the gap in the boom times of the Clinton administration, Mr. Bush opened a wide advantage again after Sept. 11, 2001, before sputtering this summer. 
 Richard P. Nathan, co-director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany and a veteran of the Nixon administration, noted that as far back as the Eisenhower era, the Republicans have presented themselves as ''the party that knows how to get the right business leaders, and manage smart, and make the government smart.''
 ''It's much easier to achieve your objectives administratively than battling them out in the Congress,'' Mr. Nathan said, ''but what you've got to do is appoint really smart, competent, savvy people who share your values. What I think is demonstrated now is not that that's a wrong idea, but it was executed all wrong by just having hack people.'' 
 ''Management is a dull business,'' he added, ''but once people have a sense that you don't have a fig of a notion about how to do it, that can be hurtful.''

 could and didn't, it's not their fault, it's not their fault.''

''You cannot read a newspaper without the gloating and the happiness with which the mainstream press is reporting the president's approval numbers."
 (Bill Marsh/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Corzine, Senate Record Shows Loyalty To the Left

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
Shortly after taking office in 2001, Senator Jon S. Corzine ruffled a few political feathers when he suggested that the ''timid progressivism'' of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, which helped send Bill Clinton to the White House, had contributed to ''paralysis on fundamental concerns such as health care, gun safety, the environment and educational opportunity.''
 ''If we begin to negotiate from the middle,'' he wrote in an article in The Nation, ''the end result inevitably takes us to the right of where I believe our nation should be.''
Now, as Mr. Corzine, a candidate for governor of New Jersey, approaches what could be his final months in the United States Senate, perhaps the most remarkable part about his five-year tenure in Washington is how faithful he has been to the liberal principles he espoused in that article.
 He has pushed for universal health care and stringent gun laws. He was one of only 23 senators to vote against the use of force in Iraq, one of 34 opposed to the ban against what critics call partial-birth abortion and one of 22 who voted to reject Judge John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice of the Supreme Court. He has also clashed with the Bush administration on tax cuts, trade and Social Security. 
 With a ranking from The National Journal as the sixth most liberal Senator in 2004, Mr. Corzine embodies a kind of nouveau New Deal belief that a government driven by populism but not averse to capitalism can still help the vulnerable and the voiceless. 
 To Republicans, his tax-and-spend reflexes make him an irrelevant extremist who lacks the fiscal discipline needed to be an effective governor. They also joke that Mr. Corzine has accomplished little, other than getting resolutions approved honoring the Nets and the Devils.
 ''I'm being somewhat facetious,'' said Douglas R. Forrester, Mr. Corzine's opponent, during a news conference this summer. ''Can Senator Corzine do anything? I don't know.''
 In terms of personal style, at least, members of both parties generally agree that Mr. Corzine is amiable and diligent. He has also reached across the political divide, on occasion, to work with conservative Republicans.
 Whether his experience in Washington proves to be relevant in Trenton remains to be seen. He would move from being a junior member of the minority party to become the top executive in a strongly Democratic state, in charge of the most powerful governor's office in the country.
 ''When you're a member of the minority, you can't get anything accomplished, so you become a firebrand, you make bold statements, you become morally outraged,'' said Ross K. Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers University. ''But that's a luxury you don't have as governor, because property taxes is not something that lends itself to ideological argument.'' 
 Mr. Corzine is a member of the Senate committees on banking, intelligence, energy and budget. Not surprisingly, Mr. Corzine, a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street investment banking and securities firm, has focused heavily on corporate ethics and consumer protection.
 When the Enron scandal exploded, Mr. Corzine was one of the few senators who grasped the intricacies of what happened. So he helped draft legislation that eventually led to the Sarbanes-Oxley package of corporate reforms.
 ''It's got the name of the two chairmen, but Corzine had a lot to do with that legislation,'' said Sen. Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland. ''He's very smart, he's very knowledgeable, and he's been a very strong defender of consumers and investors and making sure that business does things properly and ethically.''
 In 2003, he worked with Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, on the Wage Tax Cut Act, which would have reduced payroll taxes for a year to stimulate the economy. But like many bills sponsored by members of a minority party, Mr. Corzine's bill went nowhere.
 Mr. Corzine has been on the same wavelength as President Bush on measures to help end the marriage penalty and expand the child tax credit. But over all, he has agreed with Mr. Bush only half the time in the last two years, making him one of the president's leading dissenters, according to Jennifer Duffy, an analyst for The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter.
 Republicans like to trumpet the number 133 -- as in, the 133 votes that they say Mr. Corzine cast in favor of higher taxes. They also point to a recent study by the conservative National Taxpayers Union that found that Mr. Corzine proposed $441 billion in new spending in the Congressional session of 2003 and 2004, more than any other senator during the same period.
 ''He's just one of these rich guys who like to raise taxes on other people, because taxes don't mean that much to him,'' said Grover G. Norquist, president of the conservative advocacy group Americans for Tax Reform.
 And not just rich, Mr. Norquist added, but predictable. ''Corzine is a lazy liberal,'' he said. ''As far as I can tell, he's voted party line and path of least resistance, so you don't know what he thinks.''
 But Mr. Corzine's scorecard with the National Taxpayers Union, based on votes to cut spending, loosen regulations and oppose higher taxes, is actually better than those of most Democrats. In 2004, only six of the Senate's 45 Democrats received higher scores than Mr. Corzine's 19 percent mark -- meaning that Mr. Corzine was considered a little less hostile to a conservative tax philosophy than the average Democrat.
 The 133-vote figure is a bit misleading, too, because some votes were on procedural measures, and others were actually votes for Democratic proposals to cut taxes that were smaller than Republican proposals. Mr. Corzine, meanwhile, counters that he has voted 70 times for tax cuts, primarily geared toward the middle-class.
 On the issue of homeland security, Republicans criticize Mr. Corzine for being one of only 16 Senators to vote against ending a Democratic filibuster over the creation of the Department of Homeland Security, largely because of objections from organized labor to relaxed civil service rules. 
 Democrats, though, note that as part of the airline bailout package after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, Mr. Corzine worked with former Sen. Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, to give the government the right to obtain an equity interest in commercial airlines in exchange for loan guarantees. So far, the government has acquired a portfolio worth $116 million in airline stock as a result, according to Brookly McLaughlin, a spokeswoman for the Department of Treasury's Air Transportation Stabilization Board. 
 After 9/11, Mr. Corzine was one of the earliest proponents of legislation to strengthen security around chemical plants. In addition, he helped change some of the criteria used in awarding the $7 billion federal Victim Compensation Fund to 9/11 families.
 ''He was a very, very substantive guy, and I was enormously impressed with him,'' said Kenneth R. Feinberg, a Washington lawyer who was tapped by Mr. Bush to be the fund's special master. ''Whereas most of our elected officials did not want to become lightning rods by being present at meetings, Senator Corzine walked right into the lion's den and stood with the families in urging me to increase the awards.''
 Mr. Corzine took on a high-profile role as the head of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in the 2004 elections. But the Republicans gained four seats, solidifying their control of the Senate and defeating Sen. Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the former majority leader. Still, Ms. Duffy of The Cook Political Report said that Mr. Corzine had been dealt a bad Election Day hand, with the losses occurring in states that voted strongly for Mr. Bush.
 Yet Mr. Corzine has not shied away from his ideological adversaries. He recently co-sponsored legislation with Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, to set up children's savings accounts by providing newborns $500, and another $500 for low-income families.
 With Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, he shepherded legislation earlier this year through the Senate to place sanctions against those deemed responsible for the genocide in Darfur. And though that bill has not yet passed the House, the two Senators helped pass legislation that secured tens of millions of additional dollars for African Union peacekeepers.
 Mr. Corzine's own money, however, has been more problematic.
 He faces two complaints before the Senate Ethics Committee, both filed by two New Jersey lawyers and political activists. 
 One claims that Mr. Corzine violated Congressional financial disclosure rules by neglecting to report that he had given a $470,000 mortgage to the head of a major state employees union, who also happened to be his girlfriend, and later forgave the loan.
 The other centers around a vote that Mr. Corzine cast in March 2004 on a complex tax treaty between the United States and Japan. That treaty featured a tax break for a small group of investors -- Mr. Corzine being one -- who had invested in foundering banks backed by the Japanese government. Mr. Corzine said that he was unaware of the financial implications of his vote, but he appears to have saved about $5 million.
 Mr. Corzine has denied any impropriety in either of those cases.
 For all of the scrutiny of his Senate record, many political analysts say that a Governor Corzine may be less predictable than a Senator Corzine, because of the political differences between small-bore Trenton and big-picture Washington.
 ''New Jersey is a state where parochial interests can put a lot of pressure on local officials, no matter how much vision they have,'' said Jeff Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, who said he worried that Mr. Corzine's ''stellar environmental record'' might be compromised by local realities. ''That's going to be the internal and personal struggle for Corzine as governor.''


CORRECTION-DATE: October 11, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 2 about Jon S. Corzine's record in the United States Senate referred imprecisely to the benefits he received as an investor in foundering banks backed by the Japanese government, a financial dealing that is the subject of an ethics complaint against him. Mr. Corzine and his fellow investors earned $5 million as a result of their investment, according to records, but he said he received no tax breaks on top of that.
