HEADLINE: The Buckley Effect

BYLINE: By Sam Tanenhaus. 
Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, is writing a biography of William F. Buckley Jr.

 BODY:
Forty years after it was decided, the mayoral race of 1965 remains one of the most memorable elections in New York history. It was also one of the strangest, thanks in large part to the candidacy of William F. Buckley Jr. It was odd enough that Buckley, author, magazine editor, columnist, debater and gadfly -- with no experience in practical politics -- should have sought this most thankless of jobs. Odder still that his campaign style invited comparisons with Oscar Wilde, Evelyn Waugh, Noel Coward and Mort Sahl. But oddest of all was that he was taken seriously -- seriously enough to confound opponents, observers and analysts and throw the election up for grabs. Although it wasn't clear at the time, Buckley's bid for office was an important chapter in one of the crucial events in modern political history, the transformation of the consensus politics of the peak cold-war years of the 1950's and early 60's, its agenda set by liberals, into the more polarized politics of our era, ruled by conservatives. 
Today, when the right is synonymous with the Republican Party and the party itself synonymous with ideological unity and organizational punctilio, it is easy to forget that the ascendancy of ''movement conservatism'' came only after a brutal intraparty conflict, waged over the course of decades, in which (to borrow each faction's vocabulary for the other) ''leftists'' and ''me too'' Republican elders tried to fend off a mounting insurgency of ''extremists'' and ''crackpots.'' 
 The most articulate voice of that insurgency was Bill Buckley, the founding editor (in 1955, at age 29) of National Review, the New Right's flagship journal of ideas, opinion and advocacy. With its mix of authoritarian anti-Communism, free-market libertarianism and staunch opposition to civil rights legislation, National Review sowed the ideological seeds that blossomed in the 1964 presidential candidacy of Barry Goldwater, who had wrested the nomination from the G.O.P. establishment's standard-bearer, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York. It was the movement's first great triumph, but it ended in disaster. Goldwater suffered one of the most lopsided defeats of all time, leaving Republicans more divided than ever. Moderates were convinced that the party's salvation lay in a move to the center, while conservatives believed Goldwater's defeat was merely a setback on the road to eventual victory. 
 It was in this context that Buckley made his own improbable leap into elective politics. He entered the mayoral race with no sure sense of who would take him seriously. Most of Goldwater's votes had come from the Deep South and other areas that shared conservatism's longstanding enmity toward big East Coast cities. Beyond that, leaders of the right had historically defined themselves as defenders of Main Street values and heartland allegiances. How could a New York candidate stay true to those ideals and at the same time plausibly address the city's bewilderingly complex problems and its patchwork voter base? To campaign in New York as an authentic conservative required, to some extent, redefining what modern conservatism meant -- or what it might mean. At the very least, it required tuning Goldwater's message to a distinctly urban key. Buckley was confident that there were conservatives in New York. And he would be proved right. He was also confident he knew who they were. There he turned out, like so many others, to be wrong. 
 From the beginning, his 1965 campaign felt like an experiment, an improvisation. ''It was late in May, and the idea came to me very suddenly,'' Buckley, who will be 80 in November, recalled recently in an e-mail message following up a lunch conversation we had about the race. The incumbent, Robert F. Wagner Jr., a Democrat, looked unlikely to seek re-election after three exhausting and frustrating terms capped by spiraling deficits, a race riot (in the summer of 1964) and a water shortage so severe it would result in the city's being declared a national disaster area for the first time in its history. In his syndicated column, On the Right, Buckley offered some thoughts on the election and the task facing its winner. 
 ''You and I are not in fact running for mayor,'' he wrote. ''But suppose we were? What might we -- assuming, like Cincinnatus, that we were to put down our plowshares and come to the aid of the City -- suggest?'' He proceeded to list shorthand solutions to 10 urgent problems, including crime (either lock up teenage felons or make their parents legally responsible for them), drugs (legalize them for adults), welfare (cut off everyone but invalids and mothers ''looking after children 14 years or younger'') and schools (no more busing to achieve racial integration). The column was reprinted in National Review, with a front-cover teaser that read ''Buckley for Mayor,'' intended as a joke and, for the most part, received as one.
 But it was taken seriously by at least two readers: Kieran O'Doherty and J. Daniel Mahoney, brothers-in-law and co-founders of the statewide Conservative Party of New York, a three-year-old organization with only 8,700 members. Veterans of the 1964 Goldwater crusade, the pair wanted not to weaken the New York State G.O.P. as much as to steer it toward a firmer alignment with a conservative base already established in the Midwest and Sun Belt. The Conservative Party of New York sometimes endorsed Republican candidates, but more often O'Doherty and Mahoney fielded their own slates headed by little-known loyalists. The point was not to win elections. It was to advance what Buckley, a member of the Conservative Party's brain trust, called ''the root premises of the Republican philosophy of government'': anti-union, pro-business, prostates rights, pro-individualism. 
 In 1965, Buckley and his allies felt that case needed to be made more strongly than ever. L.B.J., at the peak of his strength, was turning the Beltway into what conservatives saw as a hatchery of enormous giveaways, his Great Society programs all rubber-stamped by a compliant Congress dominated by Democrats, with Republicans vying to outdo them. In the spring and summer, Congress approved two massive federal outlays: for a new program, Medicare (which included a 7 percent increase in Social Security cash benefits), and also a $1.3 billion school-aid bill. Liberals in both parties exulted in this display of consensus. But to conservatives it appeared that the two-party system was in danger.
 And nowhere was that more evident than in New York, where the mayoral campaign had yielded up an attractive new candidate, the liberal Republican John V. Lindsay, a popular Manhattan congressman who had decided to shift his ambitions from Washington to City Hall. Lindsay stood high on the conservatives' list of heretics. His voting record in Congress had earned him an 85 percent rating from the Americans for Democratic Action, which put him to the left of many Democrats. He had been among those who turned their backs on Goldwater even after Goldwater won the nomination. As a mayoral candidate, Lindsay was omitting the word Republican from much of his campaign literature and was assiduously courting the Liberal Party, whose endorsements, normally given to Democrats, had often tipped the balance in close elections.
 Buckley was further distressed that Lindsay's heterodoxy was being endorsed by Republican satraps, including Rockefeller, who reportedly dangled a $500,000 personal campaign loan, and Senator Jacob K. Javits, who would soon become co-chairman of Lindsay's campaign. The bandwagon also included Ray Bliss, the newly installed chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Richard M. Nixon, who was figuring the factional calculus as he positioned himself for the 1968 presidential election. Eventually Dwight D. Eisenhower, the last Republican president, would announce his support, too.
 The reason was electability, so often the first concern of a struggling party looking to climb back into contention. Lindsay had major vote-getting power. At age 43, 6-foot-4, athletic, Kennedy-handsome, educated at St. Paul's, where he rowed, and then Yale, he had represented Manhattan's East Side ''Silk Stocking'' district since 1959. His advocacy of progressive causes had won him many admirers. More appealing still were his eye-opening re-election margins. Even in 1964, when Republicans nationwide had absorbed a drubbing, Lindsay had retained his seat with a remarkable 71.5 percent of the vote. Now ''The District's Pride -- The Nation's Hope,'' as his campaign literature called him, stood poised to cure the party of lingering Goldwaterism. ''He was being fawned on as a meteoric presence in civilized Republican politics,'' Buckley, speaking of Lindsay, told me not long ago. ''There was talk of him as a presidential candidate.''
 Lindsay's entry into the race was a national event. He announced his candidacy in all five boroughs in a single day, sounding the call to reverse New York's ''decline and fall'' in tones of mingled idealism and pragmatism. Borrowing a page from Fiorello La Guardia, the last Republican elected mayor, he proclaimed himself a ''fusion'' candidate who could unite a broad spectrum of voters, Democrats and Republicans, sick of machine politics, of cronyism and waste, of clubhouse accommodations, of mediocre self-interest.
 Buckley, determined to stop or at least expose Lindsay, began looking for a candidate to run on the Conservative line. He knew it might lead to a Democratic victory, but he saw that as a far better outcome than for liberal Republicanism to be revalidated as a serious force in American politics. When he couldn't find a credible candidate who was interested in running, the task fell to Buckley himself. ''I helped found this party,'' Buckley would soon explain to the journalist Theodore H. White, who covered the campaign for Life magazine. ''This is my jury duty.'' Today Buckley says: ''There was a sense of opportunity. And it's just a plain fact that when I looked at it and thought, What the hell, this is kind of interesting, and reported to the executive committee of the Conservative Party, there was a sense of excitement.'' 
 The tone was set in his first news conference, held at the Overseas Press Club and attended by some 50 reporters. At 39, Buckley was well known thanks to National Review, his column (carried in almost 150 papers) and his four books (especially the hot-button sensations ''God and Man at Yale,'' a blistering attack on his alma mater, and ''McCarthy and His Enemies,'' a defense of the seemingly indefensible Red-hunter). He was also something of a figure about town, with his yachting, his Upper East Side triplex and his glamorous wife, Pat, a Vancouver heiress and onetime model. (She was present at the news conference in a wheelchair; she had broken her leg skiing in Gstaad.)
 Tall and lanky, clad in a gray wool suit and checked tie, hands plunged into his pockets, Buckley read aloud a nine-page statement in his resonant baritone. ''I am a Republican,'' he began, but ''I seek the honorable designation of the Conservative Party because the Republican designation is not, in New York, available nowadays to anyone in the mainstream of Republican opinion.'' He went on, ''Mr. Lindsay's Republican Party is a rump affair, captive in his and others' hands, no more representative of the body of Republican thought than the Democratic Party in Mississippi'' -- which was segregationist -- ''is representative of the Democratic Party nationally.'' He expanded on the remedies set forth in his column, emphasizing the need for ''a much larger police force, enjoined to lust after the apprehension of criminals even as politicians lust after the acquisition of votes.'' All this was captured by a reel-to-reel tape recorder provided by Buckley himself in the event his remarks were distorted in the press, as had happened in the past. He also had hired a court stenographer, who, after struggling to keep up with Buckley's O.E.D.-inflected vocabulary, grumbled, ''My fingers are killing me.'' 
 But the highlight was the question-and-answer period. It verged on shtick, with the reporters tossing softballs to the novice candidate. 
 Did he have any chance of winning? 
 ''No,'' Buckley said, reaching into his pocket to extract a cigar. 
 Did he really want to be mayor? 
 Buckley pondered, flashed his dazzling teeth and replied, ''I've never considered it.'' 
 Well, then, ''conservatively speaking,'' how many votes did he expect to get? 
 ''One,'' Buckley said cheerfully. 
 And who would cast that vote? 
 ''My secretary.'' 
 Wooing voters was more than he was ready for at this point, especially if it involved courting ''blocs,'' a practiced he abhorred on principle, since it elevated the group and devalued the individual. ''I will not go to Irish centers and go dancing,'' he declared. ''I will not go to Jewish centers and eat blintzes, nor will I go to Italian centers and pretend to speak Italian.'' Besides, stumping for votes was too time-consuming. He had already warned Conservative Party officials he would not disrupt his already crowded schedule. He had a magazine to edit, three columns a week to write, lectures to give -- and there was, in just a week, a sailing race to Halifax, Nova Scotia. He promised to release position papers in due time -- in the fall, once the Democratic primary had been settled -- and to deliver a speech in each of the five boroughs. He would also be available for interviews. But that would be the extent of it. 
 ''It is a melancholy reflection of our prevailing values, rather than on William F. Buckley, that he feels more responsibility for the National Review than John Lindsay feels for Congress,'' Murray Kempton, a Lindsay supporter but friend of Buckley's, remarked the next morning in his column for The World-Telegram and Sun, savoring the ''charming languors'' of a candidate who ''carried through these indignities as handsomely and containedly as any gentleman ranker offered his first introduction to the enlisted men's latrine. He also had the kidney to decline the customary humiliation of soliciting the love of the voters, and read his statement of principles in a tone for all the world that of an Edwardian resident commissioner reading aloud the 39 articles of the Anglican establishment to a conscript assemblage of Zulus.''
 It was all good fun -- too much fun, perhaps. When asked at his second news conference what he would do if elected, a stricken-looking Buckley said, ''Demand a recount.'' The line would be quoted for years to come. But it made his supporters anxious, as did the candidate's cavalier insistence that he didn't stand a chance of being elected. 
 ''I have a distinct feeling that if you were more serious about your campaigning, you could generate a lot of interest and a lot of life,'' an exasperated Barry Goldwater wrote him in July. ''Why not really tie into the whole Lindsay-Javits-Rocky situation and let's find out where our party is really headed?'' 
 Meanwhile, the New York Herald Tribune editorial page, demi-oracle of liberal Republicanism, cautioned Buckley that this was not a time for ''staging esoteric debates.'' And New Yorkers considered ''the mayoralty an office not to be trifled with.'' Of course, the debate Buckley was spoiling for was not esoteric at all; it was part of the continuing struggle for the soul of the Republican Party. Still, the election was shaping up as a momentous event, fraught with national implications, and a serious candidate needed to offer solutions to what was being referred to routinely as New York City's ''crisis'': crime, racial tension, decrepit infrastructures and disheveled public spaces. In the previous 10 years, the city's annual budget had risen 128 percent. (It was approaching $4 billion.) Business and sales taxes had doubled; real estate taxes had jumped 75 percent. Even so, the Wagner administration was borrowing prodigally to cover a $92 million deficit from 1964 and a $256 million deficit for 1965. And New York had the highest unemployment rate of any metropolis in the nation, with some 250,000 people out of work.
 The statistics translated into day-to-day dysfunctionality. Even the glittering island of Manhattan was unnaturally composed of a thin sliver of the rich, garrisoned in wealthy neighborhoods, and a massively enlarging population of the ghetto poor, with very little in between; a million middle-class New Yorkers bolted the city between 1955 and 1965, and the exodus was continuing. The year 1965 was the first in which the city's elementary schools had a greater proportion of blacks and Puerto Ricans, 50.8 percent, than whites. All races and classes had to cope with a rash of pathologies, from noise pollution and clogged streets to an alarming crime rate. In the first three months of 1965, ''serious crime'' on subways rose 41 percent. After one particularly brutal and senseless subway killing, in April, Wagner ordered night patrols on every train, with additional cops posted at each of the system's 480 stations, to combat the predations of ''the mugger, the hoodlum and the young punk.'' 
 The paradox was that this urban nightmare was happening at a time of national prosperity. The G.N.P. grew 8 percent in 1965, and unemployment nationwide stood at 4.5 percent. In Washington, the good times produced a feeling of excitement. ''The prestige of government, and government's confidence, not to say hubris, were at apogees,'' George F. Will would write 30 years later, ''higher than at any time since 1945.'' 
 At the vortex of all this self-assurance was a new cadre of policy intellectuals, employed in the various hives of the executive branch, who were armed with the latest sociological and economic theories and prided themselves on their ability to solve long-range problems. They were the Great Society's ''new priesthood,'' wrote Theodore White, licensed ''to call down the heavy artillery of government, now, on the targets they alone can see moving in the distance.''
 One member of the new priesthood was Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Labor Department official under both Kennedy and Johnson. (A New Yorker, Moynihan would soon declare his own local candidacy, for City Council president, on the Democratic ticket.) Writing in the pages of a new quarterly, The Public Interest, which made its debut in the fall of 1965, Moynihan articulated this new philosophy. ''We may now turn to issues more demanding of human ingenuity than that of how to put an end to poverty in the richest nation in the world,'' he buoyantly proclaimed. Foreign policy was one area ripe for rethinking. But why stop there? Moynihan added one more goal: ''And there is also the problem of perfecting, to the highest degree possible, the quality of our lives and of our civilization.''
 John Lindsay seemed to agree. He would soon establish no fewer than 25 task forces to propose solutions for transportation, crime, air pollution, water supply, finance and law enforcement. He assigned bank analysts to study the city's economy, management consultants to parse City Hall operations and professors of medievalism to tramp the waterfront in search of ideas for refreshing the city's public spaces. He meant to create a municipal version of the Great Society.
 But skeptics saw it all rather differently. Writing in The New York Review of Books in October 1965, Paul Goodman, author of the countercultural manifesto ''Growing Up Absurd,'' discerned the specter of Big Brotherism in L.B.J.'s grand liberal vision. It was fine when the government summoned its resources ''to prevent or remedy social and physical evils, like urban poverty, exploitation of labor, traffic congestion, air pollution,'' Goodman wrote. But this ''safeguarding function is entirely different from government trying to make life excellent, to make society moral, civilized or magnificent.'' Strip away its vaunting promises and the Great Society, in practical terms, ''multiplies professional-client and patron-client relationships'' with its ''large stable of mandarins'' employed to ''raise the tone, use correct scientific method, and invent rationalizations. Also, the literate mandarins write the speeches.''
 This critique, though it came from the left, echoed the argument that Buckley had been making, for years now, from the right and that he had incorporated into his campaign. ''Obviously the power of government is needed, for instance, to control the traffic problems in New York,'' he said in an address to a conservative group in June. ''Obviously the power of government is needed to decide such questions as what to do when the water reservoirs begin to empty. The question is whether the necessity to increase the powers of government -- yesterday there was no traffic problem, no water scarcity -- for specific purposes, has resulted in unnecessary increases in state power for general purposes.'' 
 His own literate mandarin, Buckley wrote all his speeches and all his position papers -- ''every single one,'' he told me -- at night, on weekends, in between editorial sessions, columns and travels. By the time he was done, he had covered, sometimes imaginatively, every major issue, from water (he proposed a free-market solution) to business taxes (he recommended a European-style ''value added tax''), unions (end the closed shop) and transit and traffic (bicycle lanes on major thoroughfares). At one point, he sent a letter to Walt Disney suggesting he erect a ''Disneyland East'' on the site of the World's Fair when it closed its doors in October. 
 He had help at times, not always solicited. Milton Friedman, the University of Chicago economist, volunteered that Buckley's proposal to give tax incentives to black and Puerto Rican business owners who stayed in depressed areas -- a concept that anticipated the ''enterprise zones'' of a later era -- violated the ''autarchic'' principle of economic self-determination. For the most part, however, Buckley relied on himself, with support from a small nucleus of family and friends. They included his older brother, James, a lawyer at the Buckley family's oil management company, who served, part time, as campaign manager; the public-relations wizard Marvin Liebman, who raised money and put together promotional materials; and Neal Freeman, a 25-year-old Yale graduate, National Review staff member and official of the Young Republican National Federation, who served as Buckley's aide-de-camp, shepherding him to his various appointments. ''Bill was never much interested in campaign management,'' Freeman recalled recently. ''But from Day 1 to Day Last he took very seriously the themes and rhetorical development of his message.'' 
 Throughout the summer, Buckley's quasi candidacy languidly went forward. On Aug. 30, the campaign finally opened its office in a spacious 10th-floor room at 25 West 45th Street. Visitors were taken aback by how young the staff was. O'Doherty and Mahoney were both in their 30's. The volunteers included college-age alumni of the Goldwater crusade, members of the Young Americans for Freedom (the campus organization founded on the Buckley family estate in Sharon, Conn., in 1960) and refugees from the Young Republicans. Together they resembled ''a sort of 'New Frontier' elite of the political right,'' as a Times reporter wrote. And they had no money. Marvin Liebman's original budget had a bottom line of $40,000, and though it would eventually grow to some $240,000, that was still less than one-sixth the sum that would be spent by Lindsay.
 As September began, Buckley found himself fending off charges from within the Conservative Party and from critics outside that he was taking the campaign too lightly. On Sept. 8, he sent a reassuring memo to Conservative Party officials. ''I take this campaign, its purposes, its prospects and my own involvement with it, with the utmost seriousness,'' he vowed, even as he maintained ''my principal role in political affairs, which is that of a critic and commentator.''
 A week later, Wagner's controller, Abraham D. Beame, won the Democratic primary. At 59, a mite-size 5-foot-2, Beame looked and sounded like what he was, a hardworking, detail-minded accountant whose horizons evidently ended with the spreadsheet and the culture of the Brooklyn clubhouse. He was quick to say he would not turn Gracie Mansion into a patronage dump, but he offered little in the way of ideas. His statement announcing his candidacy was 400 words long, and he read it in under five minutes. 
 Still, as a Democrat closely allied with the borough ''bosses'' Charles Buckley of the Bronx (no relation to William F.) and Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, Beame was now the front-runner. Like Lindsay, he was a Great Society liberal. The two, in fact, made roughly the same ethnic appeals (successfully to Jews and blacks, less so to Italians and Irish). In sum, as Buckley suggested in a press statement, ''the differences between Mr. Beame and Mr. Lindsay are biological, not political.'' (''That is the most sensible thing any surviving candidate for mayor has said so far in this campaign,'' Murray Kempton wrote.) Asked to elaborate, Buckley explained, in the patrician tone that would soon become catnip for stand-up comics, ''Mr. Beame is short and Mr. Lind-uh-say is tall.''
 And then came the most significant turn in the election. On Sept. 16, seven major New York newspapers were hit by a strike, all but The New York Post (then a liberal daily). The Herald Tribune was back in circulation after 11 days. But the presses remained quiet at the other papers for three weeks, and the interim proved a boon for Buckley, thanks to what he today refers to as ''that odd television thing'' -- meaning that the contest, hitherto waged largely in newspapers, most of them hostile to him, now shifted to radio and, especially, television. 
 In September and October, there were four televised debates. They were the first prolonged look many New Yorkers had of Buckley, whom they had hitherto glimpsed fleetingly on talk shows or, in many cases, simply read about. Seated alongside his competitors for an hour at a stretch, the East Coast's leading Goldwaterite scarcely seemed an exemplar of what Richard Hofstadter had recently labeled the ''paranoid style'' of conservatism. On the contrary, Buckley exuded civility and wit. Unlike Goldwater, who could seem angry and grim, a sorehead, Buckley offered comic exuberance. It came through in the gold-plated vocabulary (''Dear Bill-elect,'' a letter from his friend Norman Mailer began, ''What the hell does emunctory mean?'') and in the languid accent -- a piquant blend of British intonation and Southern drawl.
 And there was the mercilessly adroit debating style, honed over the years before many audiences. The chief victim wasn't the waxen Beame, of whom so little was expected. It was Lindsay. Effective on the stump, he was no match for the younger, quicker, looser Buckley on what Marshall McLuhan had not long before described as the ''cool'' medium of television, which dissolved the nimbus of charisma and glamour around Lindsay and exposed his bedrock earnestness and stodginess. Without a text, Lindsay was more Al Gore than Bill Clinton, dependent on creaky political-speak. (''I ask all New Yorkers to join me, to roll up their sleeves.'') While Beame and Lindsay flailed at each other, Buckley, in his role of ''critic and commentator,'' turned the contest into farce.
 In the debate on Channel 2, Beame, tired of hearing Lindsay heap the aggregate failures of the Wagner years on him, raised the well-known fact that in the run-up to the primary, Beame had been mentioned by Lindsay's advisers as a possible running mate. ''I read in the newspapers where you praised my work very highly and you were glad to have me on your ticket,'' Beame said. ''What's happened since? And that was only a few months ago.'' 
 LINDSAY: ''. . .Mr. Beame, you were never invited to be on the Lindsay ticket. And even if you were, Messrs. Buckley and Steingut and the rest of the machine boys would never let you go.''
 MODERATOR: ''Your time is up, Mr. Lindsay. Now, two minutes for Mr. Buckley.'' 
 BUCKLEY: ''Mr. Beame, I feel some sort of an obligation to history to record here that I reluctantly also came to the conclusion not to offer you a position on my slate as controller, great though my personal esteem for you is.''
 ''He is more fun to listen to than most professional comedians,'' the veteran political analyst Robert J. Donovan observed. ''And he has a way of disdaining Rep. Lindsay and Mr. Beame that has diminished both of them in the eyes of many voters.'' In the Channel 5 debate, Buckley noted dryly: ''You know, Mr. Beame keeps talking about how highly qualified he is in virtue of his very considerable political experience, and he says dreadful things about Mr. Lindsay, about how highly disqualified he is, how contemptible he is, how vicious he is, how despicable he is. And Mr. Lindsay tells us that he is highly qualified in politics and tells us that Mr. Beame is, roughly speaking, a mess. Now, if in fact long public service entitles you to make accurate judgments about each other, it would seem to me a fair inference that both of you should disappear from the public scene.''
 Buckley's comic turns served another purpose. They softened the harsher aspect of his message once he closed in on the theme that was winning him support. That theme was race. No establishment politician dared to say it, but racial tension, more than any other factor, was responsible for the ''crisis'' of the city. Crime, narcotics, substandard schools and housing, white flight, the soaring costs of social services -- all these were related to the distinct problems of New York's underclass, a million-plus blacks and 730,000 Puerto Ricans, most of them trapped in vermin-infested ghettos, where two children were bitten by rats on average each day. Products of the city's poorest schools and excluded from key labor unions, black men faced unemployment and idle days. No fewer than half a million of the urban poor were wards of an overstressed welfare system that would drain almost half a billion dollars from city coffers in 1965 alone.
 New York was coming off a year as racially fraught as any in its recent history. In July 1964, after a 15-year-old black teenager was shot in Yorkville by a police lieutenant, a weeklong riot erupted, setting off a chain of violence in cities from Rochester to Philadelphia. The issue had come to the fore in the presidential election when the archsegregationist George Wallace, the governor of Alabama, entered a string of Democratic primaries and tallied shockingly large numbers in Maryland, Indiana and Wisconsin. Playing to white anxiety over new demands from blacks for better jobs and integrated housing and education, Wallace carried every white precinct in Gary, Ind., and attracted substantial numbers of ''backlash'' votes in Milwaukee's white ethnic neighborhoods. During the general election, a Chicago columnist observed that every outbreak of black violence seemed to drive up support for Goldwater. The pundit Walter Lippmann coined the term ''Goldwater Democrats'' to describe working-class whites who crossed party lines to vote for the law-and-order candidate rather than for L.B.J, the civil rights champion. Their numbers turned out to be much smaller on Election Day than pre-election polls had indicated, but it was unclear whether this was because voters rejected the backlash argument or because Goldwater was an indecisive candidate who had run a TV ad that showed rioting blacks only to pull it amid criticism from Democrats. Buckley felt no such constraints. As he says today, ''I was able to reiterate arguments Goldwater had made without any reference to the inhibitions he had to feel.''
 And so Buckley violated the race taboo. But he did so in a novel way, drawing on a sophisticated and up-to-date set of ideas, some of them from unexpected sources, including liberal thinkers who had begun to acknowledge that even the most enlightened social policy might not solve America's age-old race problem. For instance, months before entering the mayoral contest, in a much-publicized debate at Cambridge University with James Baldwin, Buckley cited ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' a landmark study of American ethnicity written by Moynihan and the Harvard sociologist Nathan Glazer, who, in a chapter on ''the Negroes,'' cautiously proposed that blacks themselves now bore some responsibility for their disadvantages. ''The Negro middle class contributes little, in money, organization or involvement, to the solution of Negro social problems,'' they wrote. ''Conceivably, institutions organized, supported and staffed by Negroes might be much more effective than the government and private agencies that now deal with these problems.'' This formulation was not so different from the self-help argument conservatives had been making for years -- and not they alone. After Malcolm X was assassinated in February, National Review published an appreciation of him that praised the slain leader for having ''hoped for a Goldwater victory'' and for having ''called on Negroes to seek education, respect their women, show pride in themselves, work hard, save their money and start a business.'' 
 Moynihan, Glazer and Malcolm X all shared a powerful feeling of identification with the downtrodden and an acute awareness of racial injustice and its troubling legacy; Buckley, even as he appropriated their arguments, expressed no equivalent sympathy. He acknowledged the fact of racism but did not seem particularly vexed by it. He exhibited much greater zeal in his attacks on black leaders. A result was that although he did not sound like a bigot -- and indeed he was not -- he seemed to give comfort to those who were.
 A startling instance of this occurred in April, even before the campaign began. Buckley was the featured speaker at the Holy Name Society Communion Breakfast, an annual gathering of Catholic police officers, and he caused a sensation. Speaking after the famous Selma marches, led by the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., Buckley, addressing the uniformed crowd of 5,600 (about one-quarter of the entire force), accused the news media of emphasizing the brutality shown by the Alabama police and editing out their initial restraint and of playing up the story of Viola Liuzzo, a Detroit housewife who had gone south to help civil rights workers and been murdered there. ''Why, one wonders, was this a story that occupied the front pages from one end to another, if newspapers are concerned with the unusual, the unexpected?'' Buckley asked. ''Didn't the killing merely confirm precisely what everyone has been saying about the South?'' 
 The next day, The Herald Tribune reported that Buckley's remarks had been greeted with laughter and applause, and he was widely denounced by civil rights leaders and in newspaper editorials. At a news conference, Buckley played a tape recording of his speech that indicated there had been no applause in four places singled out in the report. He also lodged a libel suit against The Herald Tribune, though he withdrew it when the paper took the unusual step of opening up space on its editorial page for Buckley to respond. And he sent a copy of his remarks to Roy Wilkins, the executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., confident that Wilkins would find them harmless. He was mystified when Wilkins instead said that after reading the complete text, he felt ''even more cause for alarm.''
 Buckley's most controversial assertions, all but calculated to outrage, were on the issues of poverty and welfare. In position papers released in October, he recommended quarantining drug addicts and proposed a ''pilot program'' that would ''explore the feasibility of relocating chronic welfare cases outside the City limits.'' Instantly, he found himself fending off the charge, most tellingly from Javits in remarks he made to Jewish groups, that Buckley wanted to establish ''concentration camps'' -- a dynamite charge 20 years after the first death camps were liberated. (Javits later apologized.)
 On Oct. 7, The Herald Tribune published a poll showing Beame with 46 percent of the vote, Lindsay with 36 percent and Buckley with 10 percent, with the rest undecided. Buckley's numbers translated into as many as a quarter-million votes, an encouraging total. More important, he appeared to be cutting deeply enough into Lindsay's support to cost him the election, exactly as planned. On Oct. 10, The Daily News published the results of its World's Fair Public Opinion Poll Exhibit. Some 16,000 people were interviewed. Lindsay received 44 percent, Beame 23 and Buckley an astonishing 33. It was hardly an accurate sampling, but it made news and brought still more attention to Buckley's campaign. In a television debate that evening, Buckley the salon wit shared the stage with Buckley the tribune of the ''backlash'' vote. ''I stand for mundane and vulgar things, such as the following: I believe that it's silly to talk about law and order and the necessity therefore and do everything that you can to end the morale of the police force by coming out for a civilian review board, as both of these gentlemen have done. I believe that it's silly to talk about economy or about overcrowding unless you come out for such things as a one-year residency requirement for people before they go on the welfare roll. I believe in the principle of neighborhood schools, that education should take precedence over integration at least where education is concerned and not integration is concerned. I believe that young thugs are young thugs, irrespective of race, color or creed.'' 
 With two weeks to go, The News's first straw poll, widely considered the most reliable among New York dailies, showed Lindsay and Beame in a dead heat, at about 42 percent each, with Buckley at 16 percent, a distant but impressive third. In Queens, he got 21.5 percent (to Lindsay's 38.2 and Beame's 40.3). Even The Herald Tribune now conceded that Buckley's ''is not, after all, a frivolous candidacy; it is deadly serious.'' 
 The dandy and spoiler had touched a political nerve -- and not by accident. His vocabulary might have been ornate, but his message was plain. ''The key factor that explains the Buckley upsurge is not his personality but the fact that he is giving emotional voice to the many racial discontents among white voters,'' Samuel Lubell, the longtime poll watcher and election analyst, observed. They were New York's equivalents of the blue-collar voters attracted to Wallace in the 1964 primaries and then to Goldwater in the general election. 
 ''I can tell you that it surprised me,'' Neal Freeman recalled recently. ''I suppose that I was expecting our supporters to be National Review types -- car dealers, academic moles, literate dentists, dissenting students, whatever. As soon as we hired halls, though, we learned that [Buckley] was speaking for the people who made the city go -- corner-store owners, cops, schoolteachers, first-home owners, firemen, coping parents.'' 
 The climb up the polls was giddy -- except that Lindsay also seemed to be thriving. Buckley, it appeared, was actually stealing votes from Beame -- attracting Buckley Democrats, as it were -- a fact quickly grasped by both major candidates. In the last weeks of the campaign, Lindsay shrewdly began to play off Buckley, calling him ''an assassin from the ultraright'' and linking him with another rising celebrity on ''the radical right,'' the actor Ronald Reagan, whose prospective campaign for the governorship of California was being followed by the national media almost as closely as Buckley's race a continent away. Reagan, too, made a strong appeal to the backlash vote. He championed ''property rights'' and had shared stages with segregationists like the governor of Arkansas, Orval Faubus, whose refusal to integrate Little Rock schools had brought federal troops there in 1957. 
 With a week to go in the campaign, rumors circulated that the two insurgents had met in a ''secret hideaway,'' along with the conservative icon Clare Boothe Luce and Goldwater himself. It wasn't true, although Goldwater had offered to sign an endorsement of Buckley (''the only true Republican running for Mayor of New York''), which Buckley had declined to use for fear that a poor showing on Nov. 2 would redound against Goldwater and his movement. 
 Suddenly, the stakes really were that high. Buckley looked to be the leader of the next stage of the conservative revolt. ''He is symbolic of the new generation of Republican conservatives -- more intelligent, more sophisticated than the Goldwater generation, and in New York much more effective with the voters,'' James Reston, The Times's top political analyst, wrote from Washington. ''What happens in New York will undoubtedly have considerable effect in the Republican Party all over the country.'' If Buckley did well on Election Day, ''other conservatives in other states will undoubtedly be encouraged to put up conservative candidates, and this is bound to hurt the Republican Party all over the nation.'' 
 The usually coolheaded Walter Lippmann detected Caesarist designs. Buckley, he declared, ''is determined to wreck the party in order to rule the wreckage.'' He added, ''There is no real precedent in American politics for the kind of wrecking operation that Buckley is conducting.'' Soon Goldwaterism would be replaced by a new expression, ''Buckleyism.''
 The candidate was unruffled. ''I was 10 or 12 years into my national announcement as a spokesman for these ideas,'' Buckley told me. ''And I had defended them in all situations.'' Doing it on so big a stage ''amused me and provoked me, by which I mean that I enjoyed pressing a point which would have been thought in normal circumstances something that you couldn't mention.'' 
 Following a Vietnam protest in Manhattan in October, he distributed comments to the press saying, ''I wonder how these self-conscious boulevardiers of protest would have fared if a platoon of American soldiers who have seen gore in South Vietnam had parachuted down into their mincing ranks?'' This brought him the fiercest rebuke yet, a Times editorial that accused him of ''pandering to some of the more brutish instincts in the community, though his appeals to racism and bigotry have been artfully masked.'' In a letter, Buckley pointed out that the demonstrators had given Hanoi a free pass and that he had not said ''a single thing about the Negro problem in Harlem that hasn't been said by others whom you have not, so far as I am aware, done one of your hippopotamus-walks over. Mr. Daniel Moynihan, for instance, whose credentials are by your standards in very good order.'' 
 As the fury mounted, Buckley remained as genial and relaxed as ever. He possessed a talent, perhaps even a genius, for modulating effortlessly between his two personas, the ideological firebrand who made direct appeals to the mob alternating with the comic patrician who charmed sophisticated audiences. ''He is the first candidate for a major local office in years who is working at the top of an acute intelligence and who possesses real and not press-agented style,'' Pete Hamill of The Post observed. ''Yet he remains the leader of people who seem to understand only the emotion of contempt.'' 
 Buckley had become the focus of the campaign. His numbers pushed higher, reaching nearly 20 percent in one poll, and both his opponents were convinced that his showing would dictate the outcome. Beame, his lead all but evaporated, sent an emissary, Roy Cohn, whom Buckley had known since the early 1950's through their common friend, Joseph McCarthy. Buckley recalls: ''Roy Cohn came to me about 10 days before the election and said: 'Bill' -- he was working for Beame -- 'Beame says he's going to lose this thing. And he's going to lose it in part because he can't attack you because your followers will punish him for attacking you since they're so loyal. He wants your permission to attack you.''' Buckley granted it -- ''at that point I would above all things have wanted to defeat Lindsay,'' he says -- and Beame went on to parrot Lindsay's accusations. Buckley, as agreed, didn't fire back.
 But it was too late. On Nov. 2, Lindsay slipped through, with 45 percent of the vote to Beame's 41. It seems that Beame's attacks did damage Buckley's showing, however. He tumbled back to 13 percent, with a little more than 341,000 votes -- almost precisely the outcome he predicted in a pre-election pool with his campaign staff. It was a solid total, but only a little greater, after all, than the antitax candidate, Lawrence Gerosa, received in 1961.
 Analysts would sift through the returns for weeks trying to decide whether Buckley had actually vaulted Lindsay into office (as Beame bitterly insisted) or had cut equally into both men's totals. Buckley himself believed that he stole more of Lindsay's voters -- and that Beame had been hurt mostly by his own incompetence.
 Either way, there was no question where Buckley had run strongest. Though he failed to capture any single district, he finished second in parts of Queens and and fared especially well among Irish and German Catholics. Once again, ethnic-group interests and values -- ''who hates who,'' in the shorthand used by Kevin Phillips, author of ''The Emerging Republican Majority'' -- held true. The difference was that those aggrieved white ethnic voters now appeared to be Republicans, though whether of the Lindsay or the Buckley variety was as yet unclear.
 The answer would come in the next eight years, as what had often been called the ''ungovernable city'' lurched toward anarchy -- all the symptoms of urban dishevelment (union strife, racial unrest, mounting deficits) getting only worse, despite the best efforts of the new priesthood, and Lindsay becoming as alienating a figure as his predecessor, Wagner, and his luckless successor, Beame. The nadir came in 1977, when a citywide blackout resulted in massive looting and thousands of police officers, coming off a bitter work stoppage, failed to show up for duty. In the 1980's and 90's, helped by a strong economy, the ''crisis of the city'' finally ended, and two strong mayors, Edward I. Koch and Rudolph Giuliani, showed that municipal order could indeed be restored. Each in his way offered a gentler version of the Buckley program -- taking on unions, cracking down on crime, urging an ethic of personal responsibility.
 By this time, the struggle for the soul of the Republican Party had ended. Buckleyism -- now known as Reaganism -- prevailed. The party's liberals either were marginalized or expunged. Lindsay, as if enacting the script Buckley had written for him, switched parties, though his stab at the Democratic presidential primaries in 1972 ended almost as soon as it began.
 Most assumed that Buckley despised Lindsay personally, but this had not been the case. In fact, the two were oddly bound by their Yale connections. James Buckley had been a classmate of Lindsay's and a close friend of Lindsay's twin brother, David. There was one last meeting between the two adversaries in the 1990's, when they both attended a birthday party for John Kenneth Galbraith. Lindsay ''approached me very cordially,'' Buckley remembers. ''He had been sick. I said: 'Well, we're leaving in a week to take this boat to the Canary Islands. Why don't you come?' said I. He said, 'Well, that's an interesting idea.''' But it wasn't meant to be.
 ''The fact that it was a conceivable discussion amused me,'' Buckley says. ''I assume he was a nice guy.''

HEADLINE: Bali Bombings Kill at Least 25 In Tourist Spots

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER and JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sunday, Oct. 2 

 BODY:
A series of bomb blasts rocked popular tourist areas on the island of Bali on Saturday night, killing at least 25 people and injuring 101, the Indonesian government and a local hospital said. 
 Among the places hit were a crowded restaurant outside the Four Seasons hotel at Jimbaran beach, and a shopping square in Kuta, not far from the terrorist bombing that killed 202 people in October 2002.
 Witnesses described lifting bloodied bodies from the badly damaged Raja Bar and Restaurant in Kuta, and taking the injured to hospitals.
 Tourists who had been eating and drinking at the Raja at a peak dinner hour staggered onto the sidewalks of the Kuta Square shopping district. The front of a middle-aged man's beach shirt was drenched in blood, his forehead gashed. Another man lay on his back on a bench, his face, head and arms covered in blood. 
 At Jimbaran, a blurred amateur video caught the sounds of confusion soon after the blast, as survivors tried to escape and motorcycles and cars carried the injured to hospitals. 
 Indonesian police believed that three suicide bombers carried out the bombings at the two sites, a presidential spokesman, Dino Djalal said this morning.
 The police found a total of ''six legs and three heads but no middle bodies, and that's the strong sign of suicide bombers,'' Mr. Djalal said.
 At the beach-side restaurant in Jimbaran, near the Four Seasons hotel, two heads and two sets of legs without torsos were discovered in the debris, he said. This indicated two suicide bombers carried out the attack there, he said. At Kuta, another set of such remains was found in the shattered restaurant, Mr. Djalal said. 
 Mr. Djalal said there were no suspects yet. ''The police can only speak to what they know,'' he said. 
 But immediate suspicion fell on Jemaah Islamiyah, a radical Islamic terrorist group in Indonesia that has used suicide bombers in the past and has been behind other major attacks, including the 2002 bombings at a Bali nightclub. 
 There were conflicting reports on casualties and the number of bombs. Mr. Djalal initially said six bombs had gone off at different locations about 7 p.m. Later, the police had confirmed only three bombs. A hospital in Bali said early Sunday that 25 people had been killed and 101 seriously injured. Mr. Djalal said two of the dead were foreigners. The Australian foreign minister, Alexander Downer, said that one Australian had been killed but that he feared others could be among the dead. Diplomatic missions from other countries reported that one Japanese woman was among the dead and that five South Koreans were wounded, Agence France-Presse reported.
 Among the wounded were 49 Indonesians, 17 Australians, 6 Koreans, 3 Japanese and 2 Americans, according to officials at Sanglah Hospital near Denpasar, the capital of Bali. 
 Television reports showed chaotic scenes at a hospital as badly wounded people were wheeled into crowded corridors on gurneys, and dazed foreign tourists searched for friends. 
 One witness, I Wayan Krisna, told El Shinta radio that as he tried to drag victims from the debris at the Raja Bar, he saw dismembered bodies scattered on the floor. The first and second floors of the restaurant, a favorite hangout for foreigners, were heavily damaged, but the third floor was virtually intact. 
 President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono immediately met with counterterrorism police investigators in Jakarta who have dealt with previous attacks here, Mr. Djalal said. The government did not know who was behind Saturday's explosions, he said. ''We are going to marshal all our resources to hunt the perpetrators; the people who are going to do this are seasoned,'' Mr. Djalal said. 
 The bombs were timed in sequence much like those in the 2002 bombings by Jemaah Islamiyah and came just short of the Oct. 12 anniversary. Two suicide bombers, including one with a car bomb, were responsible for the earlier attacks. Of the 202 people killed, more than 80 were Australians. At about the same time, a smaller bomb went off outside the United States Consulate, where there were no fatalities. 
 ''The president feared something like this would be attempted around this time,'' Mr. Djalal said, referring to the anniversary.
 Initial reports Saturday night indicated that there did not appear to be a car bomb involved in the attacks. The first blasts occurred in Jimbaran, and they were followed by the blast at the Raja in Kuta. 
 Whoever was behind the bombings chose two different sides of Bali. Kuta is a reasonably priced, crowded shopping street with cheek-by-jowl shops, bars and boutiques. Jimbaran, about three miles away, is a more spacious area, with five-star hotels and new luxury condominiums, that appeals to more affluent tourists. One of the blasts in Jimbaran went off about 500 yards outside the Four Seasons hotel, said Fajar Yulinto, the duty manager of the Four Seasons in Jakarta. 
 The blasts came just as Bali had seemed to put the 2002 terror attacks behind it, and as the tourism industry, the mainstay of the economy, was steaming to recovery. 
 Tourists, particularly Australians, have been flooding back to the island, even though the Australian government has kept a travel advisory in place, warning Australians that travel there was risky. The United States and Britain also have warnings about travel to Bali.
 Although President Yudhoyono has been praised by the United States for cracking down on terrorists, American officials expressed nervousness several months ago that another major attack in Indonesia could be in the works. Much of the attention focused, however, on the capital, Jakarta, not Bali. 
 The two main bomb-makers for Jemaah Islamiyah remain at large despite the arrests of scores of members of the group. Indeed, Mr. Yudhoyono worried that Indonesia was vulnerable to further terrorism, his aides said. Two other major attacks in Jakarta, in 2003 and 2004, were attributed to Jemaah Islamiyah and carried out by suicide bombers.
 In August 2003, 12 people were killed and at least 150 injured at the JW Marriott Hotel. In September 2004, at least 9 Indonesians were killed when a suicide bomber drove up to the front gate of the Australian Embassy. 
 The attack on Bali in 2002 began when a suicide bomber set off his explosive vest inside Paddy's Club at 11:08 p.m. The explosion is believed to have killed eight people, and it also drove panicked patrons out into the street, where another bomb was waiting. That bomb, a much bigger one hidden in a van parked outside the Sari Club, was set off by a second man 29 seconds later, ripping through the crowds in the narrow street.
 The attacks did severe harm to Bali's tourism industry, which was further hurt by the scare over sudden acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, and the outbreak of the Iraq war. While tourist visits have steadily increased in the past two years, they have not reached their former levels. 
 The bombings also galvanized the Indonesian government to act against Islamic militants after years of ignoring or failing to act on warnings from the United States and other nations that terrorists were active there. Since then, the government has made hundreds of arrests of suspected militants, including people accused of plotting attacks against United States interests overseas.
 Three brothers were convicted for organizing the 2002 Bali bombings. One brother, Ali Gufron, who is known as Mukhlas, was sentenced to death in 2003 after being found guilty of having overall responsibility for the attack. His brother Amrozi was also sentenced to death. The third brother, Ali Imron, received a life sentence after cooperating with the authorities and expressing remorse.
 Prosecutors said that before that attack, Mukhlas assumed the role of operations chief of Jemaah Islamiyah. He took the commanding position from another Indonesian, Hambali, who also goes by the name Riduan Isamuddin. Hambali, who is believed to be directly involved in Al Qaeda, was captured in Thailand in August 2003 and is now in American custody.
 This past March, Jemaah Islamiyah's supreme leader, the cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, was convicted of criminal conspiracy in connection with the Bali bombings.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Several bomb explosions on the Indonesian island of Bali last night killed at least 25 people and injured scores more at sites popular with tourists. (Photo by Jason Childs/Getty Images)(pg. 4)Maps of Bali highlights the sites of the bombings yesterday and in 2002: Bombs struck again at Bali tourist sites. An attack in 2002 killed 202. (pg. 4)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Turkey's Quest to Join Europe Collides With Its Textile Dreams

BYLINE: By DAN BILEFSKY; International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: BURSA, Turkey, Sept. 30 

 BODY:
As the muezzin calls worshipers to morning prayers in this former capital of the Ottoman Empire, a small army of women in head scarves is sewing the final stitches on Adidas sweat pants and Guess T-shirts at the sprawling Biesseci factory here.
 They are the foot soldiers of Turkey's quest to get its textiles onto the runways of Milan, the shelves of London boutiques and the racks of American shopping malls.
But Bursa's aim of becoming a global textile manufacturing center is at risk. Once linked with China as part of the Silk Road in the 15th century, this city of nearly two million, across the Marmara Sea from Istanbul, now faces its greatest threat from China's low-cost textile producers and the costs associated with Turkey's drive to join the European Union. 
 As Europe and Turkey prepare for membership talks, which are scheduled to begin Monday in Luxembourg, a growing number of Turkey's textile producers are asking whether the country should distance itself from a Europe that may be intent on rejecting it.
 ''We don't need the E.U., and they don't want us anyway,'' said Bekir Celikten, the foreign trade manager at Any Tekstil, a textile firm based in Bursa that exports intricately embroidered curtains to more than 100 countries, including China. ''If we maintain our superior quality, investment will come here anyway.''
 At Biesseci, which spins cotton, dyes yarn and exports apparel to more than 50 countries, including Germany, France, Italy and the United States, Ismail Beceren, the general manager, starkly describes his problem.
 ''We can't go downmarket, because it's impossible to compete with China on price and the E.U. is bringing us extra costs,'' he said. ''We either improve quality and productivity and move upmarket, or we die.''
 Factories like Biesseci once benefited from free land, offered after Turkey's founder, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, declared Bursa to be Turkey's textile capital in 1925. He implored local residents to ''build as many factories as mosques'' to ensure Turkey's economic prowess.
 Today, such subsidies have been phased out because of the European Union's stringent state-aid rules. Meanwhile, European plans to lift quotas, by 2008, that limit Chinese textiles imported into the bloc are viewed as a ticking time bomb that threatens the industry's demise.
 The country's links with Europe have helped the Turkish economy -- but they have also pushed up wages, lifting the salary for Biesseci assembly-line workers to $675 a month, compared with $38 to $75 a month for a textile worker in China. This is reflected in the price of goods. While American and European wholesalers pay $60 for a dozen Turkish bras, Mr. Beceren said, a dozen Chinese bras cost just $2.
 To survive, dozens of Turkish firms have moved some of their production from Turkey to lower-cost countries like Bulgaria, Uzbekistan and Ukraine, as well as places in Africa. Yesim, a clothing maker that produces sweatshirts and T-shirts for companies like Gap, Nike and Zara, outsources the production of basic items to Bulgaria and Moldova. ''We have to cut costs,'' said Hayriye Torun, Yesim's export manager.
 Ms. Torun said Turkey desperately needed more global fashion brands to create buzz. She said she was unhappy that there were still no Turkish Armanis, but closer links to Europe might help.
 ''The problem is that Europeans still think of Turkey as a poor, agricultural country full of women in head scarves,'' she said. ''The image needs to catch up with the reality.''

HEADLINE: Blanket of Mold Threatens Health and Homes

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS 

 BODY:
As residents of New Orleans begin to re-enter the homes and businesses left standing after Hurricane Katrina, many may face an obstacle more pervasive and possibly more dangerous than mud and rotting wood: mold spores reproducing inside tens of thousands of buildings.
 Public health experts say mold could present significant risks and may force thousands of demolitions.
Trillions of spores, exacerbated by the sultry late-summer weather, could sicken the 20 percent of the population that has allergy problems, experts say, and could also be dangerous for older residents, children and people with weakened immune systems. 
 Further, New Orleans has large populations with high rates of asthma, particularly African-Americans and people living below the poverty line, and mold can aggravate asthma symptoms.But as the city confronts its enormous rebuilding task, removing mold has been deemed a low priority compared with repairing levees and bridges, clearing streets and figuring out how to restart the economy. 
 Officials at the state Department of Health and Hospitals, the agency primarily responsible for mold mitigation, said the department was so overwhelmed with other flood-related work that it could not inspect homes or analyze the potential health risks of mold, beyond disseminating information on its Web site.
 After the city's levees were breached, tens of thousands of commercial and residential structures were submerged. Any wall or ceiling above the flood line was at risk of attracting mold spores, which are present in the air and reproduce when there is sufficient moisture and when they have a food source -- organic materials like insulation, mattresses, wallpaper, upholstered furniture and stuffed animals. 
 Douglas A. Rice, director of the environmental quality laboratory at Colorado State University, said each square inch of mold growth could produce one million spores. While most people will not feel any ill effects of breathing a moderate number of spores, Dr. Rice said that even healthy people could come down with sinus and lung infections that could spread to the brain, and that some molds produced toxins that could cause birth defects and cancer.
 ''You are dealing with literally trillions of spores,'' he said. ''That can overwhelm even a healthy immune system.''
 But other experts disagree, and studies examining the long-term health effects of mold exposure have been inconclusive.
 Howard M. Kipen, a professor of environmental and occupational medicine at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Jersey, said scientific evidence did not bear out links between mold exposure and cancer, birth defects or even fatigue.
 ''It can make a significant percentage of the population sick,'' Professor Kipen said, referring to those with allergies. ''Mold is very nasty. But whether it causes permanent health injury is inconclusive.''
 Harold I. Zeliger, a chemical toxicologist in West Charlton, N.Y., said the mold in New Orleans -- after nearly four weeks of uninterrupted growth -- could force the widespread demolition of buildings. 
 ''Even if they could be saved structurally,'' Dr. Zeliger said, ''it probably doesn't make economic sense to do so.''
 Despite such predictions, some property owners are trying to clean up. But some of the advice being disseminated by state and federal agencies is contradictory, and most of it does not take into account the current circumstances in New Orleans.
 The federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, for instance, recommends that cleaning be completed within 48 hours but says nothing about what to do if a building was flooded nearly four weeks ago. The agency's Web site states that care should be taken not to spread spores when cleaning, and recommends blocking air vents and not using fans to dry buildings soaked by contaminated water. 
 However, the state Department of Health and Hospitals advises on its Web site, ''where possible, use fans to dry out the building,'' and does not discuss taking steps to prevent the spread of mold.
 Many of the residents who have returned have not followed the recommended precautions. Some said they could not afford special equipment and lacked insurance that would allow them to hire a professional.
 ''It's a little mold,'' said Charlie Cooke, 43, who was scrubbing the walls of his home near the Central Business District with bleach. ''I'd rather get a little sick than wait to have my place cleaned up.''
 About eight inches of water had flooded the first floor of Mr. Cooke's house; his couch was spotted with fungus, and gray and black spots of mold covered the walls, which had turned from white to yellow. 
 He wore gloves but not a mask, and was barefoot. ''You pick your poison, I suppose,'' he said.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Joan Frichter returned to her home in St. Bernard Parish, La., last week to find it infested with mold. She said she wouldn't live there again. (Photo by Richard Perry/The New York Times)
