HEADLINE: The Winner on Gasoline Alley

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

DATELINE: FORT LEE 

 BODY:
IF THERE is such a thing as a good place to run out of gasoline, the easternmost three miles of Route 46 in New Jersey would probably be it. Thirteen gas stations line this grimy stretch of four-lane divided highway just before the George Washington Bridge.
 Even during these days of wildly climbing prices, most of those 13 stations have sold a gallon of unleaded for about the same price and appear to do about the same amount of business -- except for a tidy Gulf station tucked away off the westbound lanes.
There always seem to be long lines of cars waiting for a refill at the four pumps in front of that station, Best Auto Repair, whose price for a gallon is usually seven to eight cents less than the other three stations along the westbound lanes in that three-mile stretch. 
 At noon on a recent sparkling Saturday, 10 drivers waited to refuel at Best Auto Repair, where a gallon of unleaded was priced at $2.779. There were no lines at the BP station next door, with a gallon at $2.859, or at the stations right across the highway.
 Jockeying for pump position at Best can sometimes turn into a competition. Best was the first station on this stretch during the recent run-up to drop its unleaded price below $3, and several fender-benders resulted in the lanes to the pumps.
 ''This is actually kind of slow today,'' said Sun Lee, 21, whose father, Yong Lee, franchises the gas station from Cumberland Farms.
 Forfeiting a higher profit margin in exchange for volume, Best is open 24 hours a day and sells from 350,000 to 400,000 gallons a month, making the station, the Lees said, among the top five Gulf stations on the East Coast.
 By whatever measure, the station, among the first awaiting customers leaving New York, is constantly busy. A Gulf tanker truck often stops by three times a day to refill the station's four 10,000-gallon underground tanks.
 ''They like the prices -- no, they love the prices,'' Rogelio Valencia, a Cliffside Park resident who has pumped gas at Best for two years, said of the customers.
 But the cut-rate price shown in big blue numerals in front of the station is only one of many reasons Best seems a little different from the other gas stations here. The Lees like to think they run an honest-to-goodness old-time service station.
 ''I am enjoying this job,'' Yong Lee said with a smile in broken English. ''It's my life. It is my hope.'' 
 When the lines are not too long, Best employees offer to wash windshields and check oil levels. Flowers have been placed in planters. Nineteen American flags trim the roofline. The station is well lighted. The restroom is clean. A mechanic is often on duty.
 Two signs are out front in Korean; one reads, ''Best,'' the other ''Best Auto Repair.'' The Lee family, which moved to the United States from South Korea, likes to think of the station as a place where Koreans in North Jersey can feel comfortable.
 But Koreans make up only a small percentage of the legion of repeat customers. Cliff Molder, 83, an Englewood Cliffs resident, sat in his white Oldsmobile the other day, a hundred-dollar bill in his hand, waiting for a refill. It was not his first time here.
 ''I was in the service station business for 30 years, and this is a top gas station,'' Mr. Molder said. ''I had a Mobil station. Gulf gas works good in your car, too. He runs a good business here. The prices are fair.
 ''I used to go to the Hess station across the street,'' Mr. Molder said, nodding at the station across the highway. ''I'm cheap. I tell everybody that. But look at the prices, $2.85 there, $2.77 here. It's a good business here.''
 Yong Lee, 52, has been in the gas business for only two and a half years. He moved to the United States in 1989 with his wife, Sun Ae Lee, and their only child, Sun, to make a better life. 
 While Sun Ae Lee opened a nail salon in nearby Union City, Yong Lee worked in the wholesale delivery business. A family friend ran a gas station, and Yong Lee jumped at the chance to buy the Gulf station and go into business for himself.
 Mr. Lee, who first settled in Jersey City but now lives in Ridgefield, works 14-hour days. Most of them are spent in front of the two computer screens in his office. Oil industry and public policy analysts say New Jersey is the only state to have a law in which gas prices cannot be increased more than once in a 24-hour period. The state's attorney general cited 20 gas stations for violating the law last month.
 ''Everybody is very sensitive about price,'' Mr. Lee said.
 Much of his time is spent figuring out a daily price that will keep customers coming back. Mr. Lee monitors oil prices and the prices at other stations in the area. He often looks at GasBuddy.com, a Web site in which motorists share prices.
 Mr. Lee would generally like to make 7 to 8 cents a gallon, although his son said that Best dropped its profit margin to 5 cents in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, when they, like many other gas stations, lost 30 to 40 percent of their business.
 ''The competition is ridiculous,'' his son said. ''The fact that the customer can't understand what's going on hurts. They felt like we were trying to make a profit at the worst time.''
 The Lees said they were still selling gas as cheaply as they could. It is all about volume. This is Yong Lee's first business. He said he would like to stay in it for 10 years, then help his friends and relatives establish their own businesses.
 His son has enrolled at Rutgers, where he is majoring in environmental business economics. He works at the station for his father on weekends, mostly at the pumps, where business is so brisk at times there is little time to eat lunch.
 ''Sometimes, he comes home just to go to sleep,'' Sun Lee said of his father. ''That makes me want to finish school.''

HEADLINE: A Mixed Message 

BYLINE: By PATRICK O'GILFOIL HEALY

 BODY:
HAS it finally arrived, the end of Manhattan's real estate orgy, the autumn of our discontent? After four years of record-breaking prices and consistent growth, brokers and sellers are examining the latest sales data and wondering whether they indicate a stall, a pause or an insignificant blip.
 So it's time to shake the Magic 8 Ball and ask: Is the party over?
Some signs point to yes. New market data show that the number of sales in the third quarter dropped 17.8 percent compared with the same quarter a year ago. Average prices fell some 12 percent, or about $160,000 per apartment, from July to the end of September while median prices dipped only 3 percent, or $25,000. Apartments are spending longer on the market, and inventory is building up. Sellers are cutting prices. 
 ''There is a standstill situation,'' said Jacky Teplitzky, a broker with Prudential Douglas Elliman. ''We all thought September was going to be a strong month, but that did not happen. The phones did not ring. Turnout at the open houses was low, lower than we had expected.''
 Are these just the summer doldrums, the slow exhale after a barn-burning spring? It's difficult to say. In the last 10 years, third-quarter posted gains over the second quarter five times; the other five, they showed a slump, according to data from Miller Samuel, an appraisal firm.
 Still, any dark signs may be false harbingers. If the Manhattan market is pyramid-shaped, with a few $10 million and $20 million properties at its apex, the broad base of cheaper studios and one-bedrooms seems to be as strong as ever. Average sale prices for large apartments -- four bedrooms or more -- plunged some $2 million over the last three months. Luxury inventory built up and top-shelf apartment sales, whose stratospheric prices can skew averages, dropped off sharply.
 Data from Brown Harris Stevens show the number of new listings this September was 60 percent higher than a year ago.
 Still, prices for studios and one-bedrooms leapt by 10 percent. Brokers say there has never been a stronger demand for studios.
 And over all, home prices in the city are still up 10 to 12 percent over last October.
 The Corcoran Group said that this August was its busiest ever, and brokers are expecting robust Wall Street bonuses to buoy the high end of the market. Lisa Maysonet, an Elliman broker, said she sold three-fourths of a loft conversion in Bushwick, Brooklyn, in a single weekend. Many brokers are still moving properties and insist the Manhattan market remains fundamentally strong.
 Caught in the middle of these currents are the brokers who tend empty open houses like farmers waiting for rain, the cautious buyers wary of entering a peak market and sellers who cannot fathom why no one wants to buy their once-coveted homes.
 Take the case of Randall Trombley, a portfolio manager at Bear Stearns, and his floating one-bedroom at 100 United Nations Plaza, overlooking the spires of Midtown. Mr. Trombley had lived in the 1,242-square-foot condo since April 2001 and wanted a larger apartment with another bedroom, so he listed his home for $1.33 million in August and waited for the offers to roll in.
 In the first week, buyers dangled offers of $1.2 million and $1.15 million, but never made formal bids. Others said he should lower the price by 10 percent, or praised the apartment and left without making an offer. Two weeks ago, Mr. Trombley sliced his price by $86,000, and said he may cut it further still.
 ''I'm beside myself,'' he said. ''I feel like I'm caught in the crossfire here. I have a high-floor apartment priced right around what the average has been, and we're not even getting into a negotiating stance. It's crazy. It's like, what are they waiting for?''
 They are waiting for prices to drop, said Pamela Liebman, the chief executive of the Corcoran Group. The last four years were a sellers' bacchanalia, with average prices rising 70 percent, to a peak of $1.317 million in July from $778,575 in 2001. Even as the market has tempered, sellers still expect prices of $2,000 per square foot.
 ''When you see things that have stalled, it's because of price,'' Ms. Liebman said. ''The million-dollar one-bedroom is not a fact of life. It exists, but it exists in special buildings with something that is beyond the ordinary.'' 
 A Douglas Elliman market report released last week showed that prices are starting to recede as units sit longer and longer on the market. The median apartment price citywide dipped to $750,000 from $775,000 over the last three months while the mean price -- a simple average -- fell to $1.1 million from $1.3 million.
 The bigger the apartment, the worse it fared. Two-bedrooms fell by 3 percent, three-bedrooms by 9 percent and apartments larger than that took a 35 percent price hit, according to the Elliman report.
 Jonathan J. Miller, whose appraisal firm, Miller Samuel, conducted the study, said the slow rise in mortgage rates, coupled with anxiety about gasoline prices and bubble warnings from the Federal Reserve, had compelled buyers to lock in at the low end of the market but kept richer buyers away from the high end.
 The Duke-Semans mansion, a $50 million town house on Fifth Avenue, is still on the market. A $70 million penthouse at the Pierre Hotel remains up for grabs. In the second quarter, 17 homes sold for $10 million or more; last quarter there were four such sales. ''Our interpretation was there was a pause or a pullback,'' Mr. Miller said. ''It just seems like all these external factors made everybody take a breath. We're not used to that. If we see another drop for the next couple of quarters, you may see something more negative.''
 The season's new buzzword is negotiability. The gap between what sellers ask for their apartments and what they will accept is slowly widening, said Ronald Tardanico, the sales manager for Bellmarc Realty's East Side office. In February, an average apartment in the listings represented by Mr. Tardanico's office sold for 1.68 percent higher than the asking price. Last month the average was 2.68 percent below asking price.
 Mr. Tardanico said sellers were still overestimating the worth of their apartments, such as a couple asking $100,000 more than the market would bear for a one-bedroom in NoLIta. ''Nobody's looking at it, and nobody will look at it,'' Mr. Tardanico said. ''A lot of sellers are inclined to try it at an overly optimistic number, and if they're not getting the money, they come back a bit.''
 Carmen J. Cook, a vice president at Halstead Property, said she is aiming to ignite interest in a two-bedroom in the West 50's by slashing the price from $975,000 to $899,000 -- about 8 percent. Forty blocks north, another Halstead broker, Brian Lewis, is trimming $20,000 off a $559,000 one-bedroom to sell it quickly.
 ''I'm not a pessimist,'' Mr. Lewis said. ''I just feel that the buyers that are out there from last spring are bruised. They're circling the pool and just putting their toe in.''
 The longer an apartment sits on the market, the more negotiable it becomes. Apartments now spend 133 days on the market, a month longer than they did three months or a year ago. 
 Janice Silver, a vice president at Bellmarc, said she persuaded the sellers of a two-bedroom on Madison Avenue in the East 60's to drop their asking price by $150,000 after the apartment lingered for five months with no takers.
 For brokers, the long marketing times mean they must pay more for advertising and spend more weekends at open houses and showings. Some firms are coping with the new market with seminars on how to bargain and how to sell during a slump. 
 ''Last spring it was a whirlwind,'' Ms. Silver said. ''No matter what youput on the market, it sold in a second, and you didn't even have to think. You don't see that now.''
 Except if you're trying to sell a studio or one-bedroom. The Elliman report showed studios rising an average of 13 percent this quarter and one-bedrooms by 10 percent. Combined, these sales represent 55 percent of all apartments sold in Manhattan.
 ''The demand is there, and the supply isn't going up,'' said Gregory J. Heym, an economist with Brown Harris Stevens. ''It's just been solid growth.''
 As larger apartments float out of range, average buyers naturally turn to smaller, cheaper apartments. And as that demand grows, square-foot prices for studios have risen while the higher square-foot prices for larger units decline. Brokers said that studios are also being gobbled up as homeowners combine apartments within buildings.
 Mr. Heym's numbers showed that, for the first time, studios and one-bedrooms sold for the same price per square foot, $879. The gap between two-bedrooms and studios shrunk by $17 per square foot over the past year.
 ''These new buildings, they're not building studios,'' said Richard Hamilton, a Halstead broker who specializes in Chelsea studios. ''They're ignoring a market.''
 What's likely to happen next? With the city forecasting Wall Street profits at $14.4 billion, some say big bonuses will keep the market strong. Others say new inventory will drive down prices, spur buyer interest and rekindle sales numbers.
 Others say it's simply all about value, and when the price is right, things will move.

HEADLINE: Pluses and Minuses Of Option ARM's

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A MORTGAGE known as an option ARM has become increasingly popular with borrowers. In fact, financial analysts say, this adjustable-rate mortgage may appear so attractive that borrowers may not fully understand its risks. 
 ''Option ARM's are basically a mishmash of existing products,'' said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a financial publisher in Pompton Plains, N.J.
 With the loans, Mr. Gumbinger said, the interest rate adjusts up or down in tandem with a financial index like the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor. And while rates on traditional ARM's change after a predetermined number of years, with most option ARM's the interest rate is readjusted monthly. 
 Option ARM's also allow a number of monthly payment options -- and the borrower can change the option each month. For example, Mr. Gumbinger said, the payment can be based on a fully amortizing 15- or 30-year mortgage. With those, the monthly payment includes principal and interest sufficient to pay off the loan over the specified term. 
 Another possibility, Mr. Gumbinger said, is for the borrower to make an interest-only payment. While that ensures that interest on the mortgage is paid as it accrues, it does not reduce the principal. After five years, the loan is recast and the payment recalculated to include payments against principal sufficient to ensure that the loan is fully satisfied by the end of the term. 
 The fourth and riskiest option allows the borrower to make a set minimum monthly payment based on an artificially low interest rate. For example, he said, the minimum payment may be based on an interest rate of only 1.25 percent, even though the actual interest rate is 5.5 percent. That, however, typically results in negative amortization, which means that any interest not covered by the monthly payment is added to the outstanding balance. 
 ''You end up paying more interest in the long run because you're paying interest on the interest you should have been paying all along,'' he said. He added that while option ARM's have a lifetime interest rate cap -- generally 5 or 6 percentage points above the initial rate -- there is no annual cap (other than the lifetime cap) on the interest-rate increases. ''So if interest rates rise quickly, things can get really ugly,'' he said.
 That is because a typical option ARM limits the amount the minimum monthly payment can increase from one year to the next -- usually by 7.5 percent. While that may keep the minimum payment relatively low, an increase in the actual interest rate will widen the difference between the minimum payment and the actual amount that should be paid, increasing the negative amortization. 
 In addition, said Sara Gaugl, a spokeswoman for Washington Mutual, a lender in Seattle, the minimum payment can increase beyond the 7.5 percent annual cap when the loan is recast every five years, or any time the outstanding balance exceeds the property value by 125 percent (or, under state law, by 110 percent in New York).
 Tim Malburg, president of Capstone Mortgage in Wilton, Conn., said option ARM's may make sense for some borrowers. ''The main advantage is payment flexibility,'' he said, noting that since borrowers can make any one of the allowable monthly payments each month, such a loan can benefit those whose income varies monthly. 
 But, Mr. Malburg said, another downside of such a mortgage is the potential for significant negative amortization, which could result, especially if the housing market falters, in the amount owed being more than the market value of the house. That means that if the borrower had to sell the house, he or she could not pay off the mortgage with the proceeds.

HEADLINE: With a No-Show Fish Market, Bronx Merchants Grow Grim 

BYLINE: By ALEX MINDLIN

 BODY:
When the news broke that the Fulton Fish Market was moving to Hunts Point, Vicky Ambeliotis saw her chance. ''I was doing waitress for 25 years,'' said Ms. Ambeliotis, a 42-year-old immigrant from Greece with friendly blue eyes and a blond ponytail. ''We decided to open something of our own.'' 
 Ms. Ambeliotis left her Morris Park waitressing job, and her husband, Steve, put aside his construction company. In May 2004, six months before the market's scheduled November opening, the couple built Oasis, a trim little coffee shop in a corner spot on one of the market's principal arteries, and waited for the business to roll in.
A year and a half later, they are still waiting. On a recent visit during what should have been the lunchtime rush, a single customer sat on a bar stool, and the Ambeliotises had all too much time to talk. ''We're having some tough times here, waiting,'' Ms. Ambeliotis said. 
 Since last November, the move has been postponed and rescheduled half a dozen times, often just days before the planned relocation. The two most recent delays came on Sept. 19 and last Wednesday, and both involved a continuing lawsuit over who should be unloading the fish at the new market. 
 ''I hired another girl here when they said they were going to open two weeks ago,'' Ms. Ambeliotis said Thursday. But when word of the Sept. 19 delay came, ''I had to let her go, because I couldn't afford the extra pay.''
 Like Ms. Ambeliotis, merchants across Hunts Point have been preparing energetically for the arrival of the market, only to be disappointed time and again. ''I've hired more help three times, and then had to get rid of them,'' said Joe Fratelli, the stubbly, genial owner of Fratelli's, a popular Hunts Point pizzeria. ''I take their names, tell them to come in next week when the fish market opens, and then they walk in next week and it's not open.''
 Local workers have been salivating over the arrival of the new jobs, and the reason is not hard to find. The 2000 Census estimates the Hunts Point unemployment rate at 24 percent -- the city's highest, according to a speech by Mayor Bloomberg in March. Jeremie Sautter, director of Hunts Point Works, said that of the 900 people who had come to his city-financed job placement agency since April, roughly 20 percent had been looking for fish market jobs. 
 The walk-ins at Hunts Point Works may find other jobs, but the Ambeliotises are stuck with Oasis. Ms. Ambeliotis frantically scans the news each day, hoping for word of an impending move.
 ''I'm every day with the paper,'' she said. ''I'm checking Bronx News, Channel 1, everything.'' As for her husband, he estimates that the coffee shop is making just over half the money it needs to survive. How much longer can he stay open? ''Maybe less than a month,'' he said. ALEX MINDLIN

HEADLINE: Nickels and Dimes

BYLINE: By ED MORALES. 
Ed Morales is the author of ''Living in Spanglish: The Search for Latino Identity in America.''

 BODY:
NILDA LOUISA, a 54-year-old Puerto Rican native with a perpetual smile that masks her melancholy eyes, lives with her five children, age 11 to 17, in a green and red two-family house in Clason Point, a little neighborhood in the Bronx that juts into the East River like a crooked finger.
 The family moved there two years ago after four months in a homeless shelter in the South Bronx, and although the six of them share a somewhat shabby three-bedroom apartment on the second floor of this private house, the neighborhood's relatively bucolic character has given them a sense of a fresh start.
''My daughter Evalise says, 'Mom, you know we've got a pear tree on the block?''' Ms. Louisa said the other day as she strode past the dense foliage of Pugsley Creek Park. ''The man who owns it told us he's going to give my kids some. We'll see how good they taste.'' 
 Statistics released six weeks ago by the Census Bureau showed that the Bronx, with nearly one-third of its 1.3 million residents living below the poverty line, ranked as the nation's poorest urban county. 
 A family of four is considered poor if its annual income is under $19,307; for a family of six, like Ms. Louisa's, the figure is $24,768. And many economists say the government's statistics undercount poverty in major cities like New York because the numbers are not adjusted for the cost of living. 
 Ms. Louisa's situation could be worse. The family lives in a private home rather than in public housing, and she has a job, working part time as a recruiter for an after-school tutoring program, which pays $10,400 a year. But that is her only income outside a city rent subsidy, a monthly welfare check of $140, and $433 a month in food stamps.
 Much has been said in recent years about the so-called rebirth of the Bronx, and in fact, sweeping changes have transformed many parts of the borough, particularly the long-blighted South Bronx. Perhaps most significant, unemployment has dropped in the past two years to 6.7 percent from 10.6 percent.
 But the life of the Louisa family shows that despite the well-publicized garden apartments, antiques districts and artists' lofts, poverty is still very much a fact of life for a huge number of the borough's families.
 Here is a day in the life.

Morning
 At 6 on this sultry September morning, Ms. Louisa woke up, showered, put up a pot of coffee and toasted two pieces of white bread, the kind that goes for 99 cents a loaf on special. ''It's an hour just for me,'' she said, ignoring the fact that she was already at work ironing the white shirts and black pants the children wear as school uniforms.
 By 7:15, she had awakened her brood and was making salami sandwiches for Joseph, 15, and Evalise, 14. The lunches were for a special occasion, a class trip to a local Y.
 By 8 a.m., Ms. Louisa was exhorting her children in a stern yet loving manner that by now has become a comforting ritual. ''We've got to go to school, we've got to go to school,'' she intoned. Marylynne, at 17 the eldest, left first, for G.E.D. classes at Friends of Island Academy; the academy is a kind of prep school for youthful offenders like Marylynne, who is on probation in connection with charges springing from a street robbery. The other children clambered down the stairs with their mother. 
 A few blocks from the apartment, Ms. Louisa pointed to a cluster of modest beige and brown town houses. Because a new owner has bought the house where she lives and wants Ms. Louisa out by the end of this month, she has been looking for a new place. But the search is arduous; the city housing program that subsidizes her $1,300-a-month rent won't contribute more than the $1,178 it does now. 
 ''I have no money for these kids,'' she said, with the exasperated frankness that seemed to define motherhood. ''Sure, I have this little job, a chance for me to feel good about myself. But what's going to happen October 31st? Do they wind up in a shelter again?''
 Intermediate School 174, which four of her children attend and where Ms. Louisa works as a volunteer, is around the corner from the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club, where Jennifer Lopez learned to sing and dance in the 1980's. After depositing her children, Ms. Louisa met up with Lisa Liverpool, president of the school's parent-teacher association, and the two women walked the five blocks to Intermediate School 131 to report for work as recruiters for TestQuest, a tutoring program. ''We're a team,'' Ms. Louisa said. ''I take the Spanish-speaking people aside, and when I'm done with my pitch, I send them to her to get the application.''
 Ms. Liverpool has been working with Ms. Louisa for only a few weeks, but she has already grown deeply attached to her. She is still miffed that Ms. Louisa passed up attending the graduation ceremony at the Global Business Institute, where she recently completed a computer course, because she couldn't afford the $25 for a cap and gown. 
 ''I wish she'd told me,'' Ms. Liverpool said. ''It hurts when I know she's struggling. I tell her, don't let the kids know, but the kids see it. People assume, just because the kids are dressed nice, that she's O.K. But she's not.''
 When the two women arrived at I.S. 131, their supervisor, Ideliza Duarte, whisked them to Middle School 80 in the West Bronx, where she was short on Spanish-speaking recruiters. As a sparse crowd listened to Ms. Duarte's presentation, Ms. Louisa explained why she liked this sort of work. 
 ''I was a founder of the Parent Action Committee at the New Settlement Apartments, where I used to live,'' she said. ''I don't have a college degree, I have a mother degree. My education is the kids.
 ''It's nice to help people, to talk to people, to be friendly with people. Because even though I'm poor, with my dungarees and my sneakers and my five kids, I deserve the same respect.''

Afternoon
 Around noon, Ms. Louisa returned to I.S. 174 to spend time volunteering before she returned to her official job. When she walked in, she heard some unfortunate news from David Kilgannon, the special ed teacher for her 13-year-old son, Michael. ''I had to give him detention this afternoon,'' he said. ''He just gets caught up with other kids. One kid will go off, and the other kids think they have permission to carry on. What's frustrating is he sees beyond the surface -- he has so much depth.''
 Ms. Louisa was unfazed, confident that Michael would eventually work things out on his own, and eagerly dug into a lunch of three pieces of fried chicken and soda, the $3.95 special at Mama's Fried Chicken, the fast-food place across the street. ''If I could,'' she said, ''I'd get our computer fixed so my kids could do their homework. I went to Fordham Road, and they told me it would run around $90.'' Evalise and Joseph are graduating from intermediate school this year, and they need $60 each for the senior trip, $19 for senior pictures and $35 for senior rings.
 ''I can't remember the last time we've been out to dinner as a family,'' Ms. Louisa said. ''And I haven't been to the beauty parlor for the longest time.
 ''When I was young,'' she continued, her mind drifting back to her early years in New York, ''I worked at Lord & Taylor as a stock girl. I used to like that because I could never afford those things. Those gloves they had, $60, $100, $300. I find that so exciting. To see how the other half lives, O.K.?'' 
 Down the hallway, Ms. Louisa ran into Diana Owens, the school's parent coordinator and someone she seems to love as much as she loves her children. Ms. Owens helped her get the job at TestQuest, takes her shopping for clothes and, in a monthly ritual, helps her work out a budget for her family's food expenses. ''When I get my food stamps at the beginning of the month,'' Ms. Louisa said, ''she tries to budget them enough so that by the 20th we'll still have money for food left.''
 Typically, Ms. Louisa buys a family pack of beef for $35, which will be used to make six dinners, along with two bags of chicken legs for $11 each, yielding eight meals, and a five-pound bag of ground meat for $11, good for three meals. A 20-pound bag of rice goes for $3.98, beans are 57 cents a 15-ounce can, and to wash it down, Ms. Louisa stocks her fridge with soda, at $1 for a two-liter container, and powdered iced tea, at $4.98 for a can that makes 20 quarts.
 Once a month, Ms. Owens picks up Ms. Louisa and the two of them take a drive along Bruckner Boulevard, just the two of them, no children. Ms. Owens thinks it's the least she can do in return for Ms. Louisa's volunteer work.
 ''Whenever I find myself in a difficult situation -- I have one kid, and sometimes it's too much for me -- I think of her,'' Ms. Owens said. ''She's such an inspiration, with what she faces, and she'll come here chugging along like the little train that could, always smiling.
 She added: ''She'll do what most parents won't do, like volunteer in the cafeteria for three periods. It's loud, crazy and hot, and she does it every single day.''
 After lunch, Ms. Louisa headed to the post office to see if a $40 check from her mother, who has moved back to Puerto Rico, had arrived. She hoped to use the money for Joseph's and Evalise's graduation dues or just to buy more food. The postal worker explained that the priority mail was out with the driver, and told Ms. Louisa to come back the next day. 
 Around 2, Ms. Louisa headed back to I.S. 131 for more outdoor recruiting with Ms. Liverpool. Several parents stopped and listened as she made her pitch in English, Spanish and Spanglish. When one woman asked to apply, Ms. Louisa was clearly elated; for each person who signs up, she gets a $5 bonus. 
 On the way home from work, she passed the Church of God, the Pentecostal church on Lacombe Avenue that she attends every Sunday and some weekday afternoons. ''I get a lot from the faith I have in God,'' she said. ''When I'm not volunteering, my free time is 11:30 to 2, so I go to church.
 ''Sometimes I have no money for the kids, and all of a sudden somebody calls me up and says, 'I have $20 for you.''' Ms. Louisa was referring to Andrea Case, the parent organizer supervisor from New Settlement Apartments. ''She bought the kids school supplies this year -- notebooks, pencils. She never tells me how much it cost her.'' 
 Before going home to meet Evalise, who would be cooking dinner that night, Ms. Louisa stopped at the Fine Fare supermarket on Castle Hill Avenue and bought two 10-packs of Capri Sun strawberry kiwi drinks ($5), four one-liter bottles of Pepsi ($5) and two bottles of Goya Cola Champagne ($1.98).
 ''The last time I went food shopping was two weeks ago,'' she said. ''But we still have a lot of food left. Hopefully I'll get my mother's check tomorrow.''

Evening
 Soon after Ms. Louisa arrived home, her children began filtering in from school, and Evalise had commandeered the kitchen and was making fried chicken cutlets.
 Evalise's tall, lithe frame prompts her mother to say she could be a model, although Evalise insists she wants to be a cop. This day, Evalise was sharply dressed in clothes she had bought from her $5.5o-an-hour earnings as a summer lifeguard at the Y on the Grand Concourse, a $25 Baby Phat skirt from a local store called Pretty Girl and a $3 white shirt.
 ''I would really like a pair of Jordans or Timberlands, or one of those suits that Rocawear came out with,'' she said as she tossed bread crumbs into the frying pan. ''But I don't like to ask if I know I can't get it.''
 After dinner, as her children milled around the living room, Ms. Louisa talked a little about her life before Clason Point. She has had two partners, both of whom, she said, were physically abusive. Three years ago, when her second partner moved to Virginia, Ms. Louisa briefly moved her family to Tampa, but the move didn't work out, and she returned to New York with few prospects. 
 The family's time in a homeless center was especially painful. 
 ''They stole Joey's baseball glove and bat; the kids had nothing to eat,'' Ms. Louisa said. ''They've been through a lot. But Evalise can sing, Marylynne is going to take her G.E.D., Joey wants to play baseball, Michael wants to be a comedian. 
 ''I want them to be what I'm not, so I'm trying to give them every chance in life, but they're snotty.'' Everyone laughed.
 ''I don't think we're snotty,'' Marylynne interjected. ''We're just, you know, angry.''
 ''She feels angry because she doesn't have a nice bedroom set,'' Ms. Louisa said, ''and I can't buy her clothes.'' 
 ''We should be all right; Mom's got a job,'' Evalise chimed in.
 ''But the job only pays $10 an hour,'' Michael pointed out.
 ''And as soon as the welfare finds out I'm working, they'll lower my rent assistance and the food stamps, so I lose anyway,'' Ms. Louisa added. ''It's a hard life.''
 Reverberating down the hall from the girls' room, a Jay-Z song caterwauled its way to the living room. ''It's a hard knock life,'' Evalise sang along, perfectly imitating the high-pitched chorus of children's voices.
 In an age when so many young people seem diffident if not outright alienated, the Louisa clan seems remarkable in the way its members share a single lively space. The living room walls, covered almost entirely with portraits of the children at various ages, capture a thriving togetherness.
 Children raced in and out of the house as hip-hop blared through damaged and taped-up doors. Later, they played Xbox video games: baseball, basketball, Spider-Man, Superman. Michael lamented the fact that his mother could not get him a Rottweiler from a local animal shelter because it would have required a $150 donation. Jasmine, 11, industriously cut out a story from The Daily News with the headline ''Mob Picked Dock Union Boss, Rat Says'' for her current events class. 
 In the kitchen, their mother hand-washed their shirts and pants for the next day while plotting the tasks that lay ahead. ''I'm behind on both the Con Ed bill and the cable and phone,'' Ms. Louisa said. ''I'm going to have to call them tomorrow to make sure they don't cut it off.''
 By 11 p.m., all the children had showered, brushed their teeth and been marched off to bed. ''Kiss them, are you kidding?'' their mother said. ''It's more like I'm fighting with them to go to sleep.''
 And then?
 ''Sometimes I sit and watch TV until 12 o'clock by myself,'' she said. ''I don't have a life; my life is the kids. Or I'll pick up the Bible and read Psalm 23, about the shepherd, and walking through the darkness. Me siento a llorar a veces. I sit and cry sometimes. Oh, my God, por que no me escuchas? Why don't you listen to me? My kids think I'm going mental. And then sometimes I say, God, thank you for listening to me, because at least I have food for today.''

HEADLINE: Great Expectations

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS

 BODY:
Lauren Brody, a senior editor at Glamour, was looking forward to her 10th high school reunion. She couldn't wait to go back down South and walk into a room full of great-looking overachievers from her prestigious private school, feeling better about herself than she had as a student. She was married and making it big in Manhattan. 
 ''I'm just happy about where I am now,'' she said before going. ''Everything in my life turned out better than I had expected.'' 
Except of course for the reunion. That didn't work out at all. 
 Arriving in a sparkly top and four-inch heels, she immediately felt overdressed. It got worse when she realized that many of the ''stars'' of her class weren't even there. 
 ''I guess they had better things to do,'' she said. ''So I ended up feeling like a loser for going and caring so much. And then I felt silly for thinking I had something to prove.''
 Well, in a culture in which validation is all -- from peer reviews to ''American Idol'' -- reunions are harder to take than ever. And after all, this is the culture of the reunion. 
 What else to expect when a population of narcissistic navel gazers gets egged on by businesses like Classmates.com and Reunions.com? Is any nation more obsessed with high school? Many psychologists believe that it all goes back to high school, where your place in the social order emerges. In ''The Rise and Fall of the American Teenager'' Thomas Hine writes, ''Figuring out where they fit in -- to the universe, the economy, their social circle, their family -- is a project on which teenagers spend a lot of their time and energy.''
 No wonder the film ''Romy and Michele's High School Reunion'' is a cult favorite. Lisa Kudrow and Mira Sorvino play best friends who attend their 10th reunion planning to validate themselves in the eyes of their former classmates by pretending they are rich, successful and in love when they aren't.
 ''So all we need are, like, better jobs and boyfriends, right?'' one asks.
 Actually, all they need is some self-worth.
 ''If you continually need validation externally,'' said Martha Straus, a clinical psychologist from Putney, Vt., ''it's like your bucket has a leak. Validation never really holds when it comes from the outside.'' 
 I should have been on her couch before attending my 20th high school reunion. Feeling superior, I showed up in a too-stylish blazer wanting classmates from my parochial Long Island suburb to care that I had a sophisticated Manhattan life. 
 Naturally, I left feeling sorely invalidated.
 But not as invalidated as Tori von Studnitz, who had always felt good about her high school years in Los Angeles. Then, at her 20th reunion, she and a friend gave an impromptu after-party and waited for hours for the ''cute guys'' and ''cool people.'' 
 ''But the only guy to show up was the one nobody liked,'' she said. 
 Yes, because it's only the people you can't get validation from (like your parents and ''cool'' classmates) that you need it from, right? It makes me wonder if the happiest people are the ones who actually don't need much of anything from high school reunions. 
 ''I just enjoy saying hello and seeing people who didn't age well,'' said Ira, my spouse, ''and then that's enough. I go home.'' Last weekend we attended his 25th reunion for the Bronx High School of Science.
 As I watched him work the room in a paisley Prada jacket, getting compliments for still being the best dressed and most worldly guy in his class, I realized that he required absolutely no validation from his high school classmates. Is that why he is so confident today? Or is it that he didn't care quite so much about high school even when he was in it, because he had so much else going on upon the larger stage of Manhattan? 
 Maybe what reunions really have to offer is perspective, not validation. 
 Certainly, that's what Ms. Brody got from hers when it was over. 
 ''After that reunion,'' she said, ''I knew it was time to get over high school.''
 Let us wish her luck in doing so. Then let's wish us all the same thing.

HEADLINE: Where Home Prices Rise Steeply, Bankruptcies Fall 

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN

 BODY:
A NEW bankruptcy law takes effect this month in the midst of an insolvency epidemic: personal bankruptcies have been rising steadily since 2000, and will most likely reach an all-time high this year.
 The law, which will make it harder for many people to clear away credit card debt, takes effect on Oct. 17 and has touched off a rush to the courts. In the bankruptcy court for the northern district of Texas, for example, filings for September were 46 percent greater than in September 2004. 
Yet the rise in bankruptcies since 2000 has been far from uniform around the country. While there have been large increases in much of the South and Midwest, sections of the East and West Coast have had declines in filings over the last five years.
 To some extent, the increases in the South and Midwest reflect job losses from manufacturing and agriculture.
 ''Bankruptcy results from a mismatch between income and expenses,'' said Jason Kilborn, a law professor at Louisiana State University. ''These are places where you find really serious job instability -- people who have relatively well-paying jobs, and thus the impression that they can live at a certain level. All of a sudden the job goes under, and they have no alternatives.''
 But even in these regions, there are some bright spots with better economic conditions. Higher oil prices may be contributing to a decline in bankruptcies in West Texas, for instance.
 There is also strong evidence that home equity borrowing is providing a further bulwark against disaster, allowing people to refinance their debt. Many places where bankruptcy is declining -- California, South Florida and the suburbs of New York, Boston and Washington -- are areas where home values have risen steeply.
 An analysis by Ryan Ratcliff, an economist with U.C.L.A. Anderson Forecast, a service of the University of California, Los Angeles, shows that unemployment rates tend to be the most important predictors of bankruptcy in a state. But, he said, ''There is still a strong relationship between higher home prices and lower bankruptcy.'' 
 Economists say that as housing markets begin to cool, bankruptcies are likely to increase. ''At some point you will get a combination of falling values combined with rising payments on adjustable mortgages, which will result in more bankruptcy,'' said Mark Zandi of the research firm Economy.com. ''For these areas of the country that are enjoying such wonderful conditions right now, it will become much less wonderful a few years down the road.''

HEADLINE: Constitution Or Divorce Agreement?

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ

 BODY:
IF Iraq's draft constitution were an orchestral score, it would be one that let a majority vote of the woodwinds determine what key they ought to be playing in. The strings could overrule the conductor's time signature in their section of the pit. The brass and percussion sections could band together and play almost anything they wanted, although they could not secede from the orchestra.
 The constitution, set to be approved or rejected by the Iraqi people in a referendum next Saturday, would allow provincial councils -- the rough equivalent of statehouses -- to cancel or change federal laws they did not like in all but a handful of narrowly defined areas, like drawing up foreign policy and defending Iraq's international borders.
Some constitutional authorities believe the chances are slim that this charter could keep all these disparate entities playing the same song. 
 ''It will be, to me, the beginning of the end of Iraq as a nation-state, but it will be done through constitutional means,'' said Nathan J. Brown, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and author of ''Constitutions in a Nonconstitutional World: Arab Basic Laws and the Prospects for Accountable Government'' (SUNY Press, 2001).
 '''Death certificate' is too strong,'' Mr. Brown said of the draft charter. ''It's a separation agreement.''
 Others see this constitution in an entirely different light, contending that its highly general language could still be molded by legislation and precedent into a subtle intermingling of the Islamic and the democratic that could form the basis for a form of government that would be revolutionary in the Middle East.
 As an illustration of the practical challenges that a country under this charter would face, councils could nullify unwanted federal taxes or declare laws governing marriage, divorce and other family matters to be either largely secular in nature or based much more strictly on Koranic principles. Local militias could be nationalized and declared ''regional guards,'' responsible for the internal security of a province or collection of provinces.
 Still, a constitutional democracy with regions that are out of step with one another would be a more coherent and presumably more peaceful thing than what Iraq is threatening to become: a collection of independent fiefs, none truly viable as full-fledged nations, that are locked in a civil war. 
 That, at least, appears to be the assumption by the United States, whose ambassador to Iraq, Zalmay Khalilzad, spent months bargaining and arm-twisting to obtain this charter.
 In the end, leaders of all but the disaffected Sunni minority agreed on a formula that kept Baghdad as the national capital but drained away to the provinces large amounts of its historical powers -- wielded for decades by the Sunnis.
 Now, people in both Iraq and the West are asking whether that charter has a chance of promoting a semblance of unity, or whether it simply codifies the centripetal forces that threaten to tear the country apart. The issue is so fraught that some analysts are already looking beyond the document and asserting that simply getting political leaders to play out the constitutional process is a sign of progress all by itself.
 ''What's really important is the emergence of a political class that would agree on the rules of the game,'' said Fouad Ajami, who teaches international relations at Johns Hopkins University.
 ''I don't think the constitution will make or break Iraq,'' Mr. Ajami said. ''What will make or break Iraq is the coalition of this national will.''
 It is, nevertheless, the bare text of the constitution that the voters will be focusing on at least over the next week. On that score, there is an equally wide divergence of views, with some experts asserting that the language does an admirable job on things like protecting minority rights and parceling out wealth from the nation's mighty oil industry. Others contend that the same language is vague and unworkable.
 And hanging over all of those calculations is a set of much broader questions on whether the details of the language matter at all given that the Sunnis, whose people form the base of the insurgency, have not agreed on the draft and that even the finest-sounding constitutions in the Middle East are ignored by the ruling elite in country after country.
 As Mr. Ajami delicately put it, ''I don't think countries in the region are ruled by constitutions.''
 With all those questions hanging over the charter even before the referendum, how is it possible to gauge its chances of becoming a functioning document that keeps Iraq from crumbling?
 The first thing to keep in mind, said Noah Feldman, a professor at the New York University School of Law who advised the Coalition Provisional Authority in the early days of the occupation, is that the natural American confidence in the power of a well-written constitution is out of place in Iraq.
 Even in the early days of the American republic, Mr. Feldman said, the constitutional framers understood that if their text tried to undermine accepted common law and religious rulings on the family, then the people would ignore the charter and it would never become a legislative backbone. Provisions like the Bill of Rights, wrote James Madison, would become mere ''parchment barriers'' where they were opposed by a clear majority of the populace.
 In Iraq, as in young America, the constitution must start by creating a rule of law that is broadly consistent with local custom, Mr. Feldman said.
 ''I don't want to say that the text of the document itself is a sideshow,'' he said. But a natural mistake for Americans today, he said, ''is thinking that a constitution is going to shape the facts on the ground, when in fact it's the other way around.''
 That view casts a positive light that is rarely seen in the West on the constitutional provisions that cover family law and the rights of women. Much attention has been showered on a provision letting the rules of a person's specific religious sect govern disputes on marriage, divorce, inheritance and the like. Women's groups have expressed fears that the provision opens the way to clerical rule.
 BUT because human rights, the rights of women and the role of Islam in the government are not powers granted exclusively to the federal government in this constitution, they automatically go to the regions, said Peter W. Galbraith, a former United States ambassador who is the senior diplomatic fellow at the Center for Arms Control and Nonproliferation, and who advised the Iraqi Kurds during the drafting of the constitution.
 That regional flexibility means that the Kurdish north can maintain courts that are entirely secular, Mr. Galbraith said. ''Conversely, the south can apply religious law strictly,'' he said.
 As helpful as that freedom could be for popular acceptance of the constitution, it could further stoke concerns that the Shiite south is well on its way to becoming an Iranian-style theocracy. Moreover, there is another critical area in which the same sort of flexibility could work against the constitution's effectiveness: the distribution of Iraq's vast oil and gas resources.
 Constitutional experts say that of all the things a charter can do to produce an accord among warring groups, perhaps the most important is fairly distributing a country's natural wealth. Daniel L. Rubinfeld, a professor of law and of economics at the University of California at Berkeley who is visiting N.Y.U., said that some specific language helped insure those rights in the new South African constitution, parts of which he helped write in the 1990's.
 ''The constitution needs to set up a framework that assures the ability of the minorities to extract something from the majority,'' said Mr. Rubinfeld, who cautioned that he was not an expert on the Iraqi charter.
 The challenge in Iraq is that the oil reserves are concentrated in the Shiite south and the Kurdish north, seemingly leaving the minority Sunnis vulnerable. The constitution gives control of existing wells to the federal government and of those developed in the future to the regions.
 Because the wording is extremely general, said Amatzia Baram, a senior fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington and a professor of Middle Eastern history at the University of Haifa in Israel, two possibilities may present themselves to the Sunnis: They may decide they have been dealt out and withdraw from the entire process, or they may hope that by voting in future elections, they can elect legislators who can turn the vague language to the Sunnis' advantage, by firming it up with laws that protect minority rights. Their decision will be critical, Mr. Baram said.
 ''If they are being convinced that all is lost, then certainly this constitution will be dividing the Sunnis from the rest of the population,'' he said. ''And that would be very, very sad.''
 Mr. Galbraith, who said the Sunnis should realize substantial revenues from the oil fields, suggested there was not much point in complaining about any dissonances in the music that Iraq and the rest of the world will hear if the constitution is ratified. Given the realities in Iraq, this was the best anyone could have done, he said.
 ''There wouldn't have been a constitution if there wasn't this one,'' Mr. Galbraith said. ''And not having a constitution would have broken the country up.''

HEADLINE: Where To Be Jobless In Europe

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
EUROPEANS are famous for trying to take the sting out of unemployment, with generous and long-lasting jobless benefits. Even when political and business leaders have warned that their societies can no longer afford such largess, the European public has clung to these safety nets.
 But even within Western Europe, some countries are more accommodating to those out of work than others. So it is tempting to ask: Where is it easiest to be unemployed? 
 The answer, predictably, can depend on an individual's situation: whether one is young or old, single or married, childless or with a family, recently out of work or chronically unemployed. But attitude also plays a role: Is the person eager to find another job or looking for a life of leisure? And is the country trying hard to get the employee back to work?
 In Denmark, said David B. Grubb, an economist at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a typical unemployed person might get 80 percent of past income for four years. ''But after the first year,'' he said, ''you've got to spend a lot of your time in temporary jobs or training programs.''
 Europe's lush benefits are often blamed for helping to perpetuate its high unemployment, though it should be noted that Denmark, with perhaps the softest touch of all, has a jobless rate of 4.8 percent, roughly equivalent to the United States'. In addition to the emphasis on job seeking, Denmark has relatively weak job-protection rules, which make it easier for companies to fire workers in the first place, opening up the labor market.
 Mr. Grubb, who has compared unemployment benefits in 26 countries, offers one general rule: the most generous countries are also the ones most likely to put the most pressure on recipients to find new jobs. 
 Germany has historically catered to both those in and out of work. Thanks to its still-powerful labor movement, job protection laws here are among the strictest in Europe. As for taking care of the unemployed, the generosity was epitomized by the notorious 2003 case of ''Florida Rolf,'' a former banker found living in Miami in an apartment near the beach that he paid for with $2,200 a month in German welfare checks.
 In Germany, people who lose their jobs receive 60 percent of their salaries for 12 months to 36 months. Following that, they previously were able to draw long-term assistance and other benefits that could total 53 percent of their wages.
 But Chancellor Gerhard Schroder cut back the long-term payments, and as of next February, Germans who are out of work for more than a year will be entitled to benefits similar to ordinary welfare -- about $414 a month, plus money for rent and utilities.
 That cutback, however, has probably put a firm brake on any further changes to the system. In the national election last month, the voters punished Mr. Schroder by refusing to give him a renewed mandate. But at the same time the electorate denied a majority to his conservative challenger, Angela Merkel, who had advocated even stronger free-market medicine. The likely outcome is government by an alliance of the two major parties, each feeling it imperative not to mess with unemployment benefits.
 Voters reacted so negatively because the government's parsimony coincided with a wave of job cuts that have helped raise the unemployment rate to 9.6 percent. 
 German officials said the change in long-term benefits was intended to discourage able-bodied people from permanently opting out of the work force. But other benefits are also available, and it is unclear whether some people might still get paid more not to work rather than to find a new job.
 ''This is a difficult question that occupies us as well,'' said Eugen Spitznagel, a researcher at the state-run Institute of Employment Research in Nuremberg. ''It's a hypothesis that is plausible, but difficult to prove. We don't have the empirical data yet to answer it directly.''
 Among other European countries, the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal are viewed as particularly generous to the unemployed, while Britain and Greece are seen as among the stingiest. 
 France might be the cushiest alternative of all, however. France not only offers generous compensation, but it has yet to organize an efficient network of job training and placement centers. So in pratcical terms, the most an out-of-work person has to do to maintain benefits, Mr. Grubb said, is to call in every six months to confirm that no new job has been found. 
 The French government is trying to change this laissez-faire approach -- in part by adding yet another benefit. Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin has proposed giving the unemployed a bonus of 1,000 euros, or about $1,200, for taking a job, even as the government weighs a three-strikes rule, under which jobless people would lose their unemployment compensation if they turned down three job offers. 
 The French government is also trying to make it easier for small companies to lay off workers. But that proposal provoked thousands of strikers to take to the streets last week in Paris and other cities. Mrs. Merkel floated a similar idea in Germany, and it did her little good at the polls. Still, some European experts say that French and German leaders are at least looking at the heart of the unemployment problem: that companies are not likely to hire more freely unless they can fire more freely. 
 As Katinka Barysch, the chief economist of the Center for European Reform in London, put it, ''the best place to lose your job is in a country where it's easiest to find a new job.''


CORRECTION-DATE: October 16, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about variations in unemployment benefits in Europe misstated a provision of the French system as explained by David B. Grubb, an economist at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. In France, he said, unemployed people must contact authorities once a month -- not every six months -- to confirm that they have not found a job. (Typically, they must be interviewed in person every six months about their efforts to find work.)

HEADLINE: Drink, Don't Drink. Drink, Don't Drink.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
IN April, Kansas tightened its drunken-driving law. It was nothing surprising: since the days when Carry Nation took a hatchet to its speakeasies, the state has tended to have a low drinking rate and an even lower tolerance for the recklessly inebriated. 
 Yet just a month later, the state relaxed its ban on the Sunday sale of liquor. In some parts, it is now as easy to buy a bottle of gin after church as a stick of butter. 
If Kansas seems at cross-purposes, then consider the zigs and zags of the television industry. In recent years, liquor commercials have sprouted in vast numbers on cable stations and affiliates of the major broadcast networks. But the networks themselves continue to bar them, even as they run beer commercials with bikini-clad women. Liquor commercials, the networks worry, might offend people's sensibilities. 
 Unlike, say, the French or Italians, Americans have often regarded drinking with a kind of unease that gives rise to contradictions and dissonance and boomerang shifts in attitudes. Lately, as the alcohol industry pushes to increase sales by trying to remove some of the regulations and stigma surrounding it, and advocacy groups and health experts push back, these strains seem all the more evident.
 States are tightening some alcohol laws and loosening others, including repealing bans on Sunday sales and liquor billboards, and permitting stores to hold free tasting events for hard liquor. Businesses are embracing alcohol and the dollars it brings, while trying to convey that they do so only halfheartedly.
 Wal-Mart is plunging into liquor retailing, even as it maintains a longstanding ban on alcohol at its headquarters and at all corporate events. Nascar is allowing Jim Beam and other liquor brands to festoon its cars with the emblems of sponsorship, but promises that their messages will be ''strongly grounded in responsibility.'' So television networks that bar liquor commercials are broadcasting races where liquor advertising is prominent.
 ''There are these really ambiguous messages about alcohol that you end up receiving from the leadership of the country,'' said Paul M. Roman, a sociologist at the University of Georgia. ''The messages end up being very mixed up and very confusing. And this ambivalence has been around a long time.''
 In fact, it dates to before independence. Policies regarding alcohol have been shaped by sometimes clashing beliefs. Personal freedom is valued, but a puritanical streak lingers. There is trust in free markets but also a wariness of treating alcohol as just any product.
 Consumption levels have oscillated wildly in American history. They have dropped in recent years, in part because of warnings about drunken driving and the health effects of heavy drinking. Consumption of hard alcohol sagged by roughly 40 percent between 1980 and 2002, according to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism. (Consumption of beer was down 10 percent; consumption of wine was stable.)
 This collapse in sales has led the alcohol industry, especially distillers, to challenge the boundaries of television advertising and state liquor laws. A voluntary agreement to keep liquor commercials off television fell apart in the mid-1990's. But the ads have proliferated only in the last few years. The number of liquor commercials on national cable networks jumped to more than 37,000 in 2004 from 645 in 2001, according to the Center on Alcohol Marketing and Youth at Georgetown University.
 The major broadcast networks will not show the ads -- though cable stations that have the same owners do. 
 Under the current voluntary practices, for example, the Fox Sports cable network will run liquor commercials after 10 p.m., but its corporate cousin, the Fox broadcast network, will not run them when it shows its own nighttime sports programming.
 The distinctions can have little to do with the shows that the commercials will interrupt. Jack Daniels can advertise on the serious-minded ''NewsNight With Aaron Brown'' on CNN, which began accepting liquor ads this year, but not on the commercial time on ''Desperate Housewives'' sold by the ABC network. .
 The major broadcast networks say they are far more regulated than cable stations, so they are leery of offending federal officials, and they reach households across the nation, including areas that frown on drinking. Of course, the cable stations are almost as widely available, though not as widely viewed. What it comes down to is a perception that liquor commercials on the major networks would symbolize that liquor is nearly as unexceptional as Diet Coke, and the nation may not be ready for that.
 A few years ago, NBC tried to become the first broadcast network to run liquor commercials, but retreated under fire from some officials and advocacy groups. ''There is so much sensitivity toward alcohol and how it is consumed,'' explained Alan Wurtzel, president of research at NBC Universal.
 But what about beer commercials? 
 The fissures are also revealed in the debates over bans on Sunday sales of liquor. Twelve states, including Kansas and New York, have now scaled back these laws in some form in recent years, leaving 16 states that still have strict bans on Sunday sales of liquor, according to the Distilled Spirits Council.
 Distillers and merchants have lobbied for the repeals, and lawmakers often agree in hopes that they will reap more taxes from increased sales. Still, the states wind up with their own tangle of messages. On the one hand, officials urge people to drink only in moderation, if at all, and to give the car keys to someone else if they are intoxicated. On the other hand, officials are making alcohol more accessible and visible -- and studies suggest that easier access to alcohol may lead to more social problems, like alcoholism, violence and drunken driving. That is why states raised the drinking age to 21 in the first place.
 In Kansas, some lawmakers expressed these concerns, but a majority in the Legislature sided with distillers and liquor stores in border areas who complained that they were losing business to other states on Sundays.
 ''This was an economic issue,'' said Tom Groneman, director of Alcohol Beverage Control in Kansas. ''It keeps the dollars in Kansas.''
 While the law now offers localities the option of approving or rejecting Sunday sales, it makes one Sunday sacrosanct. No matter what the localities decide, no liquor store in Kansas can open on Easter.

HEADLINE: Lights, Camera, Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By Thomas Conoscenti. 
Thomas Conoscenti is an economist who works for the Association for a Better Long Island, among other groups.

DATELINE: Setauket 

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND has begun to develop a potentially potent economic sector, its very own film and television production industry. Its efforts, however, could be stunted if a labor dispute playing out on the East End moves beyond controversy and into impasse.
 At issue is a disagreement between the Writers Guild of America East and Big Big Productions, which is using the new Wainscott Studios in East Hampton. The dispute involves money, and how big a salary the writers of shows produced at the studios should pocket. But the issue has far more importance than a writer's take-home pay and benefits. For Long Island, the future of the Wainscott Studios may determine if the region can make it in show biz. 
To put into perspective what is at stake for Long Island, the five productions shot at the Silvercup Studios in Queens generate $15 million for New York City's economy. The film industry as a whole employs 100,000 New Yorkers and puts $5 billion into the city's economic coffers. These are stunning numbers that underscore the importance of movie and television productions. The issue is of such importance to Mayor Michael Bloomberg that his commissioner of films, theater and broadcasting is backed up by a host of economic incentives that open doors for the film industry throughout the five boroughs. 
 Steve Levy, Suffolk County's executive, can read a ledger with equal skill. As a result, he has strengthened his cultural affairs office and coordinated its efforts with his economic development office. Mr. Levy's Suffolk County film office now provides a virtual concierge service to the industry, finding locations and accommodations while walking producers through special permits and other requirements. More important, Suffolk officials are not only attracting location productions, they are also bringing business to studios like Wainscott. 
 For Long Island, this opportunity is a second chance. When movies were first recognized as powerful entertainment in the early 1900's, the Vitagraph Company opened a studio in Bay Shore where the ''Keystone Cops'' and ''Our Gang'' comedies had their start. The film technicians behind primitive movie cameras found that the south shore, with its southern exposure, offered perfect conditions for filming. 
 And it wasn't just Bay Shore. Port Washington, with its sand pits, stood in for the Sahara. Legendary heartthrob Rudolph Valentino played his desert scenes in the Hamptons and Long Beach. With access to New York money and the Long Island Rail Road, producers, actors and studio technicians regularly headed east from their Astoria studios to film on location. In time, however, Hollywood became a more compelling location, and the region's film industry declined, until now. 
 The current Writers Guild attack on Big Big Productions is a dispute that's as old as the film industry itself with labor pushing back against anything that strikes them as new and therefore threatening. But Long Island is no stranger to labor disputes. The giant rat inflated at contested job sites is well known -- and as ubiquitous as a Friday night traffic jam on the Long Island Expressway. Nor does the role of celebrities' signatures on guild petitions make Long Islanders more compelled to side with the writers versus management. 
 But we all have a stake in the outcome of this confrontation. While we tend to downplay the competitive nature between New York City and Long Island, city officials will not be displeased if the Wainscott studio is run aground. They know only too well the benefits that a vibrant entertainment industry brings to New York's economy and they have no reason to see their market share eroded. If the guild cripples Wainscott by bleeding its production company, a door that has begun to open for Long Island will start to close. 
 Much as carriage makers had to accept the arrival of the automobile 100 years ago, the Writers Guild should deflate the rat and come to terms with a production company that is leveraging 21st century information technology to produce entertainment. Create a compromise before one side or the other is fatally wounded. In the meantime, the bicounty region needs to take a cue from Mr. Levy and become an advocate of incentives that allow us to strengthen Wainscott Studios and others who wish to follow in its wake on Long Island.

HEADLINE: In Nassau, 3 Countywide Races to Watch

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
VOTERS don't often pay close attention to races for countywide offices other than the top job, county executive. But this year, the action in Nassau is farther down the ticket, in hard-fought races for district attorney, county comptroller and county clerk that have big political implications. 
 In all three, Republicans are desperate either to hold their ground or to score an upset in a year when they have little hope of unseating Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive. The Democrats hope to use Mr. Suozzi's popularity to solidify their hold on the county and to continue the string of surprising advances that began six years ago, when they first won a majority in the County Legislature.
 Denis Dillon, the Nassau district attorney, has not faced a serious political challenge since 1974, when he first won office. Now as he runs for his ninth term, Mr. Dillon, a Republican, enjoys many of the advantages of a long incumbency. But he has also met a surprisingly tough opponent in Kathleen Rice, a Democrat. 
 A 40-year-old Garden City native who interned for Mr. Dillon in 1989 when she was a law student, Ms. Rice has already landed one political blow against Mr. Dillon, who is 71 and lives in Rockville Centre: she beat him in the Independence Party primary last month. Ms. Rice has also raised more than $300,000 for her campaign, much more than previous challengers.
 As evidence of how threatened Mr. Dillon is by Ms. Rice, Democrats point to Republican legal action intended to stop the Board of Elections from certifying results of the Independence primary. The case hinges on whether both factions of the party had the right to select slates of candidates, with Ms. Rice on one and Mr. Dillon on the other.
 ''The Republicans wouldn't be willing to stand before the public and say 'I don't care how you voted,' unless they were worried that the outcome could be worse,'' said Jay Jacobs, the Nassau Democratic chairman. ''Clearly, what they're afraid of is that Dillon could lose,'' he said.
 Mr. Dillon distanced himself from the effort to cancel out the primary. ''I'm named in the motion, but I'm not pushing anything,'' he said. ''I'd like to have the Independence line, but it's not vital. I've never needed any of the third-party lines to win.''
 The situation is reversed in the race for comptroller, where Howard Weitzman, the Democratic incumbent, faces a tough challenge from an energetic young Republican opponent, Donald Clavin, Hempstead's receiver of taxes who beat him in the Independence primary. 
 The county clerk seat is open this year; the present clerk, Karen Murphy, a Republican, is running for a state Supreme Court judgeship instead of seeking re-election. Maureen C. O'Connell, an eight-year Republican assemblywoman from East Williston, is running against Tricia Ferrell, the Democratic candidate and an assistant district attorney from Uniondale. Democrats say she could be the first black official elected countywide. 
 Republicans are counting on Mr. Dillon, their highest-ranking incumbent, to be a top vote-getter once again. ''Denis is completely independent as a district attorney, and that's how people view him,'' said Joseph Mondello, the chairman of the Nassau Republican Party. ''I expect enough votes from him to help other candidates on the line.''
 Mr. Dillon contends that his office has achieved a 98 percent felony conviction rate, the highest in the nation for counties of one million people or more. His staff says the felony conviction rate has stood at 95 percent or higher since 1983,
 But Ms. Rice calls the 98 percent statistic artificial, saying that Mr. Dillon's office offered plea bargains in 72 percent of violent felony cases and took only 3 percent of felony indictments to trial. ''This is not being tough on crime,'' she said. ''At some point, you have to worry about meting out justice, rather than just keeping up statistics.'' 
 Mr. Dillon said that his office does offer plea deals, ''but we only plead down one degree, and it moves cases quickly.'' The low trial rate, he said, was actually a sign of a well-run office: ''We take everything that the police bring in, and we prosecute vigorously, and we have extraordinary results.''
 His opponent's criticisms, he added, were a sign of inexperience. ''She has no knowledge of what it takes to manage other lawyers, or to run a district attorney's office,'' he said. 
 Ms. Rice worked as an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and she resigned as a federal prosecutor in Philadelphia in the spring to return to Long Island for the race. 
 Mr. Dillon began his political career as a Democrat, but he left the party in 1988 over the abortion issue; he is an outspoken opponent of abortion. When demonstrators opposed to abortion were arrested in 1986, Mr. Dillon turned the cases over to a special prosecutor instead of having his office handle them.
 Ms. Rice called the practice ''a glaring example of how he has chosen to put his personal views above his job.'' Mr. Dillon said it was an appropriate step to avoid a potential conflict of interest. 
 While Ms. Rice has run a spirited campaign, Mr. Dillon may be as unbeatable as his Manhattan counterpart, Robert M. Morgenthau, was in the Democratic primary last month. 
 ''It's exceptionally difficult to defeat an icon, especially when there's no overwhelming argument to get rid of him,'' said Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic political consultant. 
 In the comptroller's race, Mr. Weitzman, a first-term incumbent, has a feisty opponent in Mr. Clavin. ''The comptroller is supposed to provide checks and balances in government, but my opponent just hasn't done his job,'' Mr. Clavin said. ''He's the administration's lap dog, and he does what he's told.''
 Mr. Weitzman considers himself part of the Suozzi team, as reflected in his campaign fliers and television commercials. ''But it's ludicrous to call me a rubber stamp of the administration,'' Mr. Weitzman said, ''because my opponents use my audit reports to criticize Tom Suozzi.'' 
 He pointed to a recent audit that found shoddy management and excessive overtime at the county jail, and another that revealed mismanagement and negligence in the county's economic development agencies, as signs of his willingness to hold officials of his own party to account. 
 Still, Republican leaders say that Mr. Weitzman uses his office to go after agencies run by Republicans, like some of the special sanitary districts in the Town of Hempstead, where Mr. Weitzman says that he found waste, chaotic bookkeeping and excessive costs to homeowners. Republicans called the sanitary district audits an election-year stunt meant to help a fellow Democrat, Harvey Levinson, the county assessor, in his race for Hempstead town supervisor. 
 Mr. Weitzman said he was not playing politics. ''Most of my audits were aimed at county departments, but I can't audit Democrats all of the time,'' he said. ''The bigger question regarding the sanitary districts is, why haven't they called for reform in these hidden governments, because clearly the abuses we've pointed out are outrageous.''
 Leaders from both parties hope success in the district attorney's and comptroller's races will trickle down to the clerk's seat. Ms. O'Connell, the Republican, is well known in her Assembly district but has had little success outside it; she was defeated twice, in 1997 and 1999, in races for North Hempstead supervisor. Ms. Ferrell is a political newcomer. 
 Even Mr. Jacobs, the Democratic Party chairman, said, ''That's a seat that's hard to get people charged up about, but we hope that people will see that the clerk's officehas been part of the Republican patronage mill for too long.''
