HEADLINE: Swimming With the Sharks, and Devil Rays

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
TEN days before he was to replace Vince Naimoli as managing partner of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, Stuart Sternberg was talking about his impending elevation to the position of controlling owner, but not too loudly. Sternberg was concerned that if Naimoli heard or read he was talking about the change before it occurred, he might try to stall the turnover.
 ''There's not a lot I can say about anything given the contract,'' Sternberg said. ''We're in a very touchy time right now. Vince and I have been talking on and off since we signed the deal a year and four months ago. We've talked about pushing the date back, moving it up. It's been changing since the date we signed the agreement.''
Sternberg, a 46-year-old New Yorker, who will try to resuscitate the Devil Rays' lamentable franchise, was genuinely concerned that Naimoli could still foul up the plans even though they were stipulated in a contract. 
 ''I don't know if I can talk about that,'' he said, responding to a question about Naimoli. ''It's just got to wait some period of time, not to say it's a long period of time. If anything came out, it would be damaging for my ability to go forward and get this deal done.''
 The deal is done. It was announced Thursday, and there is nothing Naimoli can do to upset it. Naimoli, the man who took baseball to the west coast of Florida, then wrecked it single-handedly, has the title of chairman emeritus, but it is a title only. It does not entitle him to do anything that would affect the operation of the Devil Rays. He has done enough in the past eight years to affect the operation, nothing good.
 Now it is in Sternberg's hands to bring the franchise to life. This is where he starts.
 The Devil Rays tied for the second-worst record in the major leagues this year and had the smallest attendance. After a 2004 season in which they won a franchise-record 70 games and did not finish in last place for the first time in seven years, they reverted to 67 victories and last place. 
 Sternberg is nevertheless confident he can turn things around. ''As long as people don't expect anything to happen overnight,'' he said. ''You have to change things when you go into a business.''
 Sternberg has begun the changes, dismissing Chuck LaMar, the only general manager the team has had, and two of his chief aides. Sternberg will also need a new manager because Lou Piniella did not stick around for the last year of his contract, taking a $2.2 million buyout instead of waiting to get his $4.4 million salary.
 Sternberg said he would look for a manager ''who wants to work with younger players and get out in the community.''
 On the business side, he said, Matt Silverman, a 29-year-old Harvard graduate, will be the president and run the team day to day. It remains to be seen how much economic energy Sternberg will put into the Devil Rays, whose $30 million payroll was the lowest in the majors this year. 
 ''There's a lot of work to be done,'' Sternberg said. ''You like to be able to build something.''
 Why did he choose to buy into the Devil Rays? Sternberg said that he had looked into the possibility of buying a small interest in the Mets, but that it did not work out.
 ''Baseball,'' he said. ''It was simple as that. I've been put in a position where I can afford to do it. I didn't think the economics were atrocious. It wouldn't be a good business investment if it were tires, but it's baseball.''
 Might he have been foolish, though, to have gone into the baseball business with Naimoli?
 ''It's been suggested, but I try to look past individuals and look at the big picture,'' he said. ''I did it with the feeling that at some point I'll be able to put my stamp on it. We liked the opportunity of the marketplace, but we knew there was going to be a challenge.''
 Sternberg and his five partners are believed to have paid $65 million for 48 percent of the team, then made an additional payment to induce Naimoli to leave now rather than after the 2006 season, as the original agreement provided. 
 Sternberg was in position to buy into the Devil Rays because in 2000, Goldman Sachs bought Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, an options-trading firm in which Sternberg was a partner, for a reported $6.5 billion. Some of his partners in Spear are now his partners in the Devil Rays.
 Sternberg grew up in Brooklyn and started working on Wall Street getting coffee in the 1970's. He lives in Westchester County and has an office in Manhattan.
 ''Business expertise I have certainly,'' he said. ''I have no more baseball expertise than probably a ton of fans out there, but that's a passionate bunch. And a well-read bunch. I consider myself both, with a very good business background.''
 As his first steps toward changing the face of the franchise, Sternberg said, he will ''reach out to the surrounding communities and the entire region and try to make them care and have them care about the team.''
 He knows his task will not be easy. ''The whole concept of baseball was in free fall,'' he said, but he added optimistically, ''We should be able to get this into the middle of the pack in three to five years.''
 First, owners of the other 29 teams have to approve him, but that is a formality. In fact, Naimoli was held in such low esteem in baseball that the owners will probably approve Sternberg with a standing ovation.

Reds Put Their Trust in Narron
 Of the four managers who assumed command of their teams during the season, only Jerry Narron of Cincinnati avoided a losing record and only Narron has been hired for next season. Cincinnati had a 46-46 record under Narron, Pittsburgh was 12-14 under Pete Mackanin, Baltimore was 23-32 under Sam Perlozzo and Kansas City struggled to a 43-69 record under Buddy Bell.
 On the day that the Reds named Narron as their manager for next season, Doug Melvin, his minor league roommate and battery mate, was in the process of having his contract extended as the general manager of the Milwaukee Brewers. 
 ''We played together in the Yankee system in 1976 in the Florida State League, and then went to the Eastern League and played together in '77,'' Melvin said. ''We became good friends. Jerry was traded to Seattle, and there were years when we didn't see each other, but our paths crossed later on.''
 When Melvin was no longer pitching but Narron was still catching, Melvin, then Baltimore's minor league director, signed him to play in the Orioles' system. 
 '''Jerry, I don't think you're as much a prospect now, but I'd like you to come to Rochester and be a team leader''' Melvin said he told Narron. '''Afterwards you could become a coach and a manager.'''
 Narron followed Melvin's outline, impressed Johnny Oates, then Rochester's manager, and Birdie Tebbetts, an Orioles scout, and eventually became the Texas Rangers' manager when Oates's cancer was diagnosed.
 When they roomed together in the minors, Melvin recalled, they had a third roommate, a trainer, and the apartment had only one bedroom.
 ''We flipped a coin to see who would sleep in a walk-in closest,'' Melvin said. ''Jerry lost the flip, and he slept in the closet all year.''
 As he climbed the managerial ladder, Narron's living accommodations became better. 

Unhappiness Loves Company
 Unlike the Mets, who finished the season strong under their rookie manager, Willie Randolph, the Marlins and the Orioles have much resuscitation work to do before next season. The Orioles, to be sure, had an unusual distraction with Rafael Palmeiro's shocking suspension for steroids use, but he had not been an integral part of their offense, and the other players should have been able to overcome the development. They did not, and neither did the team as a whole. 
 Peter Angelos, the unhappy owner, could make a clean sweep of the people in charge and start anew once more. He has to make decisions about two general managers and a manager.
 Jeffrey Loria, the Marlins' owner, did not want to talk about his team, and who could blame him? Considered by many as the best team in the National League East, not to mention the wild-card favorite, the Marlins had a one-game wild-card lead after the games of Sept. 13, then lost two games to Houston, two of three to the Phillies and to the Mets, and three each to the Braves and to the Nationals, 12 losses in 14 games.
 The team erupted in the hottest display of clubhouse dissension seen in recent years. Like Angelos, Loria has a lot of work to do, and he may start by trading Carlos Delgado, whose contract he may consider too expensive to retain.

There's Evil and Then There's Evil
 Nearly three years ago, the Yankees and the Red Sox fought over the services of Jose Contreras, a Cuban defector, whose decision to sign with the Yankees prompted Larry Lucchino, the Red Sox' president, to refer to the Yankees as the evil empire. Contreras did not pitch particularly well for the Yankees, and they traded him to the White Sox.
 This season, especially late this season, he has sparkled for the White Sox, winning his last nine starts, including his playoff start against the Red Sox on Tuesday. He will either pitch against the Yankees or the Angels in the league championship series this week.
 Now who's evil?

LENGTH: 1107 words

HEADLINE: Continents Apart, Two Odysseys on Parallel Tracks

BYLINE: By CHARLES ISHERWOOD

 BODY:
Enterprise is more easily rewarded in the theater than in film or television, primarily because the price tag isn't so high. Aspiring filmmakers need a whole apparatus to support them, not to mention a big checkbook, but theatrical talent just needs somebody to lend a stage, somebody to lend an ear and somebody to spread the word.
 Danai Gurira and Nikkole Salter, the authors and performers of the new play ''In the Continuum,'' are appearing only two nights a week at the 59E59 Theaters, courtesy of Primary Stages, but these fiercely talented young women won't be spending much downtime in the near future, if their ambition meets with the success it deserves.
The play, adroitly directed by Robert O'Hara, is a kaleidoscopic diptych of two black women -- one a middle-class wife and mother in Zimbabwe, the other a 19-year-old at loose ends in Los Angeles -- whose lives are suddenly upended by H.I.V. diagnoses. Moving, smart, spirited and powerfully funny, it happens to boast a flawless cast, too: Ms. Gurira and Ms. Salter, who met as acting graduate students at New York University, possess the strong presence and confident technique needed to bring out the subtle force and potent flavoring in their writing. 
 ''It sounds depressing,'' whined the friend I invited when I described the play's worthy journalistic subject matter. Worthy it certainly is, but ''In the Continuum'' emphatically is not a downer. And while that equally uninviting epithet ''thought provoking'' applies, the disturbing points the play gently makes about the status of black women both in America and in Africa are humanized with such emotional vibrancy that the play leaves little aftertaste of sorrow.
 Much has been written about the alarming susceptibility of black women to H.I.V. infection, and its rampaging progress in Africa. But Ms. Gurira and Ms. Salter write the story in flesh and blood -- in the medium of life, which is realized most immediately onstage. And life, hard as it has suddenly become for the central characters in ''In the Continuum,'' is never just something to shed tears over.
 The stories of Abigail (Ms. Gurira), a news reader at the government broadcast service in Zimbabwe, and Nia (Ms. Salter), a Nordstrom employee fired for taking a five-finger discount one time too many, proceed along separate tracks that run parallel at telling moments, and intersect, at least on a dramatic plane, at others.
 Abigail, smart, ambitious and self-confident, clings uncertainly to her middle-class status as the economy of Robert Mugabe's Zimbabwe collapses around her. She is first seen blithely chattering to colleagues about her young son and her inattentive husband. She is hoping that a new pregnancy will keep him closer to home. ''He'll come around, he just needs another boy, that will help,'' Ms. Gurira briskly says in her wonderfully melodious voice. ''A girl?'' she sniffs. ''What am I going to do in this world with a girl?''
 Nia, gleaming with sass and attitude, is first introduced lecturing her friend Trina in the bathroom of a nightclub. Nia has pinned her hopes for the future on her boyfriend, Darnell, a basketball star who has his pick of college scholarships. Despite a bumpy past and a few stints in foster homes, Nia could still make something of herself, too. She won $500 in a poetry contest, after all, and, in one of the show's funniest interludes, she shares with Trina the mechanics of writing haiku, whipping up an impromptu piece to illustrate the form's syllabic simplicities. The first line, addressed to a female rival, is unprintable, but the poem concludes: ''Wit yo' crunchy baby hair -- seven! Leave Darnell alone -- five.''
 One of the most tensely powerful moments comes soon thereafter, in a deftly staged sequence in which Ms. Gurira is seen in the role of a nurse casually giving Abigail the news that she has tested H.I.V.-positive. Instead of Abigail's reaction, we witness Nia's brassy mask melt away as she absorbs the same news from a nurse at the hospital where she and Trina have landed after a shooting at the club.
 Abigail and Nia's odysseys then diverge, even as Ms. Gurira and Ms. Salter continue to underscore the ways in which these women living in disparate cultures, with vastly different economic and social climates, struggle with the same essential quandry: how to move ahead in a world in which everything has changed and yet nothing has changed. Their problems have multiplied, but their opportunities are still largely tied to the chance of getting -- or hanging on to -- a male provider, in both cases the man who infected them.
 Shortly after receiving their diagnoses, Abigail and Nia recede into the background as Ms. Gurira and Ms. Salter portray the people they turn to for guidance and comfort. As they move among these characters, the actresses display the breadth of their acting skills as well as the meticulous attention they've paid to the construction of character. Each portrait comes through in sharp, photographic detail.
 But it's here that the play's beginnings as an acting-school project become discernible. Stronger development of the central characters would probably be more satisfying, and some of the supplementary ones -- a witch doctor, Nia's guidance counselor -- are drawn too satirically. But if Abigail and Nia's disappearance is a dramatic liability, their evaporation from the narrative of their lives is also a potent metaphor for the simultaneous absence and presence of H.I.V.-positive women in their communities, in which taboos about AIDS are still a powerful and destructive force.
 Nia and Abigail's stories dovetail again as the play concludes, on a slightly contrived note of symmetry, with each facing a chance to confront the man who has infected her, and to bring to light the anguish each has been grappling with alone. But neither the play's flaws nor its grim subject can chill the warm afterglow it leaves behind, of human struggles explored, illumined and embraced.

In the Continuum

Written and performed by Danai Gurira and Nikkole Salter; directed by Robert O'Hara. Costumes by Sarah Hillard; lighting by Jim French; sound by Lindsay Jones; properties design by Jay Duckworth; production supervision, PRF Productions; production stage manager, Kate Hefel; director of marketing, Louis Bavaro; associate artistic director, Tyler Marchant. Presented by Primary Stages, Casey Childs, founder and executive producer; Andrew Leynse, artistic director; Elliot Fox, managing director. At 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues; (212)279-4200. Through Oct. 30. Running time: 1 hour 30 minutes.

WHAT ABOUT GALBRAITH? -- The winner of this year's Nobel in economics is being announced today, and there are candidates aplenty. One giant of the field, John Kenneth Galbraith, below, who administered price controls under Franklin D. Roosevelt and who will turn 97 on Saturday, has never received the honor. His most recent work, ''The Economics of Innocent Fraud,'' was published last year. 
 TRADE PARLEY -- The United States is playing host to trade ministers from 15 World Trade Organization members today in the hope of reaching a breakthrough accord on national subsidies to farmers, long a bone of contention between Washington and the European Union. Rob Portman, the trade representative, is hoping for a consensus on reducing subsidies and taking other market-opening measures. He is also expected to meet the European Union trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, to talk about another enduring trade dispute, European subsidies to Airbus.
ENOUGH ABOUT INTEREST RATES -- Let's talk about exchange rates -- specifically, the reluctance of China's leaders to loosen the yuan's link to the dollar. Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, head to Beijing, first to take part in meetings of finance ministers and central bank presidents, starting tomorrow. Then, on Sunday, Mr. Snow and Mr. Greenspan will open talks with Chinese officials on economic issues, notably American demands that the yuan be allowed to appreciate more rapidly against the dollar. The Treasury has postponed the release of a report on global currency practices and abuses, originally due out Saturday, until the two men return home.
 OH, ALL RIGHT, LET'S TALK ABOUT INTEREST RATES, TOO -- With inflation worries unnerving the markets last week, Friday is shaping up as a day of portents for the Fed's evolving interest rate policy. The Consumer Price Index for September will be released in the morning, and if it contains worse-than-expected news, brace yourself for turmoil in early trading. August's trade deficit will be reported on Thursday.
 EARNINGS SPOTLIGHT -- The third-quarter earnings season is under way. This week will feature Alcoa today, Apple and Merrill Lynch tomorrow, Johnson & Johnson and Monsanto on Wednesday and General Electric on Friday.

High Gas Prices Are a Boon to Internet Retailers
There's nothing like an energy squeeze to buoy the spirits of Internet merchants. Online shopping sites, already on a roll, are getting help from the high price of gasoline, which is prompting untold numbers of consumers to boot up their PC's instead of driving their S.U.V.'s to the mall. Matt Hyde, the senior vice president for merchandising and logistics at Recreational Equipment Inc., which operates REI.com, says it benefits in two ways: consumers are more likely to turn to the Web site, and they buy more bike-related products to avoid using gas. The music industry in Japan has asked the government there to charge a royalty that would be added to the price of portable digital music players. The fee, which will be probably be 2 to 5 percent of the retail price, would go to recording companies, songwriters and artists as compensation for lost revenue from home copying. [C4.]

HEADLINE: Forget Blogs, Print Needs Its Own IPod

BYLINE: By DAVID CARR

 BODY:
SOMETIMES what appears to be a threat is actually a life preserver. 
 The poor defenseless music industry cowered -- then prosecuted -- when the monster of digital downloads came lurching over the horizon. Then the iPod came along and music looks like a business again -- a smaller business, eked out in 99- cent units -- but still a business.
Cable channels were supposed to gut network television, but instead have become a place where shows like ''Seinfeld'' and ''Law and Order'' are resold and rewatched. The movie industry reacted to DVD's as though they were a sign of the imminent apocalypse, and now studios are using their libraries to churn profits. 
 Which brings us to the last of the great analog technologies, the one many of you are using right now.
 The newspaper business is in a horrible state. It's not that papers don't make money. They make plenty. But not many people, or at least not many on Wall Street, see a future in them. In an attempt to leave the forest of dead trees and reach the high plains of digital media, every paper in the country is struggling mightily to digitize its content with Web sites, blogs, video and podcasts. 
 And they are half right. Putting print on the grid is a necessity, because the grid is where America lives. But what the newspaper industry really needs is an iPod moment. 
 According to a nifty piece of polling, directed by Bob Papper of Ball State University in Muncie, Ind., and released last week, average Americans spend more time online, on the phone, punching the remote, the radio and the game console than they do sleeping -- a total of nine hours a day. And much of the time, they are using more than one medium simultaneously, answering e-mail messages while returning calls with a TV buzzing in the background.
 For all the print newspaper's elegance -- it is a very portable, searchable technology -- it has some drawbacks. A paper is a static product in a dynamic news age, and while every medium is after eyeballs, the industry has to take that quite literally. You cannot read this story while driving in your car -- which is how most of America commutes -- and you cannot have it on in the background. America is hooked on ''companion'' media, a pet platform that sits in the corner and pays attention to you when you pay attention to it.
 No wonder that print is taking a hit. In the Ball State study, the Internet in all of its incarnations beat out reading print materials in all forms in every age bracket up to 65. 
 Print's anachronisms, whether it is the last-mile delivery, the slaying of forests, or the sale of thick packages that most consumers use only small slices of, make change inevitable once a better answer is available. 
 Consider if the line between the Web and print matter were erased by a device for data consumption, not data entry -- all screen, no baggage -- that was uplinked and updated constantly: a digital player for the eyes, with an iTunes-like array of content available at a ubiquitous volume and a low, digestible price. 
 Sure, there are tablet PC's and so-called viewpads out there, but they need to boot every time they are used -- they are just computers without keyboards. The iPod was not a new kind of CD player, it was a new way of listening to music. And the dangling white headphones became something that brought joy to the ears and also cachet to the wearer.
 ''There are all sorts of devices coming along,'' said Dick Brass, who built the first spelling checker that worked and a format for e-books for Microsoft. ''When something is good enough and close enough to paper for people to say, 'I want to use this,' then things will change quickly as they have with the iPod.''
 Newspapers might live long on such devices, but again, there are hurdles, some technical, some economic.
 ''It looks simple to come up with a tablet that works, but it is not,'' said Esther Dyson, a consultant on digital issues. ''In order to have the power and portability you need, you need power. The screen is the part of the device that uses the most power.'' 
 Mr. Brass and others have suggested that superthin lithium batteries will do the trick, or that the power source can be built into the spine of a fold-out two-page device.
 But even when such a gadget is finally in a form consumers will glom onto, newspapers will have to fight for space and mindshare. And it is axiomatic thus far that online customers are much lower-margin customers than print customers. Because there is no scarcity of ad space on the Web, you cannot charge nearly so much for a banner ad on a page with millions of hits as you can for a double-page spread in a national paper. 
 The real peril of the industry has been the uncoupling of the editorial model -- still salient if the Hurricane Katrina coverage is any indication -- from the business model, which relies in part on classified advertising. The Web gives classifieds a functionality that print will never match. (Thank you, Craigslist.) And everybody knows consumers on the Web do not want to pay for what they can get free, right?
 Maybe not. As iTunes has demonstrated, there is a vast swath of consumers who are willing to pay for what they want and avoid the moral taint of unauthorized use.
 There is already a crisscross of intention on the part of the current content providers. The primary gesture of Google and Yahoo -- search is actually content -- is now being woven with video, paid columnists and, ye gads, even some reporters. Television networks are beginning to explore whether people would pay for an on-demand version of their product. Blogs are federating into verticals of quality to be sold to advertisers. Broadcast radio worries about competition from satellite radio while satellite wonders if it can get people to unplug their iPods. 
 That is the future that newspapers have to prepare for. Readers no longer care so much who you are, they just want to know what you know.
 That may sound grim for big media brands, the kind of proposition that will not provide enough cash flow to finance a squad of reporters examining what a hurricane left behind or venturing out onto the streets of Baghdad. But in a frantic age where the quality of the information can be critical, being a reliable news source humming away in everyone's backpack sounds just useful enough to be a business.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 581 words

HEADLINE: Lincoln National Is Poised To Buy a Smaller Insurer

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

 BODY:
The Lincoln National Corporation, a midsize life insurance company, is in advanced talks to buy a smaller rival, Jefferson Pilot Financial, for about $7.5 billion, according to people briefed on the transaction. 
 The deal, which could be announced as early as today, may be presented as a merger of equals, despite the disparity in size.
Lincoln, with assets of $91.7 billion, compared with $29.5 billion for Jefferson, is expected to pay a premium of about 10 percent over Jefferson's closing price on Friday of $50.79 a share. And Jon A. Boscia, the chief executive of Lincoln, is expected to take charge of the combined companies. People briefed on the transaction cautioned that negotiations had not yet been completed and that the talks could still collapse. 
 Spokesmen for the companies did not return phone calls for comment, but other industry executives said that midlevel executives at Lincoln had been instructed to call brokerage houses and other distributors of Lincoln's products as early as Monday to inform them of the merger. 
 Lincoln, which is based in Philadelphia, reported earnings of $707 million on revenue of $5.4 billion last year. Jefferson Pilot, whose main offices are in Greensboro, N.C., had net income of $546 million on $4.1 billion in revenue. Both companies have been in business for nearly 100 years.
 Last fall, Mr. Boscia signaled his intention to use acquisitions to move Lincoln up from the unheralded range of midsize companies. After the merger, Lincoln, which is already a leader in the sale of variable annuities (a combination of mutual funds and insurance), would rise in a merger from 16th to 12th in the rankings of American insurance companies, with $121 billion in assets, according to the A.M. Best Company, a rating agency. 
 A merger would also put Lincoln in fifth place after Prudential Financial in the sale of life insurance, and raise it to fifth place after MetLife in the rankings for sales of fixed annuities, which provide a modest but steady return without taxation until the savings are withdrawn. 
 Industry specialists said a deal with Jefferson could add stability to Lincoln's earnings, which are volatile because of its emphasis on variable annuities and their fluctuations in the stock market. But the specialists said that Jefferson's heavy lineup of sluggish and, at the moment, underperforming fixed annuities and traditional life insurance could also slow the pace of Lincoln's growth. 
 Even after a merger with Jefferson, Lincoln would lag far behind the giants of life insurance in size. Analysts estimate the assets of MetLife, the largest of the companies focusing on life insurance, at more than $400 billion. And Lincoln and Jefferson would have a combined market value of $15.5 billion, compared with $36.6 billion for MetLife. 
 Both Lincoln and Jefferson, the industry specialists said, have posted shrinking earnings on fixed annuities and traditional life insurance as interest rates have fallen. With those products, the insurers typically contracted to provide a return to investors of 3 percent or 4 percent. 
 The insurers aimed to earn much more by investing the premiums they received for the annuities and life insurance. But lower market interest rates have made that impossible. 
 Industry specialists said Jefferson Pilot had been looking for a merger partner for more than three years because its earnings have been stagnant and its ability to compete has been limited by its smaller size.
